Sec. 10-110. - Transfer of license. 
When a licensee shall have made a bona fide sale of the business he has been licensed under this article to conduct, he may obtain a transfer of the license issued under this article to the purchaser of the business, but only if, before the transfer, the application of the purchaser shall be approved by the city in accordance with the same procedure provided in sections 10-104 through 10-106, in the case of issuance of new licenses. Before the issuance of any transfer of license, the transferee shall pay a transfer fee of ten percent of the appropriate annual license fee. Licenses issued under this article shall not be transferable in any other way than as provided in this section. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-25), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-111. - Licensee moving to new location; changing name of business. 
(a)  New location. A licensee may move his licensed premises to a new location and operate at the new location upon approval by the city of the licensee's application for a change of location. The licensee shall submit to the city an application for a change of location, accompanied by an application fee of $200.00 at the time the application is filed. The application will contain, or have attached to it, a plan drawn to appropriate scale of the licensed premises at the new location indicating the area to be included in the new licensed premises, all windows, doors, entrances and exits and the fixed structural features of the new licensed premises. If more than one license has been issued to the licensed premises at the old location, the licensee shall state in his application for a change of location which of the licenses are being moved to the proposed new location. Upon approval of the application, there shall be issued to the licensee a license for the new location without the payment of any further fee. 
(b)  Change of name. No licensee may change the name of the business located at his licensed premises without first giving the city 30 days' notice in writing of such change and without first making payment of a change-of-name fee, the amount of which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-26), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-112. - Suspension. 
(a)  Violations of health, building, zoning or fire provisions. If a licensed premises is found in violation of a health, building, zoning or fire provision of this article, the appropriate agency shall notify the licensee of the violation according to the standard procedures of the agency and shall follow its normal agency procedures for correcting the violation and shall grant the licensee the right to exhaust applicable administrative remedies. Should the licensee fail either to correct the violation or to obtain an administrative reversal of the agency finding, the appropriate agency shall notify the city manager, who shall forthwith initiate procedures for suspension of the license. 
(b)  Other violations. If a jury or other trier of fact in a court of law finds that a licensee has violated section 10-40, whether or not an adjudication of guilt has been entered, the city manager shall forthwith initiate procedures for suspension of license. 
(c)  Fine or suspension of license. 
(1)  Procedure. Upon receiving notice that a licensee has violated a provision of this article, as provided in subsections (a) and (b) above, the city manager shall suspend the license issued for the premises where the violation occurred, unless otherwise provided below, and shall notify the licensee of his action. Notification shall be by certified mail and shall be sent to the address on the license application, which shall be considered the correct address. 
(2)  Periods of suspension. A single violation by a licensee of this article shall result in suspension of the adult entertainment license for 30 days. Upon a second violation of this article within a period of two years from the date of a prior violation of this article, but not including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for 90 days. Upon a third violation of this article within a period of two years from the first of three violations, but not including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for 180 days. All periods of suspension shall begin on the 15th day from the date the city mails a notice of suspension to the licensee or on the date the licensee delivers his license to the city, whichever comes first. 
Employers of adult entertainment establishments are responsible for the acts of their employees. Two violations of this article within a 30-day period by the same employee, as determined by a jury or other trier of fact, shall result in the suspension for seven days of the adult entertainment license of the establishment where the employee works or performs. Upon a third violation of this article by the same employee within a period of 90 days from the date of a prior violation of this article, but not including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for four weeks. Upon a fourth violation of this article by the same employee within a period of 180 days from the first of three violations, but not including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for 180 days. Upon a fifth violation of this article by the same employee within a period of one year from the first of five violations, but not including any time during which the license was suspended, the license shall be suspended for one year. All periods of suspension shall begin on the 15th day from the date the city mails a notice of suspension to the licensee or on the date the licensee delivers his license to the city, whichever comes first. 
(3)  Surrender of license required. If a licensee after having been mailed notice of the suspension of his license in the manner herein provided fails to surrender his license to the city within 15 days or fails otherwise to account for the license to the satisfaction of the city, the period of suspension of the license shall be extended until and shall not expire until a period has elapsed after the date of surrender of the license, or after the date of expiration of the license, whichever comes first, which is identical in length with the original period of suspension. 
(4)  When a license is suspended for a violation of a health, building, zoning or fire provision of this article, as described in subsection (a) of this section, the license shall not be reissued until the violation is corrected. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-27), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-113. - Appeals. 
Appeals alleging error in the denial, suspension or revocation of a license or permit under this article shall be by petition for a formal hearing before the city council. A notice of intent to appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within 15 days of the mailing of a notice of denial, suspension or revocation of a license or permit. Thereafter, and upon payment of a fee of $50.00 to cover administrative costs, a hearing will be scheduled within 30 days. The city clerk shall give the petitioning party at least ten days' written notice of the time and place for the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-28), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-114. - License fee. 
There are hereby levied annual license fees under this article, which shall be paid to the city. The amount of such fees is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-29), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-115. - Records and reports; consent by licensee. 
Each licensee shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by the city manager to implement this article and carry out its purpose. By applying for a license under this article, an individual, partnership or corporation shall be deemed to have consented to the provisions of this article and to the exercise by the city and other interested agencies of the powers given by section 10-77 in the manner therein specified. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-30), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-116. - More than one classification of adult entertainment at a single location. 
No building, premises, structure or other facility that contains any classification of adult entertainment shall permit or contain any other classification of adult entertainment. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-31), 1-10-95)  
Secs. 10-117—10-140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PERMIT FOR EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 10-141. - Adult entertainment permit required. 
Unless specifically excluded below, it shall be unlawful for any person to obtain employment in an establishment licensed or permitted to operate under this article, for any form of consideration, or to exhibit or display specified anatomical areas in an establishment licensed or permitted to operate under this article unless such person shall have first obtained an adult entertainment permit or temporary permit from the city manager. This section shall not apply to employees engaged exclusively in performing janitorial or maintenance services. This permit requirement shall be independent of and in addition to any permit or license requirements that may be imposed on employees pursuant to any federal, state or local statute, law or regulation. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(a)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-142. - Qualifications. 
Employees of a licensee on premises licensed under this article shall not be less than 18 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(b)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-143. - Application for and issuance of adult entertainment permit. 
(a)  All employees of an adult entertainment establishment shall file an application for an adult entertainment permit with the city occupational licensing department. 
(b)  All applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable payment of a fee on file in the city clerk's office. 
(c)  The city shall submit the names of all applicants for an adult entertainment permit who intend to work in an adult dancing establishment or a massage establishment to the county health department. If, in the 30 days immediately preceding submission of an application, such applicant was a known carrier of any notifiable communicable disease, as defined in F.A.C. ch. 10D-3, the health department shall notify the city; and no permit shall be issued unless the applicant presents a statement from a licensed physician certifying that the applicant is free of all notifiable communicable diseases. Any person applying for an adult entertainment permit shall be deemed to have consented to having the county health department notify the city if the applicant is a known carrier of a notifiable communicable disease and shall be deemed to have waived any right he may have to maintain the privacy or confidentiality of such information. 
(d)  At the time an applicant applies for a permit and completes all requirements for the issuance of a permit, he shall be issued a temporary permit valid for seven days. No later than seven days from the filing of an application and, if applicable, upon presentation of the statement of a licensed physician as required in subsection (c) above, the city shall issue a permit. 
(e)  It shall be the duty of the city to issue the applicant a written permit, which shall bear the name, all aliases, address, sex, age, signature and photograph of the applicant. The city shall procure the fingerprints and a photograph of the applicant and the name(s) of all entertainment establishments where the applicant is to work or perform and shall keep the same on permanent file in its office. The fingerprints, names of establishments, and photograph of the applicant shall be furnished by the applicant at the time of filing his application. The city may request an applicant to provide such additional information as is necessary to effect the purposes of this article. Upon delivery of the permit to the applicant, the applicant may begin working on the licensed premises as a permanent employee. There shall be submitted with each application for a permit proof of the applicant's age. Such proof may be provided by production of the applicant's driver's license, passport, or a certified copy of his birth certificate. If the applicant is unable to furnish any of such documents, a certificate from the public school authorities as to the age of the applicant upon entering school as required by F.S. § 232.03 or the school authorities of the state where applicant enrolled in school, shall be submitted. Upon inability of the applicant to establish a birth date as above provided, the date may be established in the order of preference as provided by F.S. § 232.03. However, uncertified copies of such documents shall not be accepted. Any applicant who does not possess a driver's license, passport or certified copy of his birth certificate may obtain a temporary permit upon completion of all other requirements for an application and submission of a written request to the appropriate authority in his state of birth that certified evidence of his date of birth be provided to the city. 
(f)  No permit shall be issued when its issuance would violate a statute, ordinance, law or when an order from a court of law prohibits the applicant from obtaining an adult entertainment permit in the city. 
(g)  Any adult entertainment establishment holding a valid adult entertainment license issued pursuant to this article shall be permitted to provide its employees with current permit application forms approved by the city and to take the photograph of the applicant in a manner and with equipment approved by the city on the express condition that the establishment: 
(1)  Requires the employee to complete the application form and be photographed within one working day of the time the employee begins to work or perform in the establishment; 
(2)  Mail a notice in writing to the city within one working day that the employee has begun to work or perform at the establishment; 
(3)  Make the employee available for fingerprinting at a time and location to be determined by the city, at which time and place the employee shall present to the city his completed application form and photograph; 
(4)  On the first Monday of every month provide the city with a current listing of all employees and their positions; 
(5)  In exchange for acceptance of the benefits provided by this subsection, waive any and all rights to challenge the permit requirements of this article; 
(6)  Reimburse the city for reasonable additional expenses incurred pursuant to this subsection; and 
(7)  Be liable for damages to the city of $250.00 per day per violation if any employee who performs in the establishment is not entitled to a permit. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(c)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-144. - Revocation. 
Should a permit be issued as a result of false information, misrepresentation of fact or mistake of fact, it shall be revoked. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(d)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-145. - Expiration and renewal. 
A permit under this article shall expire two years from the date of issuance. A permittee under this article shall be entitled to a renewal of his permit as a matter of course, except when the permit has been suspended or revoked, upon presentation of his previous permit or presentation of an affidavit as to its loss or destruction to the city and payment of a fee, on file in the city clerk's office, made payable to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(e)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-146. - Possession of permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for an employee to work, perform or to exhibit or display specified anatomical areas in an adult entertainment establishment without an adult entertainment permit in his immediate possession at all times. 
(b)  No person charged with violating this section shall be convicted if he produces to the city within 72 hours of detention or in court a permit issued to him. 
(c)  Upon receipt of a properly authenticated notification from the city verifying issuance of a valid permit, the clerk of the court is authorized to dismiss such cases at any time prior to the defendant's appearance in court. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(f)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-147. - Suspension. 
(a)  Procedure. Upon receiving notice that a jury or other trier of fact in a court of law has found that a permittee violated any provision of this article, whether or not an adjudication of guilt has been entered, the mayor shall suspend the permit and shall notify the permittee of his action. Notification shall be by certified mail and shall be sent to the address on the permit application, which shall be considered the correct address. 
(b)  Period of suspension. A single violation of this article shall result in the suspension of the adult entertainment permit for 30 days. Upon a second violation of this article within a period of two years from the date of a prior violation of this article, but not including any time during which the permit was suspended, the permit shall be suspended for 90 days. All periods of suspension shall begin on the 15th day from the date the city mails a notice of suspension to the permittee or on the date the permittee delivers his permit to the city, whichever comes first. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(h)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-148. - Appeal. 
If an application for permit under this division is denied or if a permit is suspended or revoked, the procedures specified in section 10-113 shall be available to the applicant or permittee, in the manner therein specified. If the applicant or permittee does not appeal the denial, suspension or revocation of a permit, the applicant or permittee shall be deemed to have failed to have exhausted his administrative remedies. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(i)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-149. - Replacement of lost permits. 
Replacements for lost permits shall be obtained by completing an application as required in section 10-143. All applications for replacement permits shall be accompanied by a fee on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(j)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-150. - Change of address, name or place of employment. 
Whenever any person, after applying for or receiving an adult entertainment permit, shall move from the residential address named in such application, or in the permit issued to him, or when the name of the permittee is changed by marriage or otherwise, or when the permittee takes on employment or begins to perform at an adult entertainment establishment not indicated in his application, such person shall within ten days thereafter notify the city in writing of his old and new address, or of such former and new names. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(k)), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-151. - Violations. 
Any person who violates the provisions of this division, or otherwise fails to secure a permit as required by this division, shall be prosecuted and punished in accordance with section 1-15. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-53(g)), 1-10-95)  
Secs. 10-152—10-175. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 10-176. - General requirements. 
In addition to the special requirements contained in sections 10-179 through 10-182, each licensed premises shall: 
(1)  Conform to all applicable building statutes, codes or ordinances, whether federal, state or local, specifically including the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(2)  Conform to all applicable fire statutes, codes or ordinances, whether federal, state or local. 
(3)  Conform to all applicable health statutes, codes or ordinances, whether federal, state or local. 
(4)  Have each glass area that faces a public thoroughfare or through which casual passersby can see the materials or activity inside the licensed premises covered over by black paint or other opaque covering; provided, that this requirement shall not apply if the uncovered glass area exposes to public view only a lobby or anteroom containing no material or activity other than a reception counter or desk and chairs or couches for customers to use while waiting. 
(5)  Conform to the requirements of F.S. Ch. 381 and the rules and regulations of the state department of health and rehabilitative services made pursuant thereto. Each licensed premises shall be deemed to be a place serving the public for the purposes of sanitary facilities. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-36), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-177. - Advertising. 
No adult bookstore, massage establishment, adult motion picture theater, adult dancing establishment or any other adult entertainment establishment shall: 
(1)  Display a sign advertising the presentation of any activity prohibited by a state statute, an ordinance of the county, or any applicable city ordinance. 
(2)  Display a sign capable of leading a reasonable person to believe that the establishment engages in an activity prohibited by a state statute, an ordinance of the county, or any applicable city ordinance. 
(3)  Erect, install, maintain, alter or operate any sign in violation of any applicable state, county or city law. 
(4)  Engage in, encourage or permit any form of personal advertising for the commercial benefit of the establishment or for the commercial benefit of any individual who displays or exhibits anatomical areas within the establishment. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-37), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-178. - Prohibited activities. 
(a)  No employee shall engage in specified sexual activities on the licensed premises in the presence of patrons or spectators or for any form of consideration. Notwithstanding any provisions of this article to the contrary, it shall not be unlawful for any person or employee of a commercial establishment or adult entertainment establishment to expose specified anatomical areas in connection with the use of approved sanitary facilities commonly known as restrooms. However, specified anatomical areas shall be exposed or displayed only in connection with excretory functions. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any employee, customer or patron of a licensed premises to participate in a straddle dance on the licensed premises. 
(c)  No employee, while on the licensed premises or within the scope of his employment, shall contract or agree to perform, for any form of consideration, a straddle dance and actually perform the straddle dance, regardless of where such performance takes place. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for a customer or patron of a licensed premises to touch with the hands an employee's breasts, pubic area or genitals, whether the employee is clothed or not. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for an employee of a licensed premises to touch with the hands a customer or patron's breasts, pubic area or genitals. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-38), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-179. - Adult bookstore. 
In addition to the general requirements contained in sections 10-176 through 10-178, an adult bookstore shall observe the following special requirements: 
(1)  All materials, devices and novelties shall be so displayed that they cannot be seen by anyone other than customers who have entered the licensed premises. 
(2)  If recordings are offered for sale and customers may listen to them while on the licensed premises, soundproof booths or rooms shall be available for use by customers who desire to listen, and each such booth or room shall have: 
a.  One clear window, facing the major portion of the licensed premises, covering not less than one-fourth of the wall area into which the window is set, which window shall not be covered or obscured in any manner while the booth or room is in use; 
b.  Sufficient chairs or couches to accommodate the expected number of persons who will occupy the booth or room at one time; 
c.  The number of persons who may occupy the booth or room at one time clearly stated on or near the door to the booth or room, and only that number of persons shall be permitted inside the booth or room at one time; 
d.  The door or doors opening into the booth or room incapable of being locked or otherwise fastened so that it or they will freely open from either side; and 
e.  All areas where a patron or customer is to be positioned visible from a continuous main aisle and not obscured by any curtain, door, wall or other enclosure. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-39), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-180. - Massage establishments. 
In addition to the general requirements contained in sections 10-176 through 10-178, a massage establishment shall observe the following special requirements: 
(1)  Any massage establishment seeking a license under this article shall present to the city a state license issued pursuant to F.S. ch. 480, at the time a license under this article is to be issued. No license under this article shall be issued if the applicant fails to present the state license. 
(2)  Dressing rooms shall be proportioned to the maximum number of persons who are expected to be in them at one time, excluding attendants and assistants; and separate dressing rooms shall be provided for men and women. Floors shall be of a smooth, impervious material with a nonslip surface and shall be covered at the wall junction for thorough cleaning. Partition walls shall terminate at least six inches above the floor or be placed on continuous raised masonry or concrete bases at least four inches high. 
(3)  One shower shall be provided for each 40 men or women, or fraction thereof, based upon the maximum number of persons who are expected to be using shower facilities at one time; and separate shower facilities shall be provided for men and women. Floors and partition walls shall be constructed as required in subsection (2) for dressing rooms, and duckboards or wooden gratings may be used on shower floors if duplicate sets are provided and rotated in use. 
(4)  One locker shall be provided for each patron who is expected to be on the licensed premises at one time, which shall be of sufficient size to hold clothing and other articles of wearing apparel. Each locker shall be capable of being locked by the patron, with no one else having the key so long as the patron is using the locker, or the locker shall be under the constant attention and supervision of an attendant. 
(5)  Massages of a person by another person who displays or exhibits specified anatomical areas are prohibited. 
(6)  No person shall massage the genitals or pubic area of another person. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-40), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-181. - Adult theaters. 
In addition to the general requirements contained in sections 10-176 through 10-178, an adult theater shall observe the following special requirements: 
(1)  If an adult theater contains a hall or auditorium area, the area shall have: 
a.  Individual separate seats, not couches, benches or the like, to accommodate the number of persons allowed to occupy the area; 
b.  A continuous main aisle alongside of the seating areas in order that each person seated in the areas shall be visible from the aisle at all times; 
c.  A sign posted in a conspicuous place at or near each entrance to the hall or auditorium area that lists the maximum number of persons who may occupy the hall or auditorium area, which number shall not exceed the number of seats within the hall or auditorium area; and 
d.  Sufficient illumination so that persons in all areas of the auditorium can be seen. 
(2)  If an adult theater contains adult booths, each adult booth shall have: 
a.  A sign posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance that states the maximum number of persons allowed to occupy the booth, which number shall correlate with the number of seats in the booth; 
b.  A permanently open entrance not less than 32 inches wide and not less than six feet high, which entrance shall not have any curtain rods, hinges, rails or the like which would allow the entrance to be closed or partially closed by any curtain, door or other partition; 
c.  Individual, separate seats, not couches, benches, or the like, which correlate with the maximum number of persons who may occupy the booth; 
d.  A well-illuminated continuous main aisle alongside the booth in order that each person situated in the booth shall be visible from the aisle at all times; 
e.  Except for the entrance, walls or partitions of solid construction without any holes or openings in such walls or partitions; 
f.  Illumination by a light bulb of no less than 25 watts. 
(3)  All areas where a patron or customer is to be positioned must be visible from a continuous main aisle and must not be obscured by any curtain, door, wall or other enclosure. 
(4)  In addition to the sanitary facilities required by section 10-176, there shall be provided within or adjacent to the common corridor, passageway, or area in adult motion picture theaters having adult motion picture booths, adequate lavatories equipped with running water, hand-cleansing soap or detergent, and sanitary towels or hand-drying devices; common towels are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-41), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-182. - Adult performance establishment. 
In addition to the general requirements contained in sections 10-176 through 10-178, an adult dancing establishment and lingerie modeling establishment shall observe the following requirements: 
(1)  Persons engaged in displaying or exposing specified anatomical areas are prohibited from simulating sexual activity with any patron, spectator, employee or other person on the premises. 
(2)  No person shall engage in the display or exhibition of specified anatomical areas except while the person is positioned in an entertainment area consisting of a platform or other structure raised 18 inches above the immediately surrounding area and encompassing an area of at least 100 square feet, and while the person is positioned at least three feet from a patron or spectator; except that any establishment regulated by section 10-183 shall require that person to be positioned in an entertainment area consisting of a platform or other structure raised 18 inches above the immediately surrounding area and encompassing an area of at least 100 square feet, or while the person is positioned at least three feet from a patron or spectator. 
(3)  No spectator or patron shall be present in the entertainment area defined in subsection (2) during the course of any performance involving the display or exhibition of specified anatomical areas. 
(4)  No person maintaining, owning or operating an adult entertainment establishment shall suffer or permit the construction, maintenance or use of areas partitioned or screened from public view that are designed to be occupied or are commonly occupied alone or together by any person or persons on the premises of such establishment for private performances involving the display or exhibition of specified anatomical areas. 
(5)  No person on the premises shall be permitted to use or to be present in areas partitioned or screened from public view that are designed to be occupied together or alone by any person or persons on the premises of such establishment for the display or exhibition of specified anatomical areas. 
(6)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit or authorize any acts or activities therein that are prohibited by state law. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-42), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-183. - Exhibit or display of certain anatomical areas by employees or patrons at alcoholic beverage establishments. 
It shall be unlawful for any employee of a commercial establishment, regardless of whether it is licensed under this article, where the employee knows or should have known that alcoholic beverages are on the premises, to exhibit or display the human genital or pubic region, the cleavage of the human buttocks, or the areola of the human female breast. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, § I(33-56), 1-10-95)  
Sec. 10-184. - Straddle dancing prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any employee or customer or patron of any commercial establishment in the city, whether or not the establishment is licensed under this article, to perform or participate in a straddle dance while on the premises of the commercial establishment. It shall also be unlawful for any employee, while on the premises or within the scope of his employment, to contract or agree to perform, for any consideration, a straddle dance and to actually perform such straddle dance, regardless of where such performance takes place. 
(b)  Employers of commercial establishments within the city are responsible for the acts of their employees. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person maintaining or operating any commercial establishment, regardless of whether it is licensed under this article, to knowingly, or with reason to know, permit, suffer or allow any employee on the premises to perform or participate in a straddle dance. 
(Ord. No. 4-94, §§ I(33-61), (33-62), 1-10-95)  
ARTICLE III. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGE ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 10-185. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions of terms shall prevail: 
(1)  The term "business establishment" shall include any place of business, such as a golf club, grocery store, drugstore, nightclub, hotel, cafe, bottle club, bar, restaurant, grill, filling station or location where: 
(a)  One person pays another for an article or product that is mixed with an alcoholic beverage, or an alcoholic beverage; or 
(b)  A drinking container, drink, water, beverage, or other product or article, for a consideration of any kind is sold, dispensed, served or provided, for the purpose of drinking an alcoholic beverage or with the knowledge, actual or implied, that the same will be, or intended to be, mixed, combined with, or drunk in connection or combination with an alcoholic beverage. Any place of business wherein an alcoholic beverage is carried, stored, dispensed, or consumed by the owner of the beverage or his guest, or stored or dispensed by the owner, operator or employee of such place, shall be deemed a business establishment defined in this paragraph, even if no consideration is paid directly for the dispensing, serving, or otherwise providing of such product or article, so long as the establishment charges any door fee, cover charge, entertainment fee, music fee, exhibition fee, membership fee, storage fee, or any indirect payment for admission to the premises. 
(2)  The term "alcoholic beverage" shall include distilled spirits and all beverages containing one-half of one percent or more alcohol by volume. The percentage of alcohol by volume shall be determined by measuring the volume of the standard ethyl alcohol in the beverage and comparing it with the volume of the remainder of the ingredients as though said remainder ingredients were distilled water. 
(Ord. No. 28-2003, § 1, 11-4-03)  
Sec. 10-186. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Any person, firm or corporation, or owner, lessor, partner, operator, manager, or employee of any business establishment as defined in this article violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed, upon conviction thereof, guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished therefore as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 28-2003, § 1, 11-4-03)  
Sec. 10-187. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to provide uniform regulation of all establishments and persons in the city dealing directly or indirectly with the sale, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages. It is the legislative intent that this article apply to all establishments and persons in any manner dealing with the sale, dispensing or consumption of alcoholic beverages, that the owners or operators of such establishments shall be notified hereby that they are not exempted from any zoning and land use prohibitions and regulations in force in the city where such establishments are located, that owners, operators, employees, patrons and others controlling, working in, or consuming alcohol on the premises of such establishments shall be notified hereby of the conduct and activities prohibited by this article, and the penalties for any violation thereof, and that this article be liberally construed as to effectuate this purpose. 
(Ord. No. 28-2003, § 1, 11-4-03)  
Sec. 10-188. - Prohibited hours for sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(a)  Alcoholic beverages sold for consumption on premises. 
1. 	All business establishments shall be prohibited from selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on premises from any day of the week except Sunday 	2:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. 
2. 	All business establishments shall be prohibited from selling alcoholic beverages for consumption on premises from on Sunday. 	2:00 a.m. to 11:00 a.m. 
 
(b)  Alcoholic beverages sold for consumption off premises: 
(1)  All business establishments shall be prohibited from selling alcoholic beverages in sealed containers for consumption off premises from 12:00 a.m. midnight to 8:00 a.m. any day of the week except Sunday. 
(2)  All business establishments shall be prohibited from selling alcoholic beverages in sealed containers for consumption off premises from 12:00 a.m. midnight Saturday to 11:00 a.m. Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 28-2003, § 1, 11-4-03) 
State Law reference— Local regulation of hours of sale of alcoholic beverages, F.S. § 562.14.  
Sec. 10-189. - Conduct prohibited; persons subject to article; presumptions, evidence and proof of violations. 
(a)  No patron or other person shall purchase, store on, or carry onto the premises of any business establishment, or consume therein, any alcoholic beverage at any time when such establishment is prohibited from the sale of alcoholic beverages under the terms of this article. For the purposes of this subsection, the payment of a charge of any kind for the admission to the premises or for other services or entertainment provided therein and the subsequent receipt of any alcoholic beverage, whether mixed or unmixed with any other substance, shall be deemed a purchase of an alcoholic beverage; and the presence of any alcoholic beverage container designated by symbol, device, label, or name as belonging to a particular person and the presence on the premises of such particular person shall be prima facie evidence that such person has consumed an alcoholic beverage, and it shall be the burden of any person charged under this subsection to prove that he or she did not consume any alcoholic beverage. 
(b)  No employee or other person shall assist, permit, or allow any other person to store on or carry onto the premises of any business establishment, or consume therein, any alcoholic beverage at any time when such establishment is prohibited from the sale of alcoholic beverages under the terms of this article. For the purposes of this subsection, the building owner, business establishment owner, operator, lessee, manager or other person who is licensed by the state or the city to operate a business establishment on the premises shall be deemed to have permitted any violation of this subsection for which an employee is charged; and it shall be the burden of any person thus deemed to have permitted such violation to provide that the violation was committed by an employee beyond the scope of his instruction and employment. 
(c)  No employee or other person shall sell, serve, dispense, or provide in any manner or guise any alcoholic beverage to any person on the premises of any such business establishment at any time when such business establishment is prohibited from the sale of alcoholic beverages under the terms of this article. For the purposes of this subsection, competent eyewitness testimony that any person was allowed to serve himself alcoholic beverages from any container stored on the premises of from any container carried onto the premises shall be conclusive proof that this prohibition has been violated by the person in the control of the premises at the time. 
(d)  No building owner or business establishment owner, operator, lessee, licensee, partner, or officer of any firm or corporation who is licensed by the state or the city to operate a business establishment on the premises shall assist, permit, direct, instruct or otherwise provide or allow any employee or other person to engage in any conduct prohibited by subsection (b) or (c) or any patron or other person to engage in any conduct prohibited by subsection (a). Competent testimony or documentary evidence that any employee was hired or paid for hours worked within the time such business establishment is prohibited from the sale of alcoholic beverages under the terms of this article and that such employee was present therein and working at such time, shall be conclusive proof that this subsection has been violated. 
(e)  In any prosecution for violation of any prohibition in this section, it shall not have to be proven that the alcoholic beverage, or mixture of alcoholic beverage and any other substance, that was alleged to have been purchased, sold, carried onto, stored, served, dispensed, or consumed in a business establishment, contained more than one-half of one percent alcohol by volume, nor must it be proven that such beverage or mixture of beverage was dispensed from any particular container of an alcoholic beverage, in order to obtain a conviction therefore; and the court and jury shall be bound by the legislative intent expressed in this article and the provisions of this section in the consideration of testimony, evidence, and burdens and other matters of proof in any case where such provisions are not in conflict with any court rule or decision or any statute. 
(Ord. No. 28-2003, § 1, 11-4-03)  
Chapter 14 - ELECTIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Qualifications and election of city councilmembers, art. VI. 
Cross reference— Any ordinance calling elections or prescribing the manner of conducting the election in accordance with state law saved from repeal, § 1-10(a)(16); administration, ch. 2; city council, § 2-31 et seq. 
State Law reference— Florida Elections Code, F.S. chs. 97—106. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - How arranged for. 
(a)  The city council shall authorize the city clerk to make all necessary arrangements for holding all municipal elections except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(b)  No informalities in conducting city elections shall invalidate the same if they have been conducted fairly and in substantial conformity to the requirements of this chapter and Florida state law. The election is to be conducted under ordinances of the City of Seminole and all sections of F.S. chs. 97—106. 
(Code 1991, § 23-112; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 1, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-2. - Polls; location; hours. 
(a)  The City of Seminole shall contract with the supervisor of elections to provide facilities and services for voting. 
(b)  Such polling place shall be open for such hours as may be fixed by law. If the designated polling place be destroyed, or otherwise rendered unfit to be used as a polling place prior to the day of the election, the supervisor of elections may, without further notice, transfer the polling place to a location most nearly available to the designated polling place. 
(Code 1991, § 23-111; Ord. No. 40-2003, § 1, 11-4-03; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 2, 10-28-14) 
State Law reference— Temporary change of polling place in case of emergency, F.S. § 101.74.  
Sec. 14-3. - Publication of notice of election. 
The city clerk shall cause to be published a notice of the election, which shall state the date, time and place where such election shall be held. This notice shall be published one time, not less than five days nor more than 20 days prior to the election. It shall be published in a newspaper circulated within the city. 
(Code 1991, § 23-106)  
Sec. 14-4. - Election officers. 
The city council shall authorize the city clerk to contract with the supervisor of elections to designate, assign, and train all poll workers. The supervisor of elections shall appoint the poll workers for each election. In cases in which a poll worker is absent or refuses to act, the supervisor of elections shall appoint a qualified elector to act in their place. Each poll worker of election shall be a qualified voter of the city, when possible. Each poll worker shall be sworn to perform the duties in accordance with Florida law and shall have full charge of the polling places and all voting machines. Poll workers shall be paid according to the schedule set by the supervisor of elections for such services. No person who holds any office of trust, profit, or employment under the city shall serve as a poll worker of the election. 
(Code 1991, § 23-107; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 3, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-5. - Ballots. 
The city council shall cause to be printed on the ballots the names of all persons who have qualified as candidates for any office. The ballots shall contain the names of all candidates for the same office printed together in alphabetical order. Each elector shall be entitled to one vote for each office to be filled in the election for councilperson and one vote for the office of mayor. 
(Code 1991, § 23-108)  
Sec. 14-6. - Canvass of returns. 
Pursuant to the election contract the county canvassing board shall certify the candidate who receives the highest number of votes cast for the office of mayor to be elected to such office and shall declare those persons equal in number to the positions to be filled who received the highest number of votes for the office of council to be elected to such office. The county canvassing board shall furnish an official certificate of election to the city. 
(Code 1991, § 23-109; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 4, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-7. - Date of election. 
Beginning 2014, the regular election of city council, including mayor, shall be held on the first Tuesday following the first Monday of November of each year. 
(Ord. No. 40-2003, § 2, 11-4-03; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 5, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-8. - Term of office. 
(a)  Due to the transition from March elections to November, the term of offices shall be as follows: Beginning March 2011, two councilmembers will be elected for a term that will expire November 2014; March 2012, two councilmembers will be elected for a term that will expire November 2015; and March 2013, the mayor and two councilmembers will be elected for a term that will expire November 2016. Elections shall be held in the manner provided by Article VI of the Charter. 
(b)  During the second business meeting in November, newly elected city councilmember(s) will subscribe to an oath of office and council shall elect a vice-mayor. 
(Ord. No. 40-2003, § 3, 11-4-03; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 6, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-9. - Time for qualifying. 
(a)  The qualifying period for candidates in the regular scheduled city election shall begin at 9:00 a.m. on the 98th day, preceding the scheduled regular election and the closing date for the qualifying period shall be 4:00 p.m. on the 85th day, preceding the scheduled regular election. 
(b)  The qualifying period for a special election shall be by resolution of the city council in accordance with the provisions of section 6.04 of the City Charter. 
(Ord. No. 40-2003, § 4, 11-4-03; Ord. No. 21-2014 , § 7, 10-28-14)  
Sec. 14-10. - Early voting. 
The provisions of the Florida Election Code pertaining to early voting shall not be applicable to any regular or special city election. Nothing in this section shall prevent the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections from implementing early voting procedures at any polling place within the city, provided that the supervisor of elections assumes full responsible for meeting all statutory and administrative requirements appertaining thereto. 
(Ord. No. 27-2004, 10-26-04)  
Secs. 14-11—14-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CANDIDATES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Qualifications for candidacy, § 3.01. 
State Law reference— Campaign financing, F.S. ch. 106. 
 
Sec. 14-41. - Application. 
Every person who shall desire to become a candidate for the office of mayor or councilmember shall qualify to become such candidate by filing, within the qualifying period set forth in section 14-9, with the city clerk during regular business hours at the city hall qualifying documents (application) under oath on forms provided by the city and obtained from the city clerk. 
(Code 1991, § 23-105(1), (2); Ord. No. 40-2003, § 5, 11-4-03)  
Sec. 14-42. - Qualifying fee or petition. 
The application filed under section 14-41 shall be accompanied by a qualifying fee in an amount on file in the city clerk's office for city councilmember or mayor. In lieu of such qualifying fee, the application may be accompanied by a qualifying fee in an amount on file in the city clerk's office for a candidate for city councilmember or mayor, together with petitions, which shall indicate prominently the position for which the person aspires, and shall be signed by and contain the residence address of not less than 40 of the qualified electors of the city in the exact manner as the signature of the qualified elector appears on the registration books of the supervisor of elections of the county. If the supervisor of elections shall determine that one or more signatures on such petition are not signatures of qualified electors, the decision of the supervisor of elections shall be presumed correct and the burden of presenting competent evidence to rebut such presumption shall be on the candidate. 
(Code 1991, § 23-105)  
Sec. 14-43. - Examination of application by city clerk. 
When an application is presented to the city clerk for filing under section 14-41, the city clerk shall immediately examine the application and the documents required to accompany the application and ascertain whether they conform to the provisions of this article. If found not to conform, the city clerk shall notify the applicant, in writing, why such application cannot be filed, and return it to the applicant. The application, together with the documents required to accompany the application, may be amended and again presented to the city clerk, who shall examine the amended application and its accompanying documents as hereinbefore provided. 
(Code 1991, § 23-105)  
ARTICLE III. - CANVASSING BOARD 
 
Sec. 14-44. - Canvassing board. 
The canvassing board for city elections shall be comprised of the city clerk, the city attorney and one member of the city council, who is not a candidate for election. The city council member shall not be a candidate for election and shall be appointed by a majority of the council to serve on the canvassing board for said election. 
(Ord. No. 23-2006, § 1, 1-9-07)  
Sec. 14-45. - Canvassing board meetings. 
Canvassing board meetings shall be scheduled in accordance with Florida law. The board shall meet for the purpose of canvassing and certifying the returns of the election except when the election is held in conjunction with an election conducted by Pinellas County or the city has contracted with the Pinellas County Supervisor of Elections and Pinellas County Canvassing Board to conduct the city election. In such cases the certification of the returns by the county canvassing board may be accepted as the certification of the municipal election return. 
(Ord. No. 23-2006, § 1, 1-9-07)  
Sec. 14-46. - Quorum. 
The presence of two members of the canvassing board shall be required to establish a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 23-2006, § 1, 1-9-07)  
Sec. 14-47. - Voting. 
An affirmative vote of at least two members shall be required for the approval of any matter that comes before the canvassing board, and said votes may be made by the signature of the board member where applicable and in accordance with Florida law. 
(Ord. No. 23-2006, § 1, 1-9-07)  
Chapter 18 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 6; parks and recreation, ch. 26; solid waste, ch. 34; streets, sidewalks and certain other public property, ch. 38; development standards, ch. 58; natural resources, ch. 62; environmentally sensitive lands, § 62-71 et seq.; zoning, ch. 70; zoning pollution regulations, § 70-936 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 18-1—18-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES 
 
Sec. 18-31. - Prohibited generally. 
It is hereby declared unlawful and a violation of this article for any person to do or permit to be done any of the following acts or practices: 
(1)  To throw, deposit on or bury in, or cause to be deposited on or buried in, any land, public place, street, alley, vacant or unoccupied lot, or in any waters lying within the city, any garbage or trash. This subsection shall not limit the use by an owner or tenant of property owned or leased by such person provided that such person does not use his land in such a manner as to create a nuisance due to the emission of obnoxious odors, due to the attraction of flies, insects or animals to such property, due to the penetration or drainage of waste from such premises into or onto the premises of another or into streams, lakes or other bodies of water, or due to the danger of fire. 
(2)  To allow any accumulation of trash, debris, refuse, filth, stagnant water, or other noxious matter, or other conditions or matter conducive of the breeding of mosquitoes, the breeding, concealing or harboring of snakes, dangerous reptiles or animals, insects, vermin, or anything dangerous to the public health or public safety, or matter, trash, or excessive vegetative growth likely to create a fire hazard. 
(3)  To place or allow to be placed upon any of the streets, alleys, curbings, sidewalks or other public places of the city any rubbish, sweepings, debris, bottles, cans, trash or waste materials of any kind that might adversely affect traffic, either vehicular or pedestrian, or that might endanger the health and safety of the public; however, this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage and trash in proper containers preparatory to having such material collected and disposed of. 
(Code 1991, §§ 25-102, 25-106, 25-109)  
Sec. 18-32. - Littering, prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful: 
(1)  For any person, in person or by his agent or employee, to cast, throw, sweep, sift or deposit in any manner in or upon any public way or public place in the city or any canal, public water, drain, sewer or receiving basin within the jurisdiction of the city, any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste article, thing or substance whatsoever, whether liquid or solid. 
(2)  For any person, in person or by his agent or employee to use any vehicle to haul any kind of dirt, rubbish, waste or any other material, whether liquid or solid, which is loaded in such a manner as to allow littering of any part on any street, alley or public way in the city. 
(Code 1991, § 25-108(1), (3)) 
State Law reference— Florida Litter Law, F.S. § 404.413.  
Sec. 18-33. - Grass, weeds. 
It is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and unlawful as being harmful and dangerous to the preservation of the public health and welfare for the owner of any lot, place or area within the city to permit on such lot, place or area grass or other unhealthful growth in excess of ten inches in height or upon any sidewalk abutting the same, any weeds, grass or other unhealthful growth or other noxious matter that may be growing, lying or located therein. 
(Code 1991, § 27-102; Ord. No. 3-2003, § 1, 1-28-03)  
Sec. 18-34. - Owner to abate noxious, offensive conditions. 
In order to prevent and/or to abate such nuisance or nuisances as described in this article and so as to improve the public health, public safety and general welfare of the people of the city, it shall be the affirmative duty and legal responsibility of all persons owning or occupying land to take such steps as are necessary and proper to keep down, cut, remove, drain or otherwise abate excessive growth of weeds or noxious plants or high vegetation, growth, stagnant water, garbage, trash, filth, debris or other similar conditions upon land that affords, encourages, aids or abets such hazard or breeding places or harbors mosquitoes, insects, snakes, venomous reptiles, dangerous animals, fire hazard or other public nuisance. 
(Code 1991, § 27-103)  
Sec. 18-35. - Abatement of condition by city action. 
Whenever the city manager or other person under his direction shall find that an excessive growth of weeds or any other nuisances has arisen, or is being perpetrated, created, permitted, tolerated, maintained or allowed to arise or exist upon any land within the city limits, such condition shall be abated immediately by the owner or persons having possession of the land, in the following manner: 
(1)  The city manager or his designee shall give notice of such violation to the person responsible for the correction thereof. Such notice shall: 
a.  Be in writing. 
b.  Include the description of the real estate sufficient for identification. 
c.  Specify the violation that exists and remedial action required. 
d.  Allow a period of ten days for corrective action to be taken. 
(2)  The notice provided for in subsection (1) above shall be served upon the owner or agent or occupant by delivery of a copy thereof to the owner or agent or occupant, or by forwarding a copy thereof to the owner or agent or occupant by registered or certified mail to his last known address, or by serving the owner or agent or occupant with such notice by any other method authorized under the laws of the state. If the service cannot be effected by one of the foregoing methods, the posting of a copy of such notice in a conspicuous place in or about the property or structure affected by the notice shall be deemed proper service of notice. 
(Code 1991, § 27-104)  
Sec. 18-36. - Action by city, liability of owner. 
(a)  Upon the failure of any owner, agent, custodian, lessee or occupant of any real property to maintain such property in conformance with the provisions of this article, the city manager is authorized to have cut such weeds, grass or underbrush and also to edge or trim all grass areas abutting streets and to remove any trash, debris, refuse, filth or other noxious matter and to assess the property owner actual cost for labor and equipment or $75.00, whichever is greater, for the work so done. 
(b)  The property owner will be assessed the cost so incurred and given 30 days to pay the assessment without interest. Thereafter, the amount so fixed, together with the maximum interest rate allowable by law and cost of collection, shall become a lien against the real property until paid. 
(c)  This lien shall be filed with the clerk of the circuit court in the county. 
(Code 1991, § 27-105)  
Sec. 18-37. - Conditions subject to special master code enforcement procedure. 
The existence of: excessive accumulations or untended growth of weeds, undergrowth or other dead or living plant life; overgrowth of lawn, grass or weeds; accumulation of stagnant water, rubbish, debris, construction material, construction debris, construction fill, or trash, including any wrecked, derelict or partially dismantled motor vehicle, trailer, boat, machinery, refrigerator, washing machine, plumbing fixture, furniture or similar article; all other objectionable, unsightly or unsanitary matter upon any property within this city to the extent and in the manner that such property is or may reasonably become infested or inhabited by rodents, vermin or wild animals, or may furnish a breeding place for mosquitoes, or threatens or endangers the public health, safety or welfare, or may reasonably cause disease, or adversely affects and impairs the economic welfare of adjacent property; is hereby prohibited and declared to be a public nuisance, unlawful, and subject to code enforcement through the special master procedure. 
(Ord. No. 07-2007, § 3, 8-14-07)  
Secs. 18-38—18-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - NOISE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
County code cross reference— Noise regulations, § 14-26 et seq. 
 
Sec. 18-66. - Keeping noisy, offensive animals. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within the city any animal, dog, cat, beast, fowl or bird that habitually utters, causes, emits or creates by any means noise or offensive odors, whether at night or during the day. 
(b)  It shall be further unlawful for any person to keep or harbor within the city any animal, dog, cat, beast, fowl or bird that unreasonably disturbs or annoys the residents who reside within 150 feet of the property on which the animal is kept or harbored. 
(Code 1991, § 27-121)  
Secs. 18-67—18-69. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - INOPERATIVE VEHICLES ON RESIDENTIAL AND PUBLIC PROPERTIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Lost and abandoned property, F.S. ch. 705. 
 
Sec. 18-70. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Motor vehicle means an automobile, motorcycle, truck, trailer, semitrailer, truck tractor and semitrailer combination, or any other vehicle operated on the roads of this state, used to transport persons or property, and propelled by power other than muscular power, but the term does not include traction engines, road rollers, such vehicles as run only upon a track, bicycles or mopeds. 
Inoperative vehicle means a motor vehicle that is in a state of disrepair and incapable of being moved under its own power, or a motor vehicle that is incapable of being lawfully operated on the streets of the state. A motor vehicle shall be deemed inoperative if one or more parts which are required for the operation of the vehicle are missing, are dismantled, are inoperative or are not attached to the vehicle as designed. A motor vehicle shall be presumed incapable of being lawfully operated on the streets of the state if a current registration tag, also known as a license plate, of a kind required under state law as a condition of operation upon the public streets, is not affixed thereto. 
Owner means the registered owner of the vehicle or the owner of the property upon which the inoperative vehicle is located. 
Property means any individual parcel of real property or any portion thereof. 
Public property means any federal, state, county or city-owned, leased, controlled, dedicated or platted real property including but not limited to parks, marinas, alleys, streets, rights-of-way or other real property. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 18-71. - Intent. 
It is hereby declared, that due to the urban nature and population density of the city, it is in the best interest of its citizens to prohibit the open storage of inoperative motor vehicles on residential property and public property located in the incorporated limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 18-72. - Penalty for violation of article. 
Violations of this article are punishable in accordance with the county court uniform fine schedule. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 18-73. - Territory embraced. 
This article shall apply to the incorporated limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 18-74. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person nor any business entity shall place, park or store, or allow to be placed, parked or stored, any inoperative motor vehicle(s) on any residentially zoned property located in the incorporated area of the city. 
(b)  No person nor any business entity shall place, park or store, or allow to be placed, parked or stored any inoperative motor vehicle(s) on any public property as defined in this article. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
Sec. 18-75. - Designation of investigating and enforcing authority. 
(a)  The code enforcement officer of the city and county deputy sheriffs are designated as the enforcing authority and are authorized to issue citations for violations of this section in accordance with the code of the city. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer and county deputy sheriffs are authorized to have removed from public property and impound any inoperative motor vehicle, which is in violation of this section, in accordance with the provisions of F.S. Ch. 705, as they pertain to lost or abandoned property. 
(Ord. No. 31-2000, 11-14-00)  
ARTICLE V. - SITE DEBRIS AND HURRICANE PROTECTION 
 
Sec. 18-76. - Site debris. 
(a)  The permit holder of any active or inactive construction project shall clean up and remove all construction debris or any other miscellaneous discarded articles prior to receiving final inspection approval or a certificate of occupancy, whichever is applicable. Construction job sites shall be kept clean, such that accumulation of construction debris must not remain on the property for a period of time exceeding ten days from a notice of violation. 
(b)  All debris shall be contained in such a manner as to prevent it from being spread on the property or onto adjacent property by any means. 
(Ord. No. 21-2005, § 1, 8-23-05)  
Sec. 18-77. - Hurricane protection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful and constitute a nuisance for any person or entity to allow construction related materials (including but not limited to: roof tiles, lumber, scaffolding and debris) to remain loose or otherwise unsecured at a construction site from 12 hours after a hurricane watch has been issued by the National Weather Service for Pinellas County until the hurricane watch has been lifted. All such materials shall be either removed from the construction site or secured in such a manner so as to minimize the danger of such materials causing damage to persons or property from high winds. 
(b)  Any property owner and/or contractor that violates this section shall be subject to an immediate fine of $500.00 per day from the date and time of a notice of violation through the conclusion of the weather emergency, as may be determined by a special master; and 
(c)  The city reserves the right to assess costs for remediation of the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 21-2005, § 1, 8-23-05)  
ARTICLE VI. - PORTABLE STORAGE BUILDINGS 
 
Sec. 18-78. - Intent. 
A portable storage unit structure may be utilized as a temporary structure within the city when in compliance with the standards of this article. Any use of such structures within the city not in compliance with this article shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-79. - Definition. 
The term "portable storage unit" shall be defined to be any container, storage unit, shedlike container or other portable structure than can or is used for the storage of personal property of any kind and which is located for such purposes outside an enclosed building other than an accessory building or shed complying with all building codes and land use requirements. It is the general intent of this definition to recognize portable storage units as temporary uses of property which are intended to be used for the loading and unloading of personal property, or to be used for the off-site storage of personal property. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-80. - Location and placement. 
Location and placement standards for portable storage units are as follows: 
(1)  General. Portable storage units shall not create a hazardous condition and shall not block visibility for intersections of streets, alleys, driveways or sidewalks. 
(2)  Residential. Portable storage units placed on residential land shall be located in the driveway or on a hard surface and shall not be placed in a public or private right-of-way. 
(3)  Commercial. Portable storage units placed on nonresidential land shall not reduce required on-site parking, obstruct traffic circulation aisles, encroach into drainage areas or landscaping buffers, or placed in a public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-81. - Duration, frequency and extensions. 
(a)  Duration. Portable storage units shall not exceed the following durations of stay: 
(1)  Residential use (single-family, duplex, triplex). A maximum of ten calendar days per event with a maximum of four events per dwelling unit address per calendar year. 
(2)  Multi-family residential use (apartment, condominium, townhome). A maximum of ten calendar days per event with a maximum of four events per dwelling unit address per calendar year. 
(3)  Nonresidential use. A maximum of ten calendar days per event with a maximum of four events per each nonresidential unit/tenant on a property per calendar year. 
(b)  Frequency. An "event" shall consist of the delivery and pickup of the unit. At least 30 calendar days shall pass between the removal and subsequent placement of portable storage units "event." For construction sites involving new construction, the time limit for portable storage containers related to and used for the ongoing construction shall be restricted to the period of continuous construction under a valid building permit as defined in the Code. Any portable storage container at the site of construction, and not specifically related to and used for construction, shall be subject to this article in its entirety. 
(c)  Portable storage units will be permitted as long as an active building permit is in place. At such time the building permit expires, a final inspection has taken place, or a certificate of occupancy or completion has been issued, the unit must be removed. 
(d)  In the event of fire, hurricane or natural disaster causing substantial damage to the principal structure on the property; or, In those cases where a property owner undertakes improvements or repairs that do not require a building permit, the property owner shall be entitled to site a portable storage unit on their property, subject to all other applicable sections of this chapter, for 60 days. Before the expiration of the 60-day period, the property owner may apply to the city for permission to extend the time that a portable on demand storage structure may be located as a temporary structure on the property. Application for such extended duration shall be made in writing and filed with the general services department and shall give sufficient information to determine whether such extended duration should be granted. The general services director, or his designee, shall determine whether or not to grant such extended duration and the length of such extension. In the event of an adverse decision by the general services department, the applicant may appeal such decision to the city manager. In the event of such appeal, the decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-82. - Number and size. 
(1)  Number. No more than one portable storage unit may be located for any residential address. 
(2)  Size. No portable storage unit shall be allowed which exceeds more than 1,300 cubic feet of storage. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-83. - Signage and compliance. 
(a)  Signage. All portable storage units shall have the name, current phone number, and address of the company providing the unit. Additionally, the volume of storage expressed in cubic feet and the date the unit was placed at the site shall be clearly posted on the exterior of the portable storage unit. No other signage shall be allowed on a portable storage unit. Allowed signage shall not exceed 33 percent of the area of the side of the portable storage unit containing the signage and no more than two sides of any portable storage unit shall contain signage. 
(b)  Compliance. Failure by the business, during container placement, to post portable storage containers with the required information shall be considered a violation of this section and subject to the penalties outlined in section 18-85. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-84. - Security. 
Portable storage units shall be locked and secured by the owner or tenant of the unit or property at all times when loading or unloading is not taking place. Storage of hazardous material is prohibited. It shall be the obligation of the owner or user of such temporary structure to secure it in a manner that does not endanger the safety of persons or property in the vicinity of the temporary structure. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-85. - Permits and exemptions. 
(a)  Permit. A permit is required to site a portable storage unit. However, no permit fee shall be required for any portable storage unit regardless of category. 
(b)  Exemptions. No permit shall be needed to allow for the siting of a portable storage facility used for deliveries or pickups which is placed on land for less than 48 hours. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Sec. 18-86. - Removal and enforcement. 
In the event of a natural disaster as declared by the city, the requirements of this article may be waived for a specific period of time as deemed necessary by the city manager, or his designee, in order to meet the needs of the community. 
(a)  Removal. It shall be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person or entity to allow for a portable storage unit to remain unsecured from 12 hours after a hurricane watch has been issued by the National Weather Service for Pinellas County until the hurricane watch has been lifted. All portable storage units shall either be removed or secured in such a manner so as to minimize the danger of such portable storage unit causing damage to persons or property from high winds. 
(b)  Enforcement. Any property owner that violates this section shall be subject to an immediate fine of $500.00 from the date and time of notice of violation through the conclusion of the weather emergency, as may be determined by a special master. The city reserves the right to assess costs for the remediation of the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 32-2005, § 1, 10-11-05)  
Secs. 18-87—18-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - PRIVATE DOCKS ON CITY-OWNED WATER BODIES 
 
Sec. 18-100. - Standards, procedures, required permits, indemnity and hold harmless agreement, inspection agreement, and required maintenance. 
(a)  Intent. It is the intent of the city that no private dock shall be installed on any city-owned water body that abuts a private residential use until such time as said request meets the requirements and provisions of this section. 
(b)  Administrative approval. The proposed private dock must conform to the following standards: 
(1)  Only one dock shall be allowed per lot or parcel of private property; 
(2)  No dock shall exceed 192 square feet in size or 16 feet in length; 
(3)  The placement of the dock shall meet the required side yard setbacks for the zoning district in which the lot or parcel is located; 
(4)  An indemnity and hold harmless agreement and an inspection agreement provided by the city to the applicant shall be executed by the property owner prior to the issuance of a building permit for the installation of the dock; 
(5)  All docks shall be maintained in a safe and functional condition, as may be determined by the building official; 
(6)  An approved building permit is required prior to installation of any dock. 
(c)  Procedures. The city manager is authorized to create administrative procedures to implement the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 25-2007, § 1, 11-27-07)  
Secs. 18-101—18-109. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - CANINES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Cruelty to animals, F.S. ch. 828. 
 
Sec. 18-110. - Supervision, confinement and tethering of canines. 
(a)  As used in this section, tether means to restrain a canine by typing the canine to any object or structure, including without limitation a house, tree, fence, post, garage, or shed, by any means, including without limitation a chain, rope, cord, leash, or running line. Tethering shall not include using a leash to walk a canine. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for a responsible party to tether a canine while outdoors, except when all of the following conditions are met: 
(1)  The canine is in visual range of the responsible party, and the responsible party is located outside with the canine. 
(2)  The tether is connected to the canine by a buckle-type collar or a body harness made of nylon or leather, not less than one inch in width. 
(3)  The tether has the following properties: it is at least five times the length of the canine's body, as measured from the tip of the nose to the base of the tail; it terminates at both ends with a swivel; it does not weigh more than 1/8 of the canine's weight; and it is free of tangles. 
(4)  The canine is tethered in such a manner as to prevent injury, strangulation, or entanglement. 
(5)  The canine is not outside during a period of extreme weather, including without limitation extreme heat or near-freezing temperatures, thunderstorms, tornadoes, tropical storms, or hurricanes. 
(6)  The canine has access to water, shelter, and dry ground. 
(7)  The canine is at least six months of age. Puppies shall not be tethered. 
(8)  The canine is not sick or injured. 
(9)  Pulley, running line, or trolley systems are at least 15 feet in length and are less than seven feet above the ground. 
(10)  If there are multiple canines, each canine is tethered separately. 
(c)  This section shall not apply to the transportation of canines. 
(d)  For a first-time violation, the code enforcement officer shall issue a warning notice to the responsible party and shall wait at least ten days before taking any further enforcement action against the responsible party. Thereafter, each violation of this section shall be subject to enforcement in accordance with section 18-111 of this chapter or Chapter 2, Article V., Division 4 of the City Code. For all civil penalties for violations of this section collected pursuant to section 18-110, 50 percent of the amount collected shall be paid to Pinellas County Animal Services. 
(Ord. No. 39-2009, § 1, 12-22-09)  
Sec. 18-111. - Schedule of penalties. 
First offense —Unlawful tethering of canine - Warning with ten-day correction period. 
Second offense —Unlawful tethering of canine - $100.00 and additional ten-day correction period. 
Third offense —Unlawful tethering of canine - $250.00. 
Fourth and each subsequent offense —Unlawful tethering of a canine - $500.00 and one count of animal cruelty ($500.00 fine and/or imprisonment for up to 60 days). 
(Ord. No. 39-2009, § 2, 12-22-09)  
Secs. 18-112—18-174. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 18-175. - Title of article, applicability and interpretation. 
This article shall be known as and may be cited as the stormwater management and stormwater system illicit discharge and connection ordinance of the city. The provisions of this article shall be effective within the boundaries of the city and shall set prohibitions and restrictions to prevent illicit and illegal discharges from entering or being deposited into the city's stormwater collection system. This article shall be liberally construed to affect the purposes set forth in this article. 
( Ord. No. 08-2014 , § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-176. - Policy, intent, purpose and objectives.
