(b)  The city's laws and policies governing the development of land in effect at the time of execution of a development agreement, including, but not limited to, all other ordinances comprising land development code under F.S. § 163.3202, as amended, shall govern the development of all land specified in the development agreement for its stated duration. 
(c)  The city may only apply subsequently adopted laws and policies to then existing development agreements if, after a duly noticed public hearing the city council: 
(1)  Determines that such laws and policies are specifically anticipated and provided for in a development agreement; 
(2)  Determines that such laws and policies are not in conflict with the prior laws and policies governing existing development agreements; and do not prevent development of the land uses, intensities, or densities set forth in existing development agreements; 
(3)  Determines that such laws and policies are essential to the public health, safety or welfare, and expressly state that they shall apply to existing development agreements; 
(4)  Determines and demonstrates that substantial changes have occurred in pertinent conditions existing at the time of approval of existing development agreements; or 
(5)  Determines that certain development agreements were based upon substantially inaccurate information supplied by the owner/developer. 
(d)  The provisions set forth in subsections (b) and (c) of this section do not abrogate any development rights that may vest pursuant to common law. 
( Ord. No. 07-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 163.3233.  
Sec. 50-310. - Enforcement. 
The following may file an action for injunctive relief in the circuit court of the county to enforce the terms of a development agreement, or to challenge compliance of the agreement with the provisions of F.S. §§ 163.3220—163.3243: 
(1)  Any aggrieved or adversely affected person as defined in F.S. § 163.3215(2); 
(2)  Any party; or 
(3)  The state land planning agency. 
( Ord. No. 07-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
ARTICLE VIII. - AFFORDABLE HOUSING 
 
Sec. 50-311. - Permitting procedure for the construction of affordable housing. 
(a)  Purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of this section is to provide a permitting procedure for the construction of affordable housing in keeping with the applicable provisions of the most recent housing incentive plan adopted by the board of county commissioners pursuant to the state housing initiatives partnership (SHIP) program pursuant to state law, as amended. This section will describe procedures and criteria for the certification of affordable housing developments (AHDs), describe the package of incentives which may be made available to developers of AHDs and provide a review process for the approval of AHDs. This section may also provide reference to other city or county ordinances and regulations effecting the development of AHD's. 
(b)  Definition. Affordable housing development is defined as owner-occupied housing development in which a designated portion of the units are affordable to households at or below 80 percent of area median income ("AMI") or rental housing development in a designated portion of the units are affordable to households at or below 60 percent of AMI. Income limits are updated periodically and are available from the Pinellas County Community Development Department upon request. 
(c)  Incentives. The following incentives may be made available to encourage the provision of affordable housing: 
(1)  Expedited permit processing. The city manager, or his designee, shall provide a review process that gives AHDs priority in the permit review process. A two-week turnaround time shall be the desired goal for the processing of a site plan for such development. To assist in achieving this goal a pre-application meeting will be required between the applicant and city staff. The general services director will serve as an ombudsman to assist the applicant in achieving an expeditious review. 
(2)  Impact and other review fees may be waived. The city manager is authorized, at his sole discretion, to waive all fees for affordable housing units, except where "bond covenants" (i.e. on water, sewer connection fees) or other legal constraints prevent such waiving. Subsidies for payment of fees may be provided in the form of deferred payment. The general services department shall administer any program to assist the applicant in this regard. 
(3)  Density bonus. A density bonus of up to 33 percent above the normal density permitted under the comprehensive plan or zoning district, whichever is greater, may be provided as part of an approved development agreement pursuant to chapter 50, article VII of this chapter. 
(4)  Public funding sources. Using state or federal housing funds, the county housing finance authority may also make deferred payment or low interest loans to both nonprofits and for-profits for the purchase of property when the use meets the requirements of the funding source for affordable housing developments to be located within the city. 
(5)  Identifying qualified buyers or renters. Existing sources will be identified and made available to AHDs to provide assistance in locating a qualified pool of homebuyers and renters for the affordable units. The Pinellas County Department of Community Development shall be the source for this information and the city shall coordinate with Pinellas County in this regard. 
(d)  Any proposed affordable housing development that proposes a density bonus for a property shall require a development agreement, which development agreement shall include and address the enumerated countywide rules criteria regulating affordable housing density bonuses. A development agreement for an affordable housing density bonus shall have the status of, and serve as, a land development regulation governing said property. 
( Ord. No. 07-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Chapter 54 - CONCURRENCY MANAGEMENT AND MULTI-MODAL IMPACT FEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

A), adopted Feb. 24, 2015, amended Ch. 54 in its entirety to read as herein set out. the former Ch. 54 pertained to concurrency management and proportionate fair share program, and derived from Ord. No. 22-2006, 1-9-07; and Ord. No. 14-2009, 7-14-09. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis. 
Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; development standards, ch. 58; zoning, ch. 70. 
State Law reference— Concurrency, F.S. § 163.3180. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 54-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Acceptance of, or accepted, application for development means that an application for development contains sufficient information, pursuant to existing regulations, to allow continuing review under this chapter or other regulatory ordinances. 
Application for development means any documentation which contains a specific plan for development, including the densities and intensities of development, where applicable, that is presented by any person for the purpose of obtaining a development order or development permit. 
Approved final site plan means any site development plan that has been reviewed and approved by the city as to the site plan's compliance with all currently applicable rules, regulations, and ordinances of the city. 
Certificate of concurrency means that document issued by the city manager or his designee that is a prerequisite for the issuance of any development order or development permit, except that certificates of concurrency for re-zonings shall only be issued such that further development in the rezoned parcel is conditioned upon the availability of sufficient capacity of those public facilities and services required for any project which may be subsequently proposed for that rezoned parcel, or any portion thereof. At a minimum, the certificate of concurrency shall provide information on the following: 
(1)  Type of proposal; 
(2)  Effective date of the concurrency test statement utilized in the comparison; 
(3)  Date of issuance of the certificate of concurrency; 
(4)  Status of each public facility and service after comparison with the current concurrency test statement; and 
(5)  Whether or not the development proposal is subject to development limitations, pursuant to application of the transportation management plan for properties located in service protection, constrained or deferral areas and any other limitations that may be identified in an adopted concurrency test statement. 
Concurrency means that the necessary public facilities and services to maintain the adopted level of service standards are available when the impacts of development occur. 
Concurrency management corridor means road corridors designated in this division as constrained, congestion containment, or long-term concurrency management. 
Concurrency management monitoring system means the data collection, processing and analysis performed by the county to determine levels of service for public facilities and services. Data maintained by the concurrency management monitoring system shall be the most current information available to the city. 
Concurrency management system means the procedure and process that the city utilizes to ensure that development orders and permits issued by the city shall not result in an unacceptable degradation of the adopted level of service adopted in the city comprehensive plan. 
Concurrency test statement means a public facility and service status report, approved and adopted by ordinance, which, at a minimum, establishes for each public facility and service the following: 
(1)  The existing and committed development in each service area; 
(2)  The existing levels of service for each public facility and service; 
(3)  Updates of items (1) and (2), above, based upon the most recently adopted schedule of capital improvements from a capital improvements element; and 
(4)  The methods used in determining the nature of projected development impacts on public facilities and services. 
Constrained roadway means a city or county roadway, regardless of transportation needs, which is constrained from adding additional capacity. A roadway may be physically constrained or policy constrained. Physical barriers occur when intensive land use development is immediately adjacent to highways making roadway expansion cost prohibitive, or when a facility has reached the maximum through-lane standards. Policy barriers are based on concerns about the impacts of roadway expansion on the environment, neighborhoods and/or local communities. Constrained facilities may be more specifically defined through subsequent amendments to this division or a concurrency test statement. 
Deficient road corridors include parcels, all or a portion of which lie within a corridor as defined below. 
(1)  Sole direct access. A condition where the only means of site ingress/egress is directly onto the road facility, regardless of the distance of that site from the facility; 
(2)  Direct access. A condition in which one or more existing or potential site ingress/egress points makes a direct connection to the road facility and the site is within one-half mile of the road facility; and 
(3)  Sole indirect access. A condition where the only point of site ingress/egress is onto a public non-arterial roadway which makes its first and shortest arterial level connection onto a road facility regardless of the distance of that site from the facility. 
Currently available revenue sources means an existing source and amount of revenue available to the city or county, as is applicable. 
Development or development activity/site means the addition to, or improvement of, property, including but not limited to the following activities: 
(1)  A change in the intensity of use of land, such as an increase in the number of dwelling units in a structure or on land or a material increase in the number of businesses, manufacturing establishments, offices, or dwelling units in a structure or on land. 
(2)  Building or installing a new building/structure. 
(3)  Enlarging, replacing or substantially restoring a building/structure. 
(4)  Subdividing land into three or more parcels. 
Development order means any order granting, denying, or granting with conditions, an application for development. 
Development permit means any approved final site plan, building permit, zoning clearance, rezoning, special exception, variance, conditional use, or any other official action of the city having the effect of permitting the development of land. 
Final local development order means, for the purposes of this section, that last approval necessary to carry out the development requested. 
Level of service (LOS) means a measure of performance and/or of demand versus available capacity of public services and facilities. Regarding roadways, LOS is based primarily on travel speeds on a scale of A through F. Roads operating at LOS A are at optimum efficiency with the lower grade roads reflecting travel conditions that are progressively worse. For the purposes of this division and the city concurrency management system, LOS reported for roadways is based on peak hour conditions. Level of service E and F roads and/or roads with a volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio of 0.9 or more are operating below the adopted level of service standard established in the city or county comprehensive plan and the concurrency test statement, as is applicable. 
Level of service "A" represents free flow. Individual users are virtually unaffected by the presence of others in the traffic stream. Freedom to select desired speeds and to maneuver within the traffic stream is extremely high. The general level of comfort and convenience provided to the motorist, passenger, or pedestrian is excellent. 
Level of service "B" is in the range of stable flow, but the presence of other users in the traffic stream begins to be noticeable. Freedom to select desired speeds is relatively unaffected, but there is a slight decline in the freedom to maneuver within the traffic stream from LOS A. The level of comfort and convenience provided is somewhat less than at LOS A, because the presence of others in the traffic stream begins to affect individual behavior. 
Level of service "C" is in the range of stable flow, but marks the beginning of the range of flow in which operation of individual users becomes significantly affected by interactions with others in the traffic stream. The selection of speed is now affected by the presence of others, and maneuvering within the traffic stream requires substantial vigilance on the part of the user. The general level of comfort and convenience declines noticeably at this level. 
Level of service "D" represents high-density, but stable, flow. Speed and freedom to maneuver are severely restricted, and the driver or pedestrian experiences a generally poor level of comfort and convenience. Small increases in traffic flow will generally cause operational problems at this level. 
Level of service "E" represents operating conditions at or near the capacity level. All speeds are reduced to a low, but relatively uniform value. Freedom to maneuver within the traffic stream is extremely difficult, and it is generally accomplished by forcing a vehicle or pedestrian to "give way" to accommodate such maneuvers. Comfort and convenience levels are extremely poor, and driver or pedestrian frustration is generally high. Operations at this level are usually unstable, because even small increases in flow or minor perturbations within the traffic stream will cause breakdowns. 
Level of service "F" is used to define forced or breakdown flow. This condition exists wherever the amount of traffic approaching a point exceeds the amount which can traverse it and queues begin to form. Operations within the queue are characterized by stopping and starting. Over and over, vehicles progress at reasonable speeds for several hundred feet or more, then are required to stop. Level of service F is used to describe operating conditions within the queue, as well as the point of the breakdown. It should be noted, however, that in many cases once free of the queue, traffic may resume to normal conditions quite rapidly. 
Multi-modal impact fee districts means areas identified by Pinellas County from which impact fee monies are collected and expended. 
Pinellas County Mobility Management System means the county's process of implementing the Pinellas County Mobility Plan through the management of transportation impacts of development projects on county facilities through the assessment, collection and expenditure of multi-modal impact fees. 
Public facilities and services means those necessary public facilities and services covered by a comprehensive plan element for which level of service standards have been adopted by the county. The necessary public facilities and services are: roads, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, potable water, recreation, and mass transit. 
Transportation deficient facility means a facility or facilities operating at level of service E and F and/or a volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio of 0.9 or higher. 
Transportation management plan, as developed by an applicant representing a proposed development, is submitted in conjunction with individual future land use map (FLUM) amendments, zoning map amendments, and/or site plans seeking to utilize transportation management strategies to mitigate development impacts, protect roadway capacity and to increase mobility. These strategies include, but are not limited to, density/intensity reductions, project phasing, access controls, capital improvements and/or incentives encouraging mass transit, bicycle or pedestrian travel, ride-sharing or roadway improvements. 
Volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio means the rate of traffic flow of an intersection approach or group of lanes during a specific time interval divided by the capacity of the approach or group of lanes. Volume-to-capacity ratios provide a measure of traffic congestion and are utilized in the concurrency management system to identify congested road segments and to minimize the transportation impacts of development projects that affect them. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-2. - Authority; adoption of legislative findings. 
(a)  This chapter is adopted in compliance with, and pursuant to, the Community Planning Act, F.S. § 163.3184 et seq. 
The legislative findings are as follows: 
(1)  The city council has adopted the City of Seminole Comprehensive Plan, which establishes goals, objectives and policies related to establishing levels of service for public facilities, such as water, sewer, parks, transportation, and solid waste as a basis for evaluating and minimizing the impacts of development on such services through the application of a concurrency management system; 
(2)  The county has adopted comprehensive plans, including the Pinellas Mobility Plan that provide data, analysis, and policies supporting the intent to minimize the impacts of development on county and state facilities operating with deficient level of service conditions through the application of a concurrency management system; 
(3)  The county has adopted the Pinellas County Multi-Modal Impact Fee, which establishes transportation impacts fees related to development and identifies a number of highway and roadway system facilities operating under deficient level of service conditions; county and state roads operating with deficient level of service conditions that are not scheduled for a mitigating improvement and identifies mitigation measures; 
(4)  F.S. § 163.3180 provides for local governments to establish a concurrency management option, which identifies policies, guidelines and techniques for implementing a concurrency management process, including guidelines for implementing a proportionate fair share process for transportation improvements. 
(5)  Transportation management plan strategies are important components of concurrency management for purposes of minimizing development impacts and maximizing mobility and accessibility consistent with the city's and county's comprehensive plans; 
(6)  F.S. § 163.3180 also states: "Consistent with public health and safety, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, adequate water supplies, and potable water facilities shall be in place and available to serve new development no later than the issuance by the local government of a certificate of occupancy or its functional equivalent." 
(7)  F.S. § 163.3180 encourages local governments to apply concurrency management provisions in a coordinated and cooperative manner. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-3. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  It is the purpose of this chapter, in conjunction with other land development regulations and the city's comprehensive plan, including the capital improvement element, and in coordination with the county, to establish a concurrency management system to ensure that public facilities and services needed to support development are available concurrent with the impacts of such development. Prior to the issuance of a development order and/or development permit, this concurrency management system shall ensure that the adopted level of service standards required for roadways, potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste, drainage, recreation, and mass transit shall be maintained. 
(b)  The concurrency management system is intended to serve the long-term interests of the citizens of the city by implementing a managed growth perspective that preserves the capacity of important infrastructure facilities and services. 
(c)  The concurrency management system is intended to serve the long-term interests of the county by implementing a managed growth perspective that preserves the capacity of important county infrastructure facilities and services, and to implement the county's multi-modal impact fee. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Secs. 54-4—54-9. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION 
 
Sec. 54-10. - Concurrency management system; procedure. 
(a)  Application for development. The concurrency management system is accessed by the property owner, or designated representative, when an application for development containing the required documentation for the given development order or permit is submitted to the city. A city representative shall then ascertain the completeness of the documentation, in a timely manner, to ensure that the required information is sufficient to accept the application for development for review. The burden of showing compliance with the adopted levels of service and meeting the concurrency evaluation shall be upon the applicant. The city manager or designee will direct the applicant to the appropriate staff to assist in the preparation of the necessary documentation and information. 
(b)  Review of application for development. 
(1)  When the application for a development order or permit has been accepted, it shall be processed and reviewed in accordance with adopted administrative procedures. These procedures shall include a review of the application for development for the public facilities and services identified in this chapter, as they may apply. Further, the city shall have the authority to require the applicant/developer to provide a public facilities concurrency analysis, as determined to be sufficient by the city, so that the city can determine the proposed development's impact on the existing and adopted LOS for the affected public facilities, including roadways that will serve the proposed development. At the option of the city, the city may retain a consultant to conduct an independent public facilities concurrency analysis, which shall be paid for by the applicant. 
(2)  If the application for development is not acceptable as submitted, then the application for development shall be returned to the property owner or representative clearly stating what the deficiencies are and why the application for development cannot be further reviewed. 
(c)  Concurrency review shall recognize the levels of service established by the county comprehensive plan, as applicable to the service or facility provided. The city shall recognize and adopt by reference those adopted levels of service, as defined in the county's comprehensive plan, including but not limited to drainage, recreation and open space, solid waste, water supply, sanitary sewer, traffic circulation and mass transit. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-11. - Concurrency test statement and monitoring system. 
(a)  The community development department shall establish and maintain a concurrency management monitoring system for the purposes of monitoring the status of county public facilities and services within the city, and city public facilities and services. On an annual basis, the community development department shall provide a status report on said concurrency test statement, and as appropriate, recommend the adoption of any proposed amendments to the existing city concurrency test statement, to the city manager. The city manager shall convey such proposed statement or amendment, along with the local planning agency recommendation, to the city council for final adoption. 
(b)  The remaining capacity reported for each public facility and service provided by the city on the city's annual concurrency test statement should be determined by calculating the existing demand as well as the committed impacts, including those associated with multi-year, phased development proposals or projects (including developments of regional impact, development agreements, etc.). These calculations are based upon data accumulated in the concurrency monitoring system, data supplied by other city departments, as well as a reasonable projection for the progress of each proposal or project, population growth projections, or such other considerations as good planning practices would deem appropriate. 
(c)  After city council adoption, a concurrency test statement shall be issued every year. Nothing in this chapter precludes the issuance and effectiveness of amendments to the current concurrency test statement if updating or correction is deemed necessary by the city council for, including, but not limited to, the following circumstances: errors in preparation and adoption are noted; the impact of issued development orders or permits, as monitored by the community development department, indicate an unacceptable degradation to the adopted level of service; or where changes in the status of capital improvement projects, of the state or any local government, change the underlying assumptions of the current concurrency test statement. 
(d)  Under no circumstances will an amended concurrency test statement divest those rights acquired under an approved development agreement or development order under the concurrency test statement as it existed prior to amendment, except where a divestiture of such rights is clearly established by the city council to be essential to the health, safety or welfare of the general public. In no case shall private property be taken for public use without the payment of just compensation. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-12. - Appeals and variances. 
(a)  Review of an administrative decision or concurrency variance. Any applicant who has been aggrieved by an administrative decision in the application or interpretation of the provisions of this chapter as applied to a site plan review application for development may apply for a review of that administrative decision or seek a concurrency variance to the developmental review board. 
(b)  Review hearing procedure and criteria. 
(1)  Any applicant who requests a concurrency review and variance hearing shall do so in writing to the community development department. Requests need not be in any particular form but must clearly indicate what is the specific variance request or administrative decision/interpretation review concerns, what property or project the application involved, and be accompanied by a payment determined by the City to be sufficient to cover the cost of providing the hearing procedure. Notice for a variance shall be that same notice provided for in chapter 50, article VI. 
(2)  The applicant shall demonstrate by competent, substantial evidence that the strict interpretation or enforcement of the provisions of this division would cause a unique hardship, peculiar to the applicant's parcel and not shared by other property owners in the area, may be granted a variance to the provisions of this chapter. 
(3)  The concurrency review and variance hearing shall be conducted as provided for in chapter 50, article VI. 
a.  An applicant's failure to appear or be represented at a scheduled review hearing shall be sufficient cause to deny the application on the strength of lack of evidence. 
b.  Within 30 calendar days after the applicant's review hearing, the concurrency review and variance hearing administrator shall have made available to the public, in writing, his decision of denial or approval, with or without conditions. Such report shall be released through the community development department. If agreed to by all parties, this requirement may be waived. 
c.  In reviewing applications shall consider all technical evaluations, all relevant factors, standards specified in other sections of this chapter or in the comprehensive plan, and shall utilize the following generalized guidelines and criteria: 
1.  That the variance, review, or decision on appeal will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is otherwise denied by this chapter to other similarly situated lands; 
2.  That any variance, review, or decision on appeal is the minimum increase in intensity or density that will make possible the reasonable use of the land, building, or structure, consistent with the need to protect public facilities or services; 
3.  That the variance, review, or decision on appeal is not inconsistent with the general intent, purpose, and spirit of this chapter, or with the city or county comprehensive plan, as it relates to the affected jurisdiction's facility or service to be impacted; 
4.  That the variance, review, or decision on appeal will not be injurious to the area involved or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare; 
5.  That the variance, review, or decision on appeal shall not authorize a development in conflict with any other city ordinance or the city comprehensive plan; and 
6.  That the variance, review, or decision on appeal is based upon evidence submitted by the applicant that factually supports the variance, review, or decision on appeal. 
7.  That the variance granted is only to the extent necessary to relieve the hardship. 
8.  That upon granting the variance, additional safeguards and conditions may be required to ensure proper compliance with the general spirit, purpose and intent of this chapter and of the comprehensive plan. 
d.  Further, the developmental review board may consider the following site-specific guidelines and criteria related to traffic impacts: 
1.  The expected timing of traffic impacts associated with the particular proposed use, and the status of levels of service associated with those impacts; 
2.  The proximity of intersections or highway links with identified service problems, the resolution of which involve solutions that will be impaired or prevented by the issuance of a variance, review, or appeal; 
3.  The ability of the applicant to utilize transportation management strategies as options to reduce the amount of the required variance, review, or appeal; and 
4.  The availability of alternative locations, not subject to concurrency management corridor requirements for the proposed use. 
(c)  Appeals procedure. Appeals of the decisions of the developmental review board made pursuant to this chapter shall be by petition for writ of certiorari to the circuit court. 
(d)  Applicability of appeals procedures. 
(1)  This section shall not be interpreted to limit or enhance the applicability of F.S. § 163.3215. 
(2)  This section shall apply to all decisions, determinations and results of applications made under the concurrency management system as soon as it becomes effective, as provided for in this chapter. 
(3)  In order to prevent the taking of property, any party challenging a decision, determination or result made under this chapter as a temporary or permanent taking of private property must exhaust the provisions of this section and any other subsequently enacted administrative procedures, including special master procedures under F.S. § 70.001 or section 50-53(3), before any action on a request for development is deemed final by any competent court or quasi-judicial proceeding having jurisdiction. 
(e)  The community development department shall maintain a summary record of all appeals that have been acted on by the developmental review board with a report then submitted on an annual basis to the city manager to file with the city clerk. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Secs. 54-13—54-19. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CONCURRENCY DETERMINATION AND ANALYSIS (EXCLUDING TRANSPORTATION) 
 
Sec. 54-20. - Concurrency determination generally. 
(a)  The calculations described in this chapter or in the city's or county's comprehensive plans shall be used to determine the projected demand of the proposed project described in an application for concurrency review. The calculations are listed by public facility and service type. Whenever the term "city" shall appear herein, it shall mean the city manager or designee is authorized to review calculations for the concurrency management system. The information necessary to enable the city to verify the facility/service demand calculations shall be provided by the applicant to the city. Submission requirements for calculations and formulas will be provided to the applicant by city staff. The actual values for the individual items (i.e., persons/household, adopted level of service) in the formulas will also be provided to applicants as part of the concurrency review submittal. 
(b)  After an application for development is accepted and passes review, it will be compared to the most recently adopted city and/or county concurrency test statement, as is applicable. The city shall compare the application for development to the public facilities and services on the current concurrency test statement(s), as they may apply to the location described on the application for development. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-21. - Concurrency test statement. 
(a)  The applicable portions of the concurrency test statement shall be applied to, at a minimum, the following: 
(1)  Potable water, sanitary sewer, solid waste, and drainage. The following are minimum standards that, when met, will satisfy the concurrency requirement: 
a.  A development order or permit is issued subject to the condition either through a binding executed agreement or an enforceable development agreement, pursuant to F.S. § 163.3220, or an agreement or development order issued pursuant to F.S. ch. 380, that, at the time of issuance of a certificate of occupancy or its functional equivalent, the necessary facilities and services are in place of and available to serve the new development. 
(2)  Recreation. The following are minimum standards that, when met, will satisfy the concurrency requirement: 
a.  A development order or permit is issued subject to the conditions either through a binding executed agreement or an enforceable development agreement, pursuant to F.S. § 163.3220, or an agreement or development order issued pursuant to F.S. ch. 380, that the necessary facilities and services needed to serve the new development are scheduled to be in place or under actual construction not more than one year after issuance of a certificate of occupancy or its functional equivalent as provided in the adopted schedule of capital improvements in the city capital improvements element. 
(3)  Public schools . The city may enter into an interlocal agreement with the county school board to implement a concurrency management program pursuant to the review procedures, review criteria and impact analysis contained in the interlocal agreement. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-22. - General strategies to rectify lack of concurrency. 
General strategies that may be considered in order to rectify the lack of concurrency include, but are not limited to the following list below. In all cases, these strategies may be considered effective only if one of the specific standards listed in subsection 54-21(a) (as they pertain to a particular facility and/or service) is achieved and/or mitigated. 
(1)  A plan amendment that improves the adopted level of service standard for the affected facilities and/or services. 
(2)  A renegotiated binding executed contract between the city and the applicant. 
(3)  A renegotiated enforceable development agreement, which may include but is not limited to development agreements pursuant to F.S. § 163.3220. 
(4)  A change in the funding source. 
(5)  A reduction in the scale (FAR and/or density) or impact of the proposed development. 
(6)  Phasing of the proposed development. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Secs. 54-23—54-29. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - TRANSPORTATION CONCURRENCY 
 
Sec. 54-30. - Fee required. 
(a)  Any person who, seeks a certificate of occupancy for land development activity or seeks to change a use by applying for issuance of an occupational license or development order, which will generate additional traffic shall be required to pay a multi-modal impact fee in the manner and amount set forth in this article. 
(b)  No certificate of occupancy, development order or occupational license for any activity requiring payment of an impact fee pursuant to this article shall be issued unless and until the multi-modal impact fee hereby required has been paid. 
(c)  Any person who has submitted a site plan or building permit application in accordance with the land development code prior to the effective date of this amendatory ordinance will be subject to the terms of the ordinance that was in effect at the time the site plan or building permit application was submitted. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-31. - County multi-modal impact fee. 
(a)  The city hereby adopts by reference the county's multi-modal impact fee code (chapter 150, and as amended) as it relates to the following: 
(1)  Computation of fee (section 150-40). 
(2)  Payment of fees and credits (section 150-41). 
(3)  Establishment of a trust fund (section 150-42). 
(4)  Disposition of funds (section 150-43). 
(5)  Review of fee structure (section 150-47). 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-32. - Development thresholds, required traffic analysis and required impact fee. 
(a)  When a traffic study is required, a mandatory methodology meeting is required with the city manager or designee and/or county staff to reach agreement on the scope, issues and requirements (such as study format, data requirements, transportation management plan, number of copies) for the traffic study. Following the meeting, the applicant or applicant's authorized representative, shall submit a letter to the city manager or designee confirming the agreed upon methodology and issues to be addressed in the traffic study. 
(b)  Development projects that generate between 51 and 300 new peak hour trips and are located within deficient road corridors are required to submit a transportation management plan (TMP) pursuant to section 54-34 designed to address their impacts while increasing mobility and reducing the demand for single occupant vehicle travel. The cost of transportation management strategies implemented for a project are creditable toward their multi-modal impact fee assessment. If the cost of the improvement exceeds the assessment, the development project would not be subject to payment of the fee. 
(c)  Development projects that generate more than 300 new peak hour trips and are located within deficient road corridors are required to conduct a traffic study and submit an accompanying report. The report shall include the results of the traffic study and a transportation management plan identifying improvements necessary to address the impacts of the project. The cost of transportation management strategies implemented for a project may be applied as credit toward the project's multi-modal impact fee assessment or payment of the fee could be included as part of a transportation management plan. 
(d)  Development projects that generate less than 51 new peak hour trips are required to pay a multi-modal impact fee in accordance with section 54-31. No transportation management plan or traffic study is required. 
(e)  Development projects that generate more than 50 new peak hour trips on non-deficient roads shall be reviewed by city manager or designee to determine if the impacts of the project adversely affect the level of service of the surrounding road network. If it is determined that approval of the development project would reduce the level of service of the adjacent road(s) to peak hour level of service E or F or would cause the volume-to-capacity ratio to reach or exceed 0.9, a TMP would be required. The applicant may submit a traffic study to verify whether their project would affect the level of service of the adjacent road(s). A TMP would be required if the results of the study confirm the findings of the city manager or designee. The TMP for such developments shall comply with the requirements of projects described in subsections 54-34(a) and (b) as appropriate and as determined by the city manager or designee. 
(f)  In the case of a change of use, redevelopment, or modification of an existing use, the impact fee shall be based upon the net increase in the impact fee for the new use as compared to the impact fee for the highest previous use in existence on or after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived (February, 24, 2015). 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-33. - Independent impact fee analysis. 
(a)  If an applicant opts not to have the impact fee determined according to section 54-31(1), then the applicant shall prepare and submit to the city manager or designee for approval of an independent fee calculation study for the land development activity for which a development order is sought. The traffic engineering and/or economic documentation submitted, which will require a pre-application meeting with the city manager or designee, shall show the basis upon which the independent fee calculation was made, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Trip generation studies: 
a.  Documentation of trip generation rates appropriate for the proposed land development activity. 
b.  Documentation of trip length appropriate for the proposed land development activity. 
c.  Documentation of trip data appropriate for the proposed land development activity. 
(2)  Economic documentation studies: 
a.  Documentation of the cost per lane per mile for roadway construction for the proposed land development activity. 
b.  Documentation of credits attributable to the proposed land development activity which the applicant will make available to replace the portion of the service volume used by the traffic generated by the proposed land development activity. 
(b)  Trip generation data. Trip generation documentation other than traffic engineering or economic documentation described in section 54-33(a)(1) and (2) may be submitted by the applicant in consideration of an independent fee calculation. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-34. - Transportation management plan and other strategies for mitigating impacts. 
(a)  Transportation management plans are to be submitted by applicants of development projects in conjunction with their site plans. Transportation management plans are required for development applications seeking to utilize transportation management strategies/improvements to mitigate their development impacts. The extent of the strategies/improvements included in an approved transportation management plan in terms of the scale of the project(s) and roadway capacity and/or mobility benefits provided shall be based primarily on the projected impact of the development project on the surrounding traffic circulation system. Specific conditions of the deficient road corridor impacted by the development shall also be considered. 
Transportation management plan strategies/improvements applicable to development projects within corridors will be determined at the time of site plan review. Transportation management plans must be developed by the applicant and approved by the city manager or designee. Transportation management plan strategies/improvements include, but are not limited to, those listed below. Transportation management plans seeking to implement strategies that do not involve structural improvements, such as ride-sharing and transit incentive programs, must include a monitoring program to ensure the strategies are carried out in accordance with the plan. Site-related improvements are not eligible for inclusion in transportation management plans. 
(1)  Intensity reduction. The intensity of the proposal may be reduced through an across-the-board reduction of the permitted floor area ratio, as it would otherwise normally apply to the proposal. Other such corrective actions that would reduce the intensity of the proposal may also apply. 
(2)  Density reduction. The density of the proposal may be decreased by a reduction in the number of units per acre below that which would otherwise normally apply to the proposal. 
(3)  Project phasing. A project may be divided into logical phases of development by area, with later phases of the development proposal's approval withheld until the needed facilities are available. 
(4)  Outparcel deletion. Those portions of the proposal characterized as outparcels that create separate and unique impacts may be deleted from the total proposal. 
(5)  Physical highway improvements. A project may construct link capacity improvements, acceleration/deceleration lanes, intersection improvements or frontage roads. 
(6)  Operational improvements (signal). This includes efforts involving signal removal or signal timing improvements. 
(7)  Access management strategies. These include access management controls such as the preclusion of a direct connection to an LOS deficient facility, right-in/right-out driveways, alternative driveway locations, reduction of a driveway, single point access, shared access or the implementation of median controls. 
(8)  Mass transit initiatives. A project may implement a plan to encourage transit (e.g., employer-issued bus passes). Other mass transit initiatives may include, but are not limited to the construction of bus stop amenities, bus pull-off areas and dedication of park and ride parking spaces. 
(9)  Demand management/commuter assistance . These include efforts to encourage ride-sharing (e.g., designated parking spaces for carpools, employer-sponsored carpool program, participation in transportation management organization/initiative programs), and to implement flexible work hours and telecommuting programs. 
(10)  Bicycle/pedestrian improvements. These would involve structural improvements or construction of a bikeway or sidewalk connecting an existing bikeway/sidewalk network or providing access to a school, park, shopping center, etc. These improvements may also include pedestrian treatments in parking areas, sidewalks connecting developments with adjacent land uses, trail improvements and bicycle rack and on-street bicycle lane installations, and the planting of trees to provide shade canopy along sidewalks. 
(11)  Intelligent transportation system improvements. This includes improvements pertaining to computerized traffic signal systems that automatically adjust to maximize traffic flow and to permit emergency vehicles to pass through intersections quickly. It also includes freeway management systems, such as electronic message signs, and electronic fare payment on public buses that reduce passenger boarding time. 
(12)  Livable community site design features. These include, but are not limited to, implementation of pedestrian friendly site design features such as orienting buildings toward the street and parking lots to the side or rear of buildings. 
(b)  Contribution to transportation capital project . In lieu of all or part of the multi-modal impact fee imposed under this chapter, the city manager or designee may accept the offer by an applicant to implement all or part of a transportation improvement project consistent with the comprehensive plan or the metropolitan planning organization's long range transportation plan. The project(s) may be for any mode of transportation, including rail, transit, pedestrian or bicycle travel, providing that it serves to add to the capacity of the surrounding transportation circulation system or to increase mobility and reduce the dependence on automobile travel. This offer shall not include site-related improvements. These transportation improvements must be in accordance with city requirements. The applicant shall submit an offer to make improvements in lieu of a fee payment. The offer shall include a letter detailing the improvements to be made, improvement plans and a construction cost estimate in sufficient detail to allow the city manager or designee to determine consistency with local requirements. If the city manager or designee accepts such an offer, the cost of the improvement project shall be credited against the multi-modal impact fee assessed on the proposed development. Upon satisfactory completion and construction approval of the transportation improvement made in lieu of all or a portion of the impact fee due, the improvement shall be accepted by the city or county for future maintenance. If the certificate of occupancy is requested prior to the completion of the approved project, then a performance bond shall be provided to the city manager to cover the balance of all work required following issuance of the certificate of occupancy. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Secs. 54-35—54-39. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ISSUANCE OF CERTIFICATE OF CONCURRENCY 
 
Sec. 54-40. - Issuance of certificate of concurrency. 
(a)  If the application for development being proposed is found to be exempt from the formal concurrency review, the city manager or designee may record and track facility and service impacts without issuance of a certificate of concurrency. If the application is not exempt, and is not subject to transportation impacts, then a certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall be issued without conditions. 
(b)  If the application for development is found to be subject to transportation impacts then a certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall indicate whether the proposal is acceptable or acceptable with conditions. In those instances where conditions are required, the specific conditions will be identified during site plan review. The conditions that may be applied include, but are not limited to, those required impact fees pursuant to section 54-31 and/or transportation mitigation measures pursuant to section 54-34. 
(c)  If the application for development is found by the latest concurrency analysis to fall within an area with a deficient level of service for a facility or service other than roads, then a certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall state that development shall either not be authorized or be authorized with conditions to be identified in the concurrency test statement. 
(d)  A certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall be issued within 30 days of receipt of an acceptable application for development. This period of time may be waived by the city manager or his designee with additional time granted, based upon the circumstances of the situation. 
(e)  The certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall indicate the date of issuance and will be valid for purposes of the issuance of development orders or permits for 12 months from the date of issuance. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Sec. 54-41. - Certificate of concurrency vesting. 
(a)  Any development order or permit that is issued within the effective period of a validly issued certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent shall be vested, for the purposes of concurrence, until the expiration of that development order or development permit, provided that development commences within the validity period of the development order or permit and continues in good faith, except that for purposes of a development order or development permit that authorizes construction, the validity period shall be limited to six months from the date of approval of the development order or development permit. Under no circumstances shall the validity period for a development order or permit or application for development under an existing certificate of concurrency or its functional equivalent be extended by action on a subsequent development order or permit for the same project or proposal, except when review of the subsequent development order or permit or application for development is based upon a more recently adopted or amended concurrency test statement, or subsection (b), below, applies. 
(b)  For those certificates of concurrency or its functional equivalent issued for a development agreement entered into by the city, pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 163.3220, as amended, the duration of such certificate of concurrency, as issued, shall be for the time period stated within the development agreement. 
( Ord. No. 02-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 2-24-15)  
Chapter 58 - DEVELOPMENT STANDARDS[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 58-1. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this chapter is to provide site design and improvement standards applicable to all development activity within the city. These standards are intended to ensure that future growth, development and redevelopment in the city conforms to certain minimum criteria, provided for the express purpose of achieving the goals of the city as stated in its comprehensive plan, as well as implementing the objectives and policies adopted to ensure fulfillment of those goals. The site design standards contained in this chapter are provided to protect the general health, safety and welfare of the city and its citizens; to ensure the beneficial impacts of growth and guard against the negative impacts of growth; and to protect neighboring properties as well as the general public from potential adverse impacts from a proposed use. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-2—58-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TRANSPORTATION SYSTEM STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 58-31. - Purpose. 
This article establishes minimum requirements applicable to the development as it relates to the transportation system, including public and private streets, bikeways, pedestrian ways, parking and loading areas, and access control to and from public streets. The standards in this section are intended to minimize the traffic impacts of development, to assure that all developments adequately and safely provide for the storage and movement of vehicles consistent with good engineering and development design practices. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-32. - Rights-of-way. 
(a)  Right-of-way widths. Right-of-way requirements for public road construction shall conform to the functional classification of the city's comprehensive plan and the functional classification and right-of-way standards of the county's comprehensive plan transportation element. 
(b)  Future right-of-way. Future right-of-way requirements shall be identified in the transportation circulation element of the city's comprehensive plan. 
(c)  Protection and use of rights-of-way. 
(1)  No encroachment shall be permitted into existing rights-of-way, except when authorized by the city. 
(2)  Use of the right-of-way for public or private utilities, including but not limited to sanitary sewer, potable water, telephone wires, cable television wires, internet, gas lines or electricity transmission, shall be allowed, subject to applicable city regulations. 
(3)  Sidewalks and bicycle ways shall be placed within the right-of-way. 
(d)  Vacation of rights-of-way. Applications to vacate a right-of-way shall be approved upon a finding that all of the following requirements are met: 
(1)  The requested vacation is consistent with the transportation circulation element of the city's comprehensive plan. 
(2)  The right-of-way does not provide the sole access to any property. Remaining access shall not be by easement. 
(3)  The vacation would not jeopardize the current or future location of any utility. 
(4)  The proposed vacation is not detrimental to the public interest and provides a positive benefit to the city. 
(e)  Private. (See chapter 38 for standards, as may be applicable.) 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-33. - Transportation circulation. 
(a)  Access. 
(1)  Unrestricted access shall not be permitted. 
(2)  Curb cuts at the property line shall be limited to a maximum of 25 feet for residential uses and 35 feet for nonresidential uses. At the sole discretion of the city manager or designee, the width may be increased so as to reasonably serve the use. 
(3)  All sites shall provide emergency vehicle access. 
(4)  Offset intersections shall be separated by a minimum of 150 feet on inside curves and 40 feet on outside curves. 
(5)  See chapter 38 for additional standards, as may be applicable. 
(b)  Sight visibility triangle. In order to provide a clear view of intersecting streets to the motorist, there shall be a triangular area of clear sight visibility formed by two intersecting streets or the intersection of a driveway and a street. The following standards shall be met: 
(1)  Nothing shall be erected, placed, parked, planted, or allowed to grow in such a manner as to materially impede vision between a height of two feet and ten feet above the grade, measured at the centerline of the intersection. The city shall have the right to immediately remove, without prior notice, any obstruction within the right-of-way that the city determines is in violation of this provision. 
(2)  The sight visibility triangle shall be formed by connecting a point on each street centerline, to be located at the distance from the intersection of the street centerlines, and a third line connecting the two points. Sight visibility triangles for property located on county, state and federal highways shall be determined by Florida Department of Transportation's Manual of Uniform Standards for Design, Construction and Maintenance for Street and Highway, as amended. 
(3)  The distance from the intersection of the street centerline for a local street that is a collector is 100 feet. 
(4)  The distance from the intersection of the street centerline for a local street that is not a collector is 50 feet. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-34. - Sidewalks and bikeways. 
(a)  New development. All new developments, whether residential or commercial, shall provide for pedestrian circulation. In residential areas that are predominately developed and where no sidewalks exist, the requirement for sidewalks may be waived by the city manager or designee. 
(b)  Commercial development. All commercial development must provide a minimum five-foot wide sidewalk in the following instances: 
(1)  Along public rights-of-way. 
(2)  Along or across private drives providing access to buildings or parking. 
(3)  Along access corridors between buildings. 
(4)  At interconnecting points where significant numbers of people will seek to walk, such as to amenities. 
(c)  Residential development. In residential development, hard-surfaced sidewalks a minimum of four feet in width shall be provided along at least one side of the public rights-of-way. 
(d)  New development and redevelopment. Encourage development to provide for bicycle storage, and appropriately designed bicycle and pedestrian pathways/crossings connecting internal and abutting residential and commercial areas, and connecting to recreation areas, schools, shopping areas and transit stops/terminal areas, as appropriate, and where physically possible. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-35. - Standards for drive-up facilities. 
(a)  Generally. All facilities providing drive-up or drive-through service shall provide on-site stacking lanes in accordance with the standards specified in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  Standards. 
(1)  The facilities and stacking lanes shall be located and designed to minimize turning movements in relation to the driveway access to streets and intersection. 
(2)  The facilities and stacking lanes shall be located and designed to minimize or avoid conflicts between vehicular traffic and pedestrian areas such as sidewalks, crosswalks or other pedestrian access ways. Drive-through lanes that obstruct the pathway between parking areas and entries into the building shall be designated with a pedestrian crossing that is delineated by landscaping curbing, raised or decorative pavement, and signage. 
(3)  A bypass lane shall be provided. 
(4)  Stacking lane distance, a minimum of 19 feet in length, shall be measured from the service window to the property line bordering the furthest street providing access to the facility. 
(5)  Minimum stacking lane distance shall be as follows: 
a.  Financial institutions shall provide not less than three stacking spaces at or behind the pneumatic tube(s) for the drive-through lane(s). 
b.  All other uses shall provide not less than five spaces at or behind the menu board. 
(6)  Alleys or driveways in or abutting areas designed, approved or developed for residential use shall not be used for circulation of traffic for drive-up facilities. 
(7)  Where turns are required in the exit lane, the minimum distance from any drive-up station to the beginning point of the curve shall be 34 feet. The minimum inside turning radius shall be 25 feet. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-36—58-65. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFF-STREET PARKING AND LOADING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 58-66—58-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OFF-STREET PARKING 
 
Sec. 58-86. - Applicability. 
Off-street parking facilities shall be provided for all development within the city pursuant to the requirements of this land development code. The facilities shall be maintained as long as the use exists that the facilities were designed to serve. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14) 
_____ 
Sec. 58-87. - Specific requirements. 
(a)  Minimum spaces. There shall be provided at the time of the erection of any main structure, or at the time any main structure or use is enlarged or increased in capacity such as, but not limited to, by adding dwelling units, guest rooms, floor area, change to more intense or new use, or seats, a minimum number of off-street automobile parking spaces in accordance with the provisions of subsections (b)—(f) of this section for each use on the site. When the number of required spaces is a fractional number of 0.5 or greater, then the required number of spaces shall be the next highest whole number. 
(b)  Residential uses. 
(1)  Single-family dwellings, per unit ..... 2 spaces 
(Accessory dwelling units are exempt.) 
(2)  Multifamily dwellings, per unit ..... 2 spaces 
(3)  Senior citizen housing developments that are deed restricted to senior citizens, for every ten dwelling units, shall have a minimum of eight parking spaces (0.8 dwelling units = 1 parking space). 
(4)  Nursing home or assisted living facility - one off-street parking space shall be provided for every three beds, plus one parking space for each two employees anticipated to be employed on the largest shift, plus one parking space for each staff physician on the largest shift. 
(c)  Commercial or industrial uses. 
(1)  General business, commercial or personal service establishments, per 250 square feet of gross floor area ..... 1 space 
(2)  Medical clinics or offices, per 200 square feet of gross floor area ..... 1 space 
(3)  Other office buildings, per 250 square feet of gross floor area ..... 1 space 
(4)  Motels and hotels, per hotel or motel unit ..... 1 space 
plus 3 spaces 
Ancillary uses such as restaurants, lounges, and meeting areas shall be provided with the required number of spaces. 
(5)  Eating or drinking establishments, for each 60 square feet, or fraction thereof, of floor area devoted exclusively to patron use ..... 1 space 
Plus, for each 400 square feet, or fraction thereof, or other area \ 1 space 
(6)  Auto service station, per service bay ..... 3 spaces 
(Service station bays or spaces at gas pumps may not be counted as spaces.) 
(7)  Furniture or carpet store, per 1,000 square feet of gross floor space ..... 1 space 
(8)  Open sales (e.g., autos, boats and other vehicles) ..... 20 percent 
of the display 
sales area 
(9)  Marinas, per each four berths ..... 1 space 
(10)  Campgrounds and travel parks, per campsite and/or vehicle site ..... 1 space 
plus those required 
for any accessory uses 
(11)  Commercial (such as wholesale or business services), manufacturing and industrial concerns not catering to the retail trade, per 400 square feet of gross floor area ..... 1 space 
(12)  Warehousing, per 1,500 square feet of gross floor area ..... 1 space 
(d)  Community service facilities. 
(1)  Religious facilities such as church, temples or places of worship, per 40 square feet of floor space in the main auditorium and educational buildings ..... 1 space 
(2)  Clubs, lodges or similar uses, per 50 square feet of floor area used for assembly, meeting or dining area ..... 1 space 
(3)  Hospitals, for each two patient beds ..... 1 space 
(4)  Library, museum, art gallery and similar uses, for 400 square feet of public area ..... 1 space 
(5)  Theaters, auditoriums, places of assembly, for each four seats ..... 1 space 
(e)  Educational facilities. 
(1)  Elementary, middle or high schools, per employee ..... 1 space 
Plus, per four seats in combination of an auditorium, stadium or gymnasium \ 1 space 
(2)  College, university or similar institution, same as (e)(1) above plus, for each classroom ..... 7 spaces 
(3)  Day care facility, for each ten students ..... 1 space 
Plus, per employee \ 1 space 
(f)  Mixed use residential facility. A facility of mixed use (e.g., retirement community) shall provide one off-street parking space per bed unless the applicant demonstrates to the city manager or designee that such a ratio is unnecessary for the facility in question. 
(g)  Uses not specifically listed. The number of parking spaces required for uses not specifically listed in the matrix shall be determined by the city manager or designee. The city manager or designee, shall consider requirements for similar uses and appropriate traffic engineering and planning data, and shall establish a minimum number of parking spaces based upon the principles of this land development code. 
(h)  Disabled facilities. 
(1)  Number. Accessible parking spaces for disabled persons shall be provided in the following manner: 
FIGURE 1

A minimum of four spaces shall be provided at a hospital or physical rehabilitation center. 
(2)  Size. Diagonal or perpendicular spaces for the disabled shall be a minimum of 12 feet wide. 
(3)  Access. All spaces for the disabled shall be provided with a curb cut or curb ramp to a pathway, a minimum of 44 inches wide to provide access to the building served and shall be located so that users will not be compelled to wheel behind parked vehicles. 
(4)  Location. Disabled parking spaces shall be located immediately adjacent to the building to be served. 
(5)  Marking. Such spaces shall be posted with a permanent above-grade sign bearing the international symbol of accessibility and the caption "Parking by Disabled Permit Only." 
(6)  Calculation. In calculating the required number of accessible spaces, the accessible space shall be included in determining the threshold for additional accessible spaces (i.e., for each multiple of 25 parking spaces, the accessible spaces shall be included as part of the total, not in addition to the total). 
(i)  Bicycle parking. 
(1)  Purpose. The bicycle parking requirements of this section are intended to encourage the use of bicycles as a means of transportation in the city by ensuring that adequate bicycle parking facilities are provided at travel destinations. By encouraging use of bicycles, the public health, safety and welfare will be furthered through improved air quality, reduced energy consumption and more efficient use of vehicular parking facilities. 
(2)  Locational requirements. All bicycle parking facilities provided to satisfy the requirements of this section shall be located on the same building site as the uses which they serve, convenient to the principal entrance(s) of the building. These facilities may be located in the rear 50 percent of any required front yard setback or in other areas approved by the community development department, but shall not be located in any vehicle parking space required by chapter 58. 
(3)  Design requirements. All bicycle parking facilities shall be approved by the community development department. 
(4)  Covered parking encouraged. Wherever the design of the building or use being served by the bicycle parking facility includes covered areas which could accommodate such facilities either as proposed or through economical redesign, covered bicycle parking shall be encouraged. To this end, the community development department shall be authorized to permit modifications to the design requirements of this chapter commensurate with the cost of providing covered parking.

b.  Bicycle parking encouraged for other uses. For any use not listed, bicycle parking facilities may be provided in lieu of not more than two percent of all vehicle parking spaces required by this section, or one space (whichever is greater). For each vehicle space so converted, eight bicycle parking spaces shall be provided. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14) 
_____ 
Sec. 58-88. - Maximum number of parking spaces and provision for relief. 
(a)  The minimum parking space requirements of subsections 58-87(b)—(f) shall not be exceeded. 
(b)  Any development, redevelopment, or change of use of property through the use of a site plan that proposes to exceed the minimum parking requirements shall either: 
(1)  Require the approval of a variance to be granted in strict accordance by conclusively meeting all the required findings of chapter 50, article VI, pertaining to the granting of variances; or 
(2)  Require the approval of a development agreement in accordance with chapter 50, article VII. 
(c)  It is the intent of this section to permit the continuance of those uses on properties/developments that were in compliance with the parking requirements in place prior to the adoption date of this section, March 28, 2006, until the use(s) or property is proposed to change use or is subject to a development order defined in section 50-86. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-89—58-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - OFF-STREET LOADING 
 
Sec. 58-111. - Spaces required. 
Loading areas shall comprise one space for every commercial or industrial building of 5,000 square feet or more, plus one additional space for each additional 25,000 square feet of gross building space. This requirement may be waived, at the sole discretion of the city manager or city manager designee, depending on the nature of the proposed use. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-112. - Access and design. 
(a)  Each loading space shall have direct access to an alley or street. 
(b)  Each loading space shall have the following minimum dimensions: 
(1)  Length, 25 feet. 
(2)  Width, 12 feet. 
(3)  Height, 14 feet. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-113—58-135. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 58-136. - Location. 
Off-street parking or loading lots may be developed in any required side, front or rear yard. Parking garages shall conform to the minimum yard requirements for the principal building of the district in which they are located. Parking spaces for all dwellings should be located on the same lot or parcel with the main structure to be served. Parking spaces for other uses should be provided on the same lot or parcel not more than 500 feet distant as measured along the nearest pedestrian walkway. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-137. - Surface. 
Lots shall be surfaced by a durable paving material, properly graded and drained to dispose of all surface water. Parking areas designed for use three days a week or less, such as for religious facilities, may be surfaced up to 100 percent with sod. The use of pervious/permeable concrete or other similar type porous surface is encouraged as part of low impact development techniques as described and may be required pursuant to this chapter, article IV. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-138. - Dimensions. 
Each parking space shall be measured according to Figure 3. The marking of parking spaces is required in lots designed for more than four vehicles. Access drives or aisles shall be measured according to Figure 3. For those lots of 50 spaces or more the developer may set aside ten percent of the total parking spaces for compact car parking. Such areas shall be a minimum of eight and one-half feet wide and 18 feet deep exclusive of required access drives or drive aisles.
