( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-139. - Vehicular access. 
All parking spaces, except for single family, dwellings, shall be restricted and controlled by curbs or concrete bumpers, including those spaces located on sod. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-140. - Illumination. 
Lots shall be adequately illuminated if designed for use by more than four vehicles after dark. Where parking lots abut residential uses, lighting fixtures shall be shielded or directed so as to protect the residential use from direct parking lot illumination. Residential uses will also be shielded from parking lots by hedges, berms or walls or any combination thereof so that no lights from vehicles using the parking lot shall shine into any residence windows. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-141. - Egress. 
Excluding single-family residences, all off-street parking areas shall be designed so that no vehicle is required to back into a public or private street or through drive to obtain egress. For the purpose of this provision, drives or aisles serving more than 25 vehicles and which are not internal to a parking bay but serve one or more parking bays are considered to be through drives. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-142. - Landscaping. 
Vehicular use areas shall be landscaped in compliance with this chapter, article V. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-143. - Open sales and service areas. 
To protect and maintain safe traffic conditions, all open sales and service areas, e.g., automobile sales lots, trailer sales lots, shall provide a minimum total area of 20 percent of the lot or parcel area as open off-street parking area. Parking required per section 58-87 shall not be counted towards satisfying the requirement of this section. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-144. - Permanent reservation. 
Area reserved for off-street parking or loading in accordance with this division shall not be reduced in area or changed to any other use unless the permitted use it serves is discontinued or modified, except where equivalent parking or loading space is provided. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-145. - Aggregation. 
Parking requirements for two or more uses, of the same or different types, may be satisfied by the allocation of the required number of spaces for each use in a common parking facility. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-146. - Nonconformities. 
In addition to the nonconforming compliance thresholds pursuant to chapter 50, full compliance with the parking requirements and design standards shall be required where the seating capacity, building addition/expansion, or other factors increase the required parking by 25 percent or more. The city manager or city manager designee in their discretion shall determine if a formal site plan submittal is required. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-147—58-200. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER MANAGEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 58-201. - Purpose. 
The United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA), pursuant to Title 40, Section 122.26 of the Code of Federal Regulations, and as amended, has mandated that municipalities provide the legal authority to control discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system under the NPDES permit in order to control the quality of discharges from the municipal separate storm sewer system. Therefore, the city commission finds it necessary and in the public interest to protect the quality of waters receiving stormwater discharges for the health, safety, and general welfare of the citizens of the city. 
In addition to meeting the requirements of this land development code, the design and performance of all stormwater management systems shall comply with applicable national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) regulations, state regulations, and the rules of the Southwest Florida Water Management District (SWFWMD) and the Florida Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). In all cases the strictest of the applicable standards shall apply. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-202. - Exceptions. 
The following development activities are exempt from this article, except steps to control erosion and sedimentation must be taken for all development. 
(1)  The construction of a single-family, duplex or triplex residential dwelling unit and related accessory structures on a single parcel of land. 
(2)  Any development within a subdivision if each of the following conditions has been met: 
a.  Stormwater management provisions for the subdivision were previously approved and remain valid as part of a final plat or development plan; and 
b.  The development is conducted in accordance with the stormwater management provisions submitted with the final plat or development plan. 
(3)  Bona fide agricultural activity, including forestry, provided farming activities are conducted in accordance with the requirements set forth in an approved natural resources conservation service conservation plan and forestry activities are conducted in accordance with the silviculture best management practices manual published by the state division of forestry. If the conservation plan and forestry best management practices are not implemented accordingly, this exemption shall become void and a stormwater permit shall be required. 
(4)  Maintenance activity that does not change or affect the quality, rate, volume or location of stormwater flows on the site or of stormwater runoff. 
(5)  Action taken under emergency conditions to prevent imminent harm or danger to persons, or to protect property from imminent fire, violent storms, hurricanes or other hazards. A report of the emergency action shall be made to the community development department as soon as practicable. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-203. - Scope. 
A complete drainage system shall be provided. All areas within the development, including lots, streets and other areas, must be suitably drained. In addition, where drainage runoff from outside the development passes over or through the areas of the development, such runoff shall be included in the drainage system design. The system should be designed for long life and shall be suitable for low-cost maintenance by normal maintenance methods. 
(1)  Maximum use shall be made of lakes, low impact development (LID) techniques and retention ponds. 
(2)  Unless approved by the city engineer, all drainage systems in public drainage easements or drainage rights-of-way, with the exception of major county drainage ditches and canals, will be in pipe. 
(3)  Stormwater system design shall be in accordance with design criteria pursuant to this article. 
(4)  To reduce non-point source pollutant loadings and improve the efficiency of the city's drainage system, dumping of debris of any kind (e.g., yard clippings and trimmings) into drainage ditches, canals and storm water control structures shall be prohibited. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-204—58-224. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONVEYANCE AND CONTROL SYSTEM DESIGN STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 58-225. - General standards. 
(a)  All stormwater from all construction sites shall be controlled in such a way as to retain sediment onsite and prevent violations of state water quality standards or national pollutant discharge elimination system permits. Stormwater from areas of development activity shall be treated or managed on-site, using best management practices (treatment methods and practices to control the discharge of pollutants) in accordance with NPDES permits or as required and permitted by DEP or SWFWMD, prior to discharging to a municipal system, Lake Seminole and/or any wetlands. All stormwater discharges from the site shall be of a quality which will not adversely impact the water quality or beneficial uses of the receiving water. 
(b)  The hydraulics of underground drainage through storm sewers, where employed, and drainage structures such as bridges, box culverts, headwalls, dams, weirs, spillways, bulkheads and other structures shall conform to good accepted engineering practice and coefficients of friction suitable for the type of pipe or structure utilized. Foundations or other supports or anchoring methods shall be adequate. Erosion shall be minimized by energy dissipators or other means of reducing flow velocity. 
(c)  The review and approval of stormwater facility design shall be pursuant to the standards identified below or as may be recommended for modification by the city engineer and as approved by the city manager. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-226. - Valley curb. 
Valley curb shall be 24 inches wide with a minimum thickness of six inches at the center, with a three-inch rise to the back of the curb and a one-inch rise to the pavement edge, 3,000 pounds per square inch concrete used throughout. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-227. - Curb and gutter. 
Curbs shall be 12 inches deep, five-inch top width with a six-inch deep, one-inch wide reveal on the face. Gutters shall be six inches deep, 18 inches wide with a slope of one inch to one foot, 3,000 pounds per square inch concrete used throughout. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-228. - Vertical curb. 
Vertical curb without gutters shall be six inches wide, 18 inches deep with six-inch curb above pavement, 3,000 pounds per square inch concrete used throughout. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-229. - Culvert pipe. 
Culvert pipe shall be reinforced concrete pipe, PVC or ADS N-12 or equal. Corrugated metal pipe shall not be used between structures or within road right-of-way. Culvert pipe under roadways shall be reinforced concrete pipe. Easements, as may be required by the city, for pipe outside the right-of-way are subject to case-by-case review. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-230. - Headwalls. 
All culverts under roadways where sufficient pipe length is not provided shall have headwalls made of reinforced concrete or other approved structure. Where shallow swales intersect deeper drainage ditches, erosion control shall be provided by use of culvert pipes, concrete swales, headwalls with spillways, or other suitable means. Cover material over culverts in swales shall be suitably stabilized to prevent erosion. The proposed design of reinforced concrete headwalls shall be submitted for approval. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-231. - Manholes and junction boxes. 
Drainage connections to drainageways, and intersecting or converging drainageways shall be suitably designed and aligned to provide effective erosion and silting control. All manholes or junction boxes shall be constructed of reinforced concrete. They shall be approved by the city engineer as to appropriate size. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-232. - Catch basins. 
All catch basins shall be constructed of reinforced concrete. They shall be approved by the city engineer as to the appropriate size. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-233. - Valley crossings in streets. 
The design of valley crossings in streets shall be submitted for approval. In no case shall concrete valley gutters be less than 36 inches wide. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-234. - Underdrains. 
(a)  Underdrains for curb and gutter construction are required on both sides of all roads within the public right-of-way. 
(b)  Underdrains for roadside swale construction shall be installed if the bottom of roadside swale ditches is less than 24 inches below the edge of the road surface. 
(c)  Underdrain installation shall be per approval by the city engineer. 
(d)  An isolated underdrain system with cleanout/inspection boxes shall be required if the storm drain system is of insufficient depth to ensure a properly functional underdrain system. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-235. - Swale drainage. 
(a)  Swale geometry. Swale drainage will be considered only with the approval of the city engineer. 
(b)  Swale erosion protection. Swales shall be provided with permanent erosion protection. Such protection may be turf, using an approved type of grass, or approved type of pavement liner may be utilized. When turf protection is used, the swales shall be sodded, sprigged or seeded a lateral distance extending from within one foot of the road pavement to the top of the swale backslope. Mulching in accordance with state road department standards shall be acceptable. 
(c)  Driveways across swales. Driveways across swales shall have placed beneath them drainage pipes of adequate size, as determined by the city engineer. The culvert pipes shall be long enough to provide an adequate shoulder, as determined by the city engineer, on each side of the driveway pavement. The ends of the pipe shall be finished with mitered end sections or headwalls. 
(d)  For local lot drainage, rear yard swales are not permitted when traversing more than one lot. Yard drains and inlets are required where necessary for adequate drainage. Where side yard swales and other swales are required, side slopes shall be not steeper than 5:1 for subdivisions and 3:1 for commercial sites. Minimum depth of swales will be six inches. Minimum gradients of yard swales shall be one-eighth inch per foot (one percent). Vertical rise from high point of swale to lowest floor level shall be not less than eight inches. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-236. - Canals, lakes, major waterways. 
(a)  Open channels other than major waterways may be defined as minor streams, canals, ditches, and swales. Such open channels shall be designed in accordance with good accepted engineering practice adapted to local conditions. Cross-sectional areas and hydraulic gradients shall be such that design velocities shall not result in soil scouring for the soil and/or turf conditions reasonably anticipated. Mean velocities greater than three feet per second shall be considered excessive unless permanent channel lining or other suitable protection is employed. The design shall provide that the channels will not overflow their banks at design flood conditions. 
(b)  All major waterways shall conform to proposed construction as shown on master plans for the various drainage basins. Improvement or establishment of major canals is of such significance that the design of each such improvement or establishment proposed shall be developed as a separate hydraulic problem. Engineering data, criteria and suitable calculations shall be submitted prior to approval of construction plans. 
(c)  Where lakes are included as a part of the drainage system, detention time in these lakes may be considered in computing discharge by presentation of hydrographs developed with accepted engineering methods. Lakes shall have a maximum side slope of 3:1 to a point two feet below water level. Proposed designs shall be submitted for approval. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-237. - Floodplains. 
Where lands are or have been subject to periodic flooding and minimum building elevations have not been established, the subdivider's engineer shall establish flood elevations at design flood conditions and meet any requirements of chapter 62, article IV. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-238. - Drainage outfalls. 
(a)  Studies may be required showing that existing outfalls are both positive and adequate. 
(b)  Drainage wells, seepage basins or underdrains will not be accepted as positive outfalls. In some cases of severe hardship, the city engineer may approve such an outfall with special site specific restrictions and requirements. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-239—58-260. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STORMWATER POND CONSTRUCTION AND MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 58-261. - Retention/detention of surface water runoff. 
(a)  All new construction, development, threshold redevelopment (where any existing multifamily or nonresidential structure and/or parking lot is rebuilt in its entirety) or substantial improvement (where any existing multifamily or nonresidential structure is substantially modified or rehabilitated in excess of 51 percent of the most current total assessed property value per the county property appraiser records or where more than 51 percent of a parking lot area is demolished and/or replaced), other than a single-family home, and all site plans shall include on-site retention/detention of surface water runoff as required by this Code, the applicable SWFWMD, state or federal regulations. General design standards include the following: 
(1)  The peak rate of runoff from a 25-year frequency, 24-hour duration rainfall shall be equal to, or less than, a predevelopment (no impervious surface) condition and used as the design storm. 
(2)  The 100-year, 24-hour design storm event generates 12 inches of rainfall, and shall be used when no potential for outfall into a receiving body exists. 
(3)  Ultimate land usage shall be assumed for selection of proper runoff coefficients within the basins involved, whether within the development or not. Weighted runoff coefficients shall be applied where different coefficients apply within the areas comprising the basin. The rational formula may be used to determine peak runoff rates for project with total drainage areas of ten acres or less. Other, more precise, methods acceptable to the city engineer shall be employed for developments with larger drainage areas. 
(b)  A single family home may be required to provide drainage swales or a French drain system if so determined by the city manager, or city manager designee. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-262. - Drainage plan. 
Every application for new construction or substantial improvement to existing construction, including single-family homes, subdivided lands and un-platted lands, must include a drainage plan that demonstrates: 
(1)  All runoff entering the site from adjacent lands is carried through the site and discharged to a positive and adequate outfall. A sinkhole shall not be considered a positive or adequate outfall. 
(2)  On-site detention is provided as required. 
(3)  Existing surface water drainage systems are not blocked or diverted onto neighboring property. 
(4)  The drainage system will be maintained as such, not landscaped (except for sod or bio-filtration system) or built upon, and will continue to function. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-263. - Diversion; excavation. 
(a)  Surface water runoff shall not be diverted across major drainage basin boundaries. 
(b)  On-site stormwater detention areas may be excavated within the 100-year floodplain as long as perimeter berms are not constructed above existing ground level and adequate compensation is provided on-site. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-264. - Retention/detention facilities design standards. 
The attenuation, treatment and habitat characteristics of retention/detention facilities shall be designed as follows: 
(1)  Side slopes of wet detention ponds shall be constructed to a maximum slope of three feet horizontal to one foot vertical (3:1). Side slopes of dry detention areas shall have maximum slopes of 1½:1. All slopes shall be stabilized to prevent erosion. 
(2)  Vertical walls shall not be permitted around more than 50 percent of the perimeter of wet detention ponds without the installation of a fountain or aeration system. No more than 50 percent of the perimeter of a dry detention pond may be walled if the remainder is sloped no steeper than 3:1. 
(3)  At least 50 percent of the surface area of a detention area must be open to sunlight. 
(4)  During excavation and construction, downstream turbidity shall be maintained at conditions reasonable to assure maintenance of water quality to meet the conditions of the applicable SWFWMD, state or federal regulations. 
(5)  All ground surfaces disturbed by construction shall be sodded or seeded per the city engineer's standards. 
(6)  All construction practices shall conform to accepted best management practices for erosion control, such as straw bales, ground cover, slope stabilization, temporary vegetation, silt barriers trenched into the soil and turbidity barriers. 
(7)  Detention areas must be roughed out prior to other site grading, as a means of erosion control. 
(8)  For on-site irrigation purposes, water quality treatment volume may be pumped onto land from which surface water runoff returns to the same detention area. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-265. - When low-impact development (LID) systems are required. 
(a)  Low-impact development (LID) is a stormwater management approach that uses a set of hydrologic controls (structural and non-structural) distributed throughout the site and integrated as a treatment train (i.e., in series) to replicate the natural hydrologic functioning of the landscape. Unlike conventional systems, which typically control and treat runoff using a single engineered stormwater pond located at the "bottom of the hill," LID systems are designed to promote volume attenuation and treatment at or near the source of stormwater runoff via distributed retention, detention, bio-filtration, treatment, and harvesting mechanisms. The fundamental goal of applying LID concepts, design, and practice is to improve the overall effectiveness and efficiency of stormwater management relative to conventional systems, reducing total and peak runoff volumes, and improving the quality of waters discharged from the site. LID systems are designed primarily for addressing stormwater quality and will provide some attenuation of peak flows; however, they may not provide sufficient storage capacity to meet SWFWMD water quantity control criteria. 
(b)  The utilization of LID techniques or in combination with traditional stormwater systems, as approved by the city manager, shall be required for new, threshold redevelopment or substantial improvements to multifamily and nonresidential development on five acres or more. LID techniques may be required on such developments on less than five acres on a case-by-case basis. 
(c)  LID techniques include, but are not limited, to the following: 
(1)  Bio-filtration/bio-filtration retention. Bio-filtration areas are shallow depressions used as structural stormwater controls to capture, treat, and infiltrate stormwater runoff. Bio-filtration retention systems are also shallow depressions which utilize underdrains as structural stormwater controls to capture and treat stormwater runoff and connect to an outfall such as a stormwater pond or roadway. Within the bio-filtration area, nutrient-adsorption media, soils, mulch, and planted vegetation facilitate treatment and remove pollutants from the runoff. Multiple bio-filtration or bio-filtration retention areas are often distributed throughout a larger catchment, providing numerous treatment and water storage areas. Although any one treatment area may be small, the cumulative effect can be significant. 
(2)  Dry wells. A dry well consists of a small excavated pit backfilled with aggregate, usually pea gravel or stone. Dry wells function as infiltration systems used to control runoff from building rooftops. Another special application of dry wells is modified catch basins, where inflow is a form of direct surface runoff. Dry wells provide the majority of treatment by processes related to soil infiltration, including adsorption, trapping, filtering, and bacterial degradation. 
(3)  Parking lot/sidewalk pervious pavement. Pervious pavement or pavers (also commonly referred to as permeable pavement and porous pavement) systems are structural stormwater controls that capture and temporarily store part or all of the water quality volume. Pervious pavement systems infiltrate and capture rainfall that falls on the surface at rates up to the surface infiltration rate, compared to impervious pavements where almost all direct rainfall becomes runoff. These systems infiltrate water below the surface, where water is typically allowed to ex-filtrate into the surrounding parent soil. Under these circumstances, pervious pavement systems function as retention systems. Pervious pavement systems should be considered as part of a treatment system with credit based on available storage volume and the ability of the system to readily recover the storage volume. 
(4)  Stormwater harvesting. It is a combination of a specified harvesting volume and rate of use intended to achieve yearly average reduction in discharge volume. This system utilizes a surface detention pond or underground storage system to hold water, primarily for irrigation use. 
(d)  The city manager or designee may permit the following incentives for utilizing LID techniques. 
(1)  Reduce required parking lot drive-aisle and parking stall depth up to two feet. 
(2)  Permit up to 25 percent compact parking spaces. 
(3)  Permit one landscape island per 20 spaces if drainage is directed toward interior vehicular use area bio-filtration swales or retention ponds. 
(4)  Reduce the parking requirement for multi-family and nonresidential uses up to 25 percent. 
(5)  Other waivers to this chapter, as deemed appropriate and approved by the city manager, to provide incentives for utilizing LID techniques. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-266—58-285. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DEDICATION OR MAINTENANCE OF SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 58-286. - Dedication. 
If a stormwater management system approved under this land development code will function as an integral part of the city-maintained regional system, as determined by the city engineer, the facilities should be dedicated to the city. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-287. - Maintenance by an acceptable entity. 
(a)  All stormwater management systems that are not dedicated to the city shall be operated and maintained by one of the following entities: 
(1)  A local governmental unit including a county, municipality, or municipal service taxing unit, special district or other governmental unit. 
(2)  An active water control district created pursuant to F.S. ch. 298, or drainage district created by special act, or community development district created pursuant to F.S. ch. 190, or special assessment district created pursuant to F.S. ch. 170. 
(3)  A state or federal agency. 
(4)  An officially franchised, licensed or approved communication, water, sewer, electrical or other public utility. 
(5)  The property owner or developer if: 
a.  Written proof is submitted in the appropriate form by either letter or resolution that a governmental entity or such other acceptable entity as set forth in subsections (1)—(4) above will accept the operation and maintenance of the stormwater management and discharge facility at a time certain in the future. 
b.  A bond or other assurance of continued financial capacity to operate and maintain the system is submitted. 
(6)  For-profit or nonprofit corporations, including homeowners associations, property owners associations, condominium owners associations or master associations, if: 
a.  The owner or developer submits documents constituting legal capacity and a binding legal obligation between the entity and the city affirmatively taking responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the stormwater management facility. 
b.  The association has sufficient powers reflected in its organizational or operational documents to: 
1.  Operate and maintain the stormwater management system as permitted by the city. 
2.  Establish rules and regulations. 
3.  Assess members. 
4.  Contract for services. 
5.  Exist perpetually, with the articles of incorporation providing that if the association is dissolved, the stormwater management system will be maintained by an acceptable entity as described above. 
(b)  If a project is to be constructed in phases, and subsequent phases will use the same stormwater management facilities as the initial phase or phases, the operation/maintenance entity shall have the ability to accept responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the stormwater management systems of future phases of the project. 
(c)  In phased developments that have an integrated stormwater management system, but employ independent operation/maintenance entities for different phases, the operation/maintenance entities, either separately or collectively, shall have the responsibility and authority to operate and maintain the stormwater management system for the entire project. That authority shall include cross easements for stormwater management and the authority and ability of each entity to enter and maintain all facilities, should any entity fail to maintain a portion of the stormwater management system within the project. 
(d)  The applicant shall be an acceptable entity and shall be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the stormwater management system from the time construction begins until the stormwater management system is dedicated to and accepted by another acceptable entity. 
(e)  The maintenance of a drainage system constructed or placed on private property is the unequivocal responsibility of the property owner(s) or the designated maintenance entity. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-288. - Illicit discharge and penalties. 
Any discharge to a municipal separate storm sewer system, Lake Seminole or to waters of the United States that is not composed entirely of stormwater, with the exception of discharges approved by the city, county, SWFWMD or DEP. Any discharge in violation of a NPDES system or SWFWMD permit shall constitute an illicit discharge and such violation and penalties shall be enforced pursuant to Code of Ordinances, chapter 18, article IX. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-289. - Nonconformities. 
In addition to the nonconforming compliance thresholds pursuant to chapter 50, any existing development that does not comply with the stormwater management requirements of this land development code must be brought into full compliance or as may be required by the Southwest Florida Water Management District when any proposed use of the development as part of a formal site plan submittal increases the impervious surface ratio by 25 percent or more. When any proposed use of the development does not require a formal site plan submittal, but increases the impervious surface area, then only compliance with the regulations of the Southwest Florida Water Management District shall be required. The city manager or city manager designee in their discretion shall determine if a formal site plan submittal is required. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-290—58-320. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - LANDSCAPING AND BUFFERING 
 
Sec. 58-321. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Grounds permit means a permit that must be secured from the city prior to the development or redevelopment of or addition to any vehicular use area. 
Plant material means as follows: 
(1)  Accent tree means a species of tree which grows to a typical mature height of less than 30 feet and whose natural form is a narrow or oval shape as opposed to a broad canopy shape. Palms are not classified as accent trees. 
(2)  Caliper is the minimum diameter of a tree measured six inches above the ground for trees up to and including four inches in diameter, and 12 inches above the ground for trees having a larger diameter. This measurement is utilized by nurseries for measuring tree sizes. 
(3)  Canopy trees are self-supporting, woody plants that normally grow to a minimum height of 15 feet with a mature crown spread of 15 feet or greater and having trunks that can be maintained with over five feet of clear wood. 
(4)  Diameter at breast height (dbh) means the diameter of a tree measured at a point four and one-half feet in height from the base of the tree at grade level. This measurement is utilized inventorying mature trees and for tree replacement mitigation and tree valuation purposes. 
(5)  Ground covers include plant materials that normally reach a maximum height of not more than 12 inches and may be used in lieu of grass. 
(6)  Hedge means a row of planted shrubs forming a boundary or screen. 
(7)  Lawn grass includes all species normally grown as permanent lawns in the city or county. 
(8)  Major gateway streets include Park, Seminole and Johnson Boulevards; Park, 113th and 102nd Streets, and Starkey Road. 
(9)  Shrub is a self-supporting woody plant with several permanent stems instead of a single trunk. 
(10)  Vehicular use areas include all areas used for the circulation, loading, parking and/or display of any and all types of vehicles, boats or heavy construction equipment, whether self-propelled or not, and all land upon which vehicles traverse as a function of the primary uses. This shall include, but not be limited to, vehicular circulation of a drive-in nature, such as service stations, convenience stores, banks, restaurants and the like. Only driveways and parking spaces serving single and two-family uses shall be an exception to this definition. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-322. - Purpose. 
This article is intended to assure that for all development in the city other than single-family or duplex, where off-street parking and open lot sales, display and service areas are provided, a portion of such areas be devoted to landscape beautification and natural plant growth. The purpose of this requirement is to improve the appearance of the city, major gateway streets, environment, character and value of the total urban area; reduce urban heat island effects, promote energy conversation, and to protect nearby properties, thereby promoting the public health and general welfare. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-323. - Design principles. 
(a)  A landscape plan shall be submitted for review and approval that demonstrates compliance with this article and should conform to the following general design principles: 
(1)  Landscaping should integrate the proposed development into existing site features through consideration of existing topography, hydrology, soils and vegetation, and buffering of adjacent uses. 
(2)  The functional elements of the development plan, particularly the drainage systems and internal circulation systems for vehicles and pedestrians, should be integrated into the landscaping plan. 
(3)  Landscaping should be used to minimize potential erosion through the use of ground covers or any other type of landscape material that aids in soil stabilization. 
(4)  Landscaping should enhance the visual environment through the use of materials that achieve variety with respect to seasonal changes, species of living material selected, textures, colors and size of maturity. 
(5)  Landscaping design should consider the aesthetic and functional aspects of vegetation, both when initially installed and when the vegetation has reached maturity. Newly installed plants should be placed at intervals appropriate to the size of the plant at maturity, and the design should use short- and long-term elements to satisfy the general design principles of this section over time. 
(6)  Landscaping should enhance public safety and minimize nuisances. The city will perform an on-site inspection as part of the final inspection. 
(7)  Landscaping should be used to provide windbreaks, channel wind and increase ventilation. 
(8)  Landscaping should maximize the shading of streets and vehicle use areas. 
(9)  The selection and placement of landscaping materials should consider the effect on existing or future solar access, of enforcing the use of solar radiation, and of conserving the maximum amount of energy. 
(b)  No development plan shall be denied solely on the basis of the design principles in this section. The purpose of this section is to provide developers with a checklist of principles in designing landscaped areas. 
(c)  Any modification to an approved landscape plan shall require city approval pursuant to this article. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-324. - Installation of landscaping. 
All landscaping shall be installed in accordance with accepted good planting procedures as prescribed by the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agriculture (IFAS) and/or registered landscape architect. Plant material to be used in conformance of this article shall conform to the standards for Florida No. 1 or better as given in the current "Grade and Standards for Nursery Plants," State of Florida, Department of Agriculture, Tallahassee, or equal thereto. At a minimum 25 percent of all required canopy trees shall be native Florida vegetation. Plant materials and trees shall be planted in an upright manner perpendicular to the ground and trees shall be appropriately staked for a minimum period of at least 60 days. 
(1)  Landscaped areas, wall structures and walks shall be protected from vehicular encroachment or overhang through appropriate wheel stops or curbs, located a minimum of two and one-half feet from such areas, structures or walkways. When wheel stops are not provided, any required landscape buffer width shall be increased by two and one-half feet (Exhibit A). 
(2)  Ground covers must present a finished appearance and reasonably complete coverage at time of planting. Ground cover size at time of installation must be a one gallon minimum planted at a maximum of 24 inches on center. It is encouraged in lieu of turf to reduce irrigation needs. 
(3)  Grass may be sodded, plugged, sprigged or seeded; except that solid sod shall be used in areas subject to erosion. In areas where other than solid sod or grass seed is used, nurse-grass seed shall be sown for immediate effect and protection until coverage is otherwise achieved. Grass sod shall be clean and reasonably free of weeds and noxious pests or diseases. Turf areas should be consolidated and limited to areas of pedestrian traffic, recreation and erosion control. 
(4)  Shrubs and hedges shall be minimum of 18 inches in height when measured immediately after planting. Hedges, where required, shall be planted and maintained so as to form a continuous, unbroken, solid visual screen within a maximum of one year after time of planting. Spacing for plants for a hedge shall be no more than two or three feet on center, depending on the species used. 
(5)  Accent trees may be substituted for canopy trees at a ratio of 2:1. A maximum of 30 percent of the required canopy trees may be substituted with accent trees. At least 60 percent of all required canopy and accent trees, other than palms, shall have a minimum caliper diameter of three inches at the time of planting. At least 40 percent of all required trees, other than palms, shall have a minimum caliper diameter of two inches at the time of planting. Fractions of a single tree required as a result of the percentage calculations shall be rounded off to the nearest whole number (0.5 or greater = one tree). Trees to be planted shall be selected from a list of trees as contained in section 58-327 or as approved by the city manager or designee. All trees shall be installed in a planting area of at least 25 square feet, with a minimum dimension of eight feet, excluding any curbing. Planters must provide a minimum planting medium/soil depth of four feet and a minimum bottom width of three times the tree root ball diameter. 
(6)  A maximum of ten percent of the required canopy trees may be substituted with palms at a ratio of 3:1. A maximum of 30 percent of all required accent trees may be substituted with palm at a ratio of 2:1. Palms shall have a minimum of ten feet of clear trunk at planting and at a minimum be clustered in pairs. Palms to be planted shall be selected from section 58-327 or as approved by the city manager or designee. 
(7)  The front yard setback area for all zoning districts must be landscaped and maintained. This area may not be treated as a left-over or unmaintained area. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-325. - Maintenance of required landscaping—Nonresidential and residential properties. 
(a)  The owner, tenant and their agent, if any, shall be jointly and severally responsible for the maintenance of all landscaping, which shall be maintained in good condition so as to present a healthy, neat and orderly appearance and shall be kept free from refuse and debris. Plant materials and trees shall be maintained so as to grow in an upright manner perpendicular to the ground. Water supply shall be piped to each individual planter island, and in no case shall any landscaped area be more than 50 feet from a water supply hose bib. These requirements shall apply to all landscaping, drainage retention areas, and common areas required to be installed on nonresidential properties as part of an approved site plan, irrespective of whether or not the site plan was approved by the county and the property was subsequently annexed by the city, or as approved by the city. The city shall have the right to require the property owner to replace or reinstall plant material that was required as part of a site plan and landscape approval, development order or development permit for any plant material that is diseased, or which has died or otherwise been removed. Removal of dead or diseased trees will require tree replacement equivalent to the dbh size of trees to be removed or tree replacement mitigation pursuant to chapter 62, section 62-36 or other replacement alternative as approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Tree topping. It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any property owner or landscape maintenance firm to top any required landscape tree. Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from this ordinance at the determination of the city manager or city manager designee. Crown reduction is different than topping and is a recognized pruning procedure referenced in the American National Standards Institute (ANSI-A-300 Standards) that can be used to reduce the height or width of a tree per the requirements. 
(c)  Pruning and corner clearance. Every owner of any tree overhanging any street or right-of-way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear space of 13 feet, six inches above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs, which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The city shall have the right to prune any tree or shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or interferes with sight visibility of any traffic control device or sign. 
(d)  When pruning lateral branches of a required tree, the proper pruning techniques, as specified by the ANSI A300 Part 1: Tree, Shrub and Other Woody Plant Maintenance - Standard Practices (pruning) must be followed. Flush cuts (pruning cuts that remove the branch collar) and stub cuts (pruning cuts that leave a limb stub) are improper pruning techniques and are prohibited. 
(e)  Any tree that has been topped or improperly pruned will not be recognized as a tree left in a healthy growing condition and consequently will not meet approval by the city towards meeting landscape buffer or tree replacement requirements. Such tree(s) shall be subject to tree replacement requirements pursuant to this article. 
(f)  A tree removal permit is required for the removal of any required tree(s) and/or palm(s) pursuant to the approved landscape plan and this article. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-326. - Irrigation. 
All landscaped areas shall be provided with a non-potable water supply for the irrigation system. If a landscaped area contains primarily species native to the immediate region, Florida-Friendly drought tolerant plants, or plants acceptable for xeric landscaping, the city manager or city manager designee, as applicable, may waive the requirement for installation of a non-potable irrigation system. Consideration of a waiver of the irrigation requirement shall include, in addition to the area covered by native vegetation, such local conditions as sun or shade, use of fill soil, and depth to water table. New irrigation systems require a rain sensor device which will override the timing cycle when adequate rainfall has occurred. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-327. - Acceptable and prohibited landscape materials. 
The following is a list of plant material that may be used to fulfill the requirements of this article. Other plant materials may be used subject to approval by the city manager or city manager designee. On development sites of one or more acres, required landscaping shall provide for the planting of at least two different species of canopy/large tree and accent tree. 
(1)  Approved plant materials list:

( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-328. - Existing vegetation. 
Existing plant materials that conform to the requirements of this article may be used to satisfy minimum landscape requirements. However, existing invasive species must be removed at the time of site development or redevelopment. Where existing mature tree canopy precludes meeting the perimeter or interior requirements of this article, the city manager or designee may grant administrative relief from said provisions. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-329. - Perimeter landscaping and buffering requirements. 
Where possible, a minimum of 25 percent of the native vegetation on-site should be preserved and incorporated into the following landscape requirements. The exterior (property line) perimeters of a development site or lot providing a vehicular use area or any nonresidential use abutting a residential use, or multi-family use abutting a single-family use shall be entirely screened visually from abutting property or right-of-way. Fractions of required landscaping shall be rounded off to the nearest whole number (0.5 or greater = one tree/palm/planter island). The following standards shall apply: 
(1)  One canopy tree shall be provided for every 50 linear feet of frontage, or fraction thereof, except where such planting would conflict or interfere with underground or overhead utilities. In such cases, pursuant to this article, accent trees and/or palms may be substituted for required canopy trees pursuant to section 58-324. Trees shall be located between the common lot line and the adjacent nonresidential or residential use off-street parking area or other vehicular use area within a minimum five-foot wide buffer strip with wheel stops set back two and one-half feet from curb (see Exhibit A). Where a parking lot is located along the property perimeter, for every eight parking spaces and at the terminus of a row of parking spaces there shall be created planter islands. Each required planter island shall be a minimum of nine feet wide and 18 feet deep and planted with a canopy tree. Along the development site and/or vehicular use perimeter there shall also be landscaping with two or more accent trees and a continuous row of shrubs as shown in landscape standard A; or 
a.  Where a development site or vehicular use area perimeter or nonresidential or multi-family structure fronts along a major gateway street, the minimum buffer width, excluding any curbing, shall be ten feet. No wheel stops required (see Exhibit A). 
b.  Where a nonresidential use abuts a single-family residential zoned property a minimum eight-foot wide buffer is required. 
(2)  A wall with a continuous hedge, berm with hedge, or combination thereof, not greater than eight feet in height nor less than four feet in height, to form a continuous screen is required between all vehicular use areas and adjacent residential property. At the discretion of the city manager or city manager designee, landscaping may be required to be located on the residential or street side of the wall. 
(3)  Canopy trees should be located in such a manner that at maturity the tree should not conflict with freestanding signage. 
(4)  Any new single-family house abutting a public or private street shall plant at least one canopy tree within the required front yard setback area, except where such planting would conflict or interfere with underground or overhead utilities. In such cases, pursuant to this article, accent trees and/or palms may be substituted for required canopy trees pursuant to section 58-324. 
(5)  Mitigation in the form of a payment in lieu of, as established by the City, may be considered by the city manager or city manager designee, as a substitute for the installation of required landscaping, in those areas where required landscaping installation has been determined by the city manager or city manager designee, as not being feasible or practical to meet the requirements of this section. 
Landscape Standard A 
Perimeter buffer requirement: 
Plant material/50 linear feet of frontage. 
One canopy tree. 
Two accent trees. 
Continuous row of shrubs. 
 
 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-330. - Perimeter landscaping and buffering requirements—Exceptions. 
(a)  Exceptions from the landscaping and buffer requirements of section 58-329 are as follows: 
(1)  When a nonresidential or multi-family use property line abuts a dedicated alley or those portions of the property that are opposite a building or other structure located on the abutting residential property, no buffer is required on the nonresidential use property. The existing alley must be platted or a dedicated easement for vehicle traffic and be a minimum 15 feet wide. 
(2)  A nonresidential or multi-family use may receive credit for an existing buffer which is located on an adjacent residential or nonresidential property. 
(3)  Where the abutting property is zoned or used for nonresidential uses, only the canopy tree and shrub provisions shall apply within a five-foot wide planter island (see Exhibit A). 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-331. - Interior vehicular use area landscaping requirements. 
(a)  An area or a combination of areas, equal to ten percent of the total vehicular use area exclusive of the perimeter landscape buffers required under sections 58-329 and 58-330, shall be devoted to interior landscaping (see Exhibit A). Any perimeter landscaping area provided in excess of that required by sections 58-329 and 58-330 may be counted as part of the interior landscaping requirement. There shall be a minimum of one canopy tree for each 400 square feet or fraction thereof of the required landscaped area. Up to 50 percent of this requirement may be satisfied using accent trees (clustered in pairs of two) or palms (clustered in pairs of three). Planters shall be located to most effectively relieve the monotony of large expenses of paving and contribute to the orderly circulation of vehicular and pedestrian traffic as illustrated in Exhibit A. 
(b)  Landscaping (trees/palms) provided around a structure or structures on the same parcel of land, may count toward meeting the interior requirement. 
(c)  Multi-family housing development and nonresidential development must provide a planter island for every eight parking spaces and at the end of each row of parking. Each planter island shall be a minimum of nine feet by 18 feet and planted with one canopy tree. An alternative to providing an island for every eight spaces is to provide a nine-foot wide planter median with wheel-stops or ten-foot wide island without wheel-stops (see Exhibit A). 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-332. - Open space and stormwater pond landscaping requirements. 
(a)  Required open space areas shall be landscaped with one canopy tree or two accent trees for each 2,000 square feet of open space area. 
(b)  Stormwater ponds located adjacent to public right-of-way or private property shall be landscaped along the top of the bank or slope with one canopy tree spaced every 50 feet or two accent trees spaced every 25 feet. Pond slopes shall be planted with grass and/or plants as recommended by the Southwest Florida Water Management District. Any fencing along the pond perimeter shall be decorative PVC fencing or black or green vinyl coated chain link fencing. 
(c)  No more than 50 percent of the required use perimeter buffer area and/or parking lot perimeter buffer, shall be utilized for a stormwater pond(s), provided the buffer planting requirement is met along the top of the bank. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-333. - Nonconformities to landscape buffers and vehicular use area landscaping requirements. 
(a)  An existing development that does not comply with the requirements of this article must be brought into full compliance when one of the following occurs: 
(1)  Twenty-five percent or more of the site building square footage is increased. 
(2)  Fifty percent or more of the existing building square footage is converted to a use that triggers a greater parking requirement. 
(3)  Fifty percent of the vehicular use area is replaced or demolished. 
(4)  Site and/or building renovations (exterior) exceed 51 percent of the most current assessed value of the property (building(s) and land) per the county property appraiser records; or 
(5)  Pursuant to compliance required by chapter 50. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Secs. 58-334—58-365. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SUBDIVISIONS, STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 58-366. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Improve means any procedure, administrative, technical and/or physical required in order to grade, construct, reconstruct, repair, build or rebuild, alter, extend or open streets, sidewalks, avenues, alleys and thoroughfares; to remove encroachments, obstructions, building, ruins, trees or poles; to construct, maintain or repair storm and drainage sewers; to construct, reconstruct, pave or repave, hard-surface or rehard-surface, widen, gutter and drain existing or new streets, avenues, cul-de-sacs, parking areas, and sidewalks, including the necessary appurtenances thereto. 
Maintain means to hold, keep or continue in a condition or state of repair satisfactory to the city manager or designee and subject to sound engineering judgment and economic feasibility. 
Maintenance means the necessary procedures, administrative technical or physical, required in order to maintain. 
New means a street, avenue, cul-de-sac, thoroughfare, sidewalk, parking area, or alley not previously platted or constructed. 
Property owner means freeholders of improved or unimproved real property only. Multiple owners of single parcels or individual owners of multiple parcels shall be considered one petitioner. 
Rebuild means to reconstruct to minimum standards a street, avenue, cul-de-sac, thoroughfare, sidewalk, parking area, or alley, that has reached a state of deterioration that indicates its further repair or maintenance is not feasible to sound engineering and economic judgment. 
Repair means to restore to a safe condition limited surface areas of streets, avenues, and cul-de-sacs that may have become unsafe or deteriorated due to normal wear and tear by usage or erosion and not due to groundwater conditions by such means or methods as may be considered by the city satisfactory when subject to sound engineering judgment and economic feasibility. 
Solar energy system means a solar collection (such as solar panels) or other device or structural design feature of a structure that relies upon sunshine as an energy source and is capable of collecting, distributing and storing the sun's radiant energy to use for water heating, space heating or cooling, electrical power and/or other applications. 
Solar-oriented lot shall mean: 
(1)  A lot with a front lot line oriented to within 30 degrees of a true east-west line. When the lot line abutting a street is curved, the "front lot line" shall mean the chord or straight line connecting the ends of the curve. For a flag lot, the "front lot line" shall mean the lot line that is most parallel to the closest street, excluding the "pole portion of the flag lot"; or 
(2)  A lot which, when a straight line is drawn from a point midway between the side lot lines at the required front yard setback to a point midway between the side lot lines at the required rear yard setback, is oriented to within 30 degrees of true north along said line; or 
(3)  A corner lot with a south lot line oriented to within 30 degrees of a true east-west line, which south lot line adjoins a public street or permanently reserved open space; provided, however, that the abutting street right-of-way has a minimum north-south dimension of at least 50 feet. 
Used for includes "designed for." 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-367. - Minimum street, sidewalk and landscaping standards. 
(a)  The minimum design standards for streets, avenues or cul-de-sacs shall be in substantial correspondence with the standards of the FDOT manual of uniform minimum standards for design, construction and maintenance for streets and highways, as amended. 
(1)  Pavement width. Local residential streets shall be constructed to a minimum width of 24 feet, including width of curbing or valley gutter. Local commercial streets shall have a minimum width of 30 feet, unless less width is recommended by the city engineer and approved by the city manager or designee. 
(2)  Base construction. Bases for local residential streets shall be a minimum of six inches compacted thickness of shell or limerock. Other base materials may be considered upon request providing supporting evidence of adequacy accompanies the request. A greater base thickness may be required for streets that may be placed in a higher classification by the city council. 
(3)  Subbase construction. Subbase shall be of a good clean acceptable material, nine inches compacted thickness, having a minimum Florida bearing value of 60 pounds at 95 percent of maximum density per square inch. Subbase shall extend a minimum of six inches beyond back of concrete curb or valley gutter. 
(4)  Private street. Private streets must be approved by the city manager, or designee, as to specification, type of construction, width, etc. 
(5)  Pavement surfaces. Pavement surfaces shall be a minimum of one-and-one-half-inch-thick asphaltic concrete surface course, or as directed by the city. 
(6)  Pavement crown. All pavement crowns shall be sloped at one-quarter inch per foot or greater. Finish pavement shall be from one-quarter inch to one-half inch higher than the lip of the adjacent concrete gutter. 
(7)  Sidewalks. Consideration for future installation of sidewalks shall be given in designing the grade of newly constructed pavements. 
(8)  Gutters. Concrete valley gutters shall have a width of 24 inches, a minimum thickness of six inches at the center, and a one-inch rise to the edge of pavement. A minimum rise of three inches to the back of the gutter is required. Three thousand pounds per square inch concrete shall be used. 
(9)  Drainage. New streets and streets being rebuilt shall be drained by concrete valley gutters along the length of the pavement. They shall have a minimum longitudinal grade of 0.3 percent, and inlets shall be placed at all sags and at intermediate points as dictated by an analysis of the drainage conditions. Inlets shall be served by an adequate storm sewer system designed to conduct flow to a suitable outlet. Complete drainage plans shall be developed showing incremental and total areas drained, runoff factors, storm frequency, design rainfall intensity, expected total flows and capacity of each element of the storm sewer system. Subsurface drainage using pipe underdrains shall be installed unless adequate studies of groundwater conditions show they are not necessary. 
(10)  Shoulders. Shoulders must be stabilized and sodded according to specifications approved by the city manager or designee. 
(11)  Driveways. In cases of new building construction, driveways must be paved in an acceptable manner in accordance with specifications approved by the city manager or designee up to the property line. 
(b)  The minimum standards established in this article shall be applied only when constructing new streets, avenues and cul-de-sacs, and whenever it is necessary as determined by the city manager or designee to completely rebuild existing streets, avenues and cul-de-sacs. 
(c)  The minimum standards established in this article shall be applied only when constructing new streets, avenues and cul-de-sacs and whenever it is necessary as determined by the city manager or designee to completely rebuild existing streets, avenues and cul-de-sacs. 
(d)  Upon the recommendation of the public works director and approval by the city manager, or designee, may approve a lessening of the minimum standards where circumstances and economics justify same. 
(e)  No street, avenue or cul-de-sac shall be required to be brought to minimum standard if it can be maintained economically as determined by the city manager or designee. 
(f)  Any new single-family house abutting a public or private street shall plant at least one canopy tree within the required front yard setback area, except where such planting would conflict or interfere with underground or overhead utilities. In such cases, pursuant to article V of this chapter, accent trees and/or palms may be substituted for required canopy trees pursuant to section 58-324. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-368. - Subdivision and platting design standards. 
(a)  Subdivision standards for residential and commercial developments, except as required by this article, shall comply with F.S. ch. 177. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-369. - Subdivision standards for solar energy systems. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the city's intent to encourage the use of both active and passive solar energy systems for heating air and water and providing electrical power in homes and businesses, as long as natural topography, soil or other subsurface conditions or other natural conditions peculiar to the site are preserved. While the use of solar energy systems is optional, the right to solar access should be protected. Solar collectors require access to available sunshine during the entire year, including between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., EST, on December 21, when the longest shadows occur. Additionally, a goal of this section is to ensure that site plan elements do not excessively shade adjacent properties, creating a significant adverse impact upon adjacent property owners. Thus, standards are set forth to evaluate the potential impact of shade caused by buildings, structures and trees. 
(b)  Solar-oriented residential lots. Lots less than 15,000 square feet in area in single and two-family residential developments should conform to the definition of a "solar-oriented lot" in order to preserve the potential for solar energy usage. 
(c)  Access to sunshine. 
(1)  The elements of the development plan (e.g., buildings, circulation, open space, and landscaping) shall be located and designed to the maximum extent feasible, to protect access to sunshine for planned solar energy systems or for solar-oriented rooftop surfaces that can support a solar collector or collectors capable of providing for the anticipated electrical and hot water needs of the buildings in the project between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m. EST, on December 21. 
(2)  Solar access easements should be established pursuant to F.S. § 704.07 to protect a property's solar access rights. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-370. - Engineering for assessment related improvements. 
(a)  All plans for street or drainage improvements shall be prepared by a licensed professional engineer of the state and submitted to the city council for approval prior to calling for bids. They shall be accompanied by an engineering estimate of the total cost of the project, unit cost of the materials and labor, total assessable footage, assessable footage of each property to be benefited, and the unit assessment cost. 
(b)  Specifications for materials and methods of construction shall conform to the latest edition of the state department of transportation specifications for road and bridge construction. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)  
Sec. 58-371. - Procedures for assessment related improvements. 
(a)  An undertaking may be initiated by the city council when: 
(1)  It is deemed necessary in the interest of the health, welfare and safety of the owners and/or users of abutting property or of property to be benefited in any given area within the city limits; or, 
(2)  The city council receives a petition signed by owners of more than 50 percent of the lands of abutting property in any given area within the city limits requesting that the improvement, maintenance or repair be undertaken. 
(b)  In all such undertakings, the city council shall determine and record whether such undertaking is to be assessed. When the city council determines that the costs of an undertaking or a portion thereof are to be assessed, the method for levying and collecting such assessment shall be in accordance with state statutes, and accompanying resolutions. It shall be the policy of the city to assess property owners on each side of the street improvements, who shall pay 30 percent of the total of all of the cost associated with the improvements on a linear footage basis, with the city assuming the balance of 70 percent of the cost of the improvements. 
( Ord. No. 24-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 11-25-14)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 14, 2014, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, § 62-1, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1991, § 5.00.00. 
 
Sec. 62-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to establish those resources or areas of a development site that must be protected from harmful effects of development. A developer should apply the provisions of this chapter to a proposed development site before any other development design work is done. Application of the provisions of this chapter will divide a proposed development site into areas that may be developed and areas that must generally be left free of development activity. The proposed development should then be designed to fit within the areas that may be developed. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Secs. 62-2—62-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TREE PROTECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), adopted Oct. 14, 2014, amended Art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. II, §§ 62-31—62-40, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1991, §§ 5.01.01—5.01.09; Ord. No. 25-2001, 10-9-01. 
 
Sec. 62-31. - Intent. 
Trees are declared to be a natural public resource. It is the intent of the city to protect them as set out in this article in the interest of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of this city. To that end, it shall be unlawful to cut down, damage by topping or improper pruning, poison or in any other manner destroy or cause to be destroyed any trees as covered by the terms of this article except in accordance with all the provisions of this article. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-32. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accent tree means a species of tree which grows to a typical mature height of less than 30 feet and whose natural form is a narrow or oval shape as opposed to a broad canopy shape. 
Commercial nursery or tree farm means a licensed plant or tree nursery or farm in relation to those trees planted and growing on the premises of the licensee, which are so planted and growing for the sale or intended sale to the general public in the ordinary course of the licensee's business. 
Diameter at breast height (dbh) means the diameter of a tree measured at a point four and one-half feet in height from the base of the tree at grade level. 
Drip line means an imaginary, perpendicular line that extends downward from the outermost tips of the tree branches to the ground. 
Protected tree means any tree listed as a native tree, excluding palms, by the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences or as listed in chapter 58, article V. 
Protective barrier means a physical structure limiting access to a protected area, composed of wooden or other suitable materials that assures compliance with the intent of this article. 
Remove or removal means the actual removal by digging up or cutting down, or the effective removal through damage or other means. 
Transplant means the digging up by a property owner of a tree from one place on his property and the planting of the same tree in another place on the same property. 
Tree means any self-supporting, woody plant that normally grows to a minimum height of 15 feet or greater with a mature crown spread of 15 feet or greater and having trunks that can be maintained with over five feet of clear wood. Mangroves shall be considered trees and palms are not defined as trees. 
Tree survey means an aerial photograph or drawing at no more than a scale of 1" = 200' which provides the location of all trees protected under the provisions of this article, plotted by accurate techniques, common and botanical name of all trees, consecutively numbered and calibrated by dbh. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-33. - Permit required—Small tracts. 
(a)  On platted lots or tracts of less than one acre in area, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed any protected tree, except exempt trees, with a trunk dbh of four inches or more without first having a tree removal permit to do so as provided in this article. 
(b)  On approved nonresidential or multi-family development landscape plans, no tree or palm shown on the approved landscape plan shall be removed without first obtaining a tree removal permit. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-34. - Permit required—Large tracts. 
(a)  On any platted or unplatted tract of one acre or more in area, it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause to be removed any protected tree, except exempt trees, with a trunk dbh of four inches or more, without first having obtained a tree removal permit to do so as provided in this article. 
(b)  On approved nonresidential, multi-family or single-family subdivision development landscape plans, no tree or palm shown on the approved landscape plan shall be removed without first obtaining a tree removal permit. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-35. - Protected and exempt trees. 
(a)  Protected species. All species commonly known as mangroves (Avicennia germinans, black mangrove; Laguncularia racemosa, white mangrove; Rhizophora mangle, red mangrove; Conocarpus erectus, buttonwood) of whatever size, as well as the species Quercus Virginiana (live oak) and Quercus laurifolia (laurel oak), of four-inch dbh or greater, and any other protected tree species, except exempt trees, 20-inch dbh or greater are recognized to be of special ecological value. No mangrove tree, live oak or laurel oak or any other protected tree species 20-inch dbh or greater shall be removed without a tree removal permit and a report prepared by a certified arborist, provided by the permittee, regarding the current condition of the tree(s) and specific reason(s) for removal. Where, in the opinion of the city manager or designee, a large numbers of protected trees less than 20-inch dbh are proposed to be removed, a report prepared by a certified arborist regarding the current condition of the tree(s) and specific reasons for removal may be required to be submitted with the permit application. 
(b)  Mangroves exempt from survey. Due to the vegetative characteristics of mangroves, they will be exempt from the tree survey requirement; but no other permitting procedures will nullify the requirements of this article, including site plan review. 
(c)  Commercial nursery/tree farm. The terms and provisions of this article shall not apply to a commercial nursery or tree farm. 
(d)  Exempt trees. Specifically exempt from the terms and provisions of this article are the following species of nuisance trees: 
(1)  Melaleuca quinquenervia (punk). 
(2)  Enterolobium cyclocarpum (ear). 
(3)  Melia azedarach (chinaberry tree). 
(4)  Jacaranda mimosifolia (jacaranda tree). 
(5)  Schinus terebinthifolius (Brazilian pepper). 
(6)  Casuarina equisetifolia (Australian pine). 
(7)  Cinnamomum camphora (Camphor). 
(8)  Sapium sebiferum (Chinese tallow tree). 
The above list shall be supplemented by exotic and/or invasive plant species that are determined to be noxious, invasive, cause environmental degradation to native habitats, or to be detrimental to human health, safety or the public welfare by the city manager or designee and/or as identified by the University of Florida Center for Aquatic and Invasive Plants. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-36. - Reforestation. 
(a)  Reforestation required. As a condition for the issuance of a permit under the provisions of this land development code, the city manager or designee may require that the owner of the property either relocate or replace any trees with comparable substitutes within designated areas of the property. The permittee may be required to replace the tree(s) based on a minimum dbh or caliper size and height and/or pay a mitigation fee on the tree(s) proposed to be removed on a per dbh inch basis. The city shall establish the basis for the per dbh inch mitigation fee to compute the total cost of mitigation for each protected tree species proposed to be removed. No tree which has been planted as a replacement under the provisions of this section may be removed without a tree removal permit, regardless of size. No mitigation fee will be assessed where a report prepared by a certified arborist has determined the protected tree is diseased, dead, in a severe state of decline or poses a public safety threat. However, tree replacement may be required. 
(b)  Replacement species. A list of suggested tree replacement species is available upon request; the trees on this list were selected from the viewpoint of hardiness, disease and pest resistance, availability, and size. It is not the intent to limit acceptable species, but rather to provide adequate guidelines. However, in no case shall single-trunk palms or cluster palms (at a replacement ratio of 3:1) and/or accent trees (at a replacement ratio of 2:1) constitute more than 20 percent of the total number of required replacement trees. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-37. - Protection during construction. 
(a)  Area of protection. It shall be unlawful for any person in the construction of any structures or improvements to place material, machinery or temporary soil deposits within six feet or two-thirds of the drip line, whichever distance is greater, of any tree having a dbh of four-inches or greater. 
(b)  Barriers required. Before development, demolition, excavation, land clearing or any other land alterations that may affect the health of existing trees, the developer shall be required to erect suitable protective barriers; further, these barriers shall remain until such time as they are authorized to be removed. During construction, no wires or attachments of any kind shall be affixed to any of these trees. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-38. - Emergencies. 
In the case of emergencies such as hurricane, windstorm, flood, freeze or other disasters or hazards, the requirements of this division may be waived by the city manager or designee upon a finding that such waiver is necessary so that public or private work to restore order in the community will not be impeded. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-39. - Public right-of-way. 
No trees shall be removed from the public right-of-way except under the direction of the city manager or designee. 
( Ord. No. 09-2014 , § 2(Exh. A), 10-14-14)  
Sec. 62-40. - Creation and establishment of a tree advisory committee. 
There is hereby created and established a tree advisory committee for the city, which shall consist of five members, who shall be appointed by the mayor and council. 
(1)  Duties and responsibilities. It shall be the responsibility of the tree advisory committee to develop and/or update, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, pruning, planting, replanting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in parks, along streets and in other public areas. The tree advisory committee shall consider, investigate, make finding, report and recommend upon any special matter of question coming within the scope of its work. 
(2)  Term of office. The term of the five persons to be appointed by the mayor and council shall be three years. In the event that a vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be appointed for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(3)  Compensation. Members of the tree advisory committee shall serve without compensation. 
(4)  Definitions. 
Park trees mean trees, shrubs, bushes and all other woody vegetation in public parks having individual names, and all areas owned by the city, or to which the public has free access as a park. 
Street trees mean trees, shrubs, bushes, and all other woody vegetation on land lying between property lines on either side of all streets, avenues, or ways within the city. 
(5)  Operation. The tree advisory committee shall choose its own officers, governed by Robert's Rules, and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members shall be a quorum for the transaction of business.
