(d)  All decisions shall be mailed, transmitted electronically, or hand delivered to the applicant. A record shall be kept of the date of mailing, electronic transmittal, or hand delivery. For the purposes of calculating compliance with the 30-day deadline for a decision upon an application or the seven day deadline for a decision upon request for reconsideration, the decision shall be deemed made when deposited in the mail, transmitted electronically, or hand delivered to the applicant. 
(e)  As exceptions to the foregoing, the 30-day deadline for approval and the seven-day deadline for a decision upon receipt of a request for a reconsideration shall not apply (that is, the time shall be suspended): 
(1)  In any case in which the application requires a variance from any provision of the City Code of Ordinances, a rezoning of the property, or an amendment to the comprehensive plan of the city. In such cases, the time shall be suspended until a final decision is made upon the application for the variance, rezoning, or comprehensive plan amendment. 
(2)  If the applicant is required to make any change to the application in order to obtain an unconditional approval, the time shall be suspended while the applicant makes such change. 
(3)  If an applicant is required to obtain an approval from any other governmental agency, the time shall be suspended until such approval is obtained. 
(4)  In any of the foregoing cases, the applicant may elect to seek a variance, make no change to the application, or obtain no approval that may be required by another governmental agency, and may instead demand a decision upon the sign permit application as filed. In such event, the city manager or designee shall make a decision on the application as appropriate within five business days after receiving such demand. If a decision is not made in such a time, the application shall be deemed denied and the city manager or designee shall verify that any applicable fee was refunded to the person who paid the fee. 
(5)  An application which is materially incomplete or which is not accompanied by the required fee shall not be deemed accepted and the time for review of the application shall not commence until a complete application accompanied by the required fee is filed with the city manager or designee. However, the city manager or designee shall keep the record of incomplete application or any application not accompanied by the correct fee, as required by applicable public record laws. In addition, the city manager or designee shall within 30 days of receipt of such an application send the applicant a written explanation of the deficiencies in the application and ask that the deficiencies be remedied, explaining that the application can not proceed forward otherwise and the review will be suspended pending receipt of the required information or documentation. The applicant must then submit a new application with the deficiencies corrected in order for it to be considered by the city manager or designee. 
(f)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager or designee upon his or her sign permit application shall have the right to seek judicial review by the Circuit Court of the Sixth Judicial Circuit and for Pinellas County, Florida, or any other court of competent jurisdiction, filed in accordance with the requirements of law, seeking such appropriate remedy as may be available. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-71. - Sign permit fees. 
Before issuance of a permit, the building official or his designee shall collect the necessary sign permit fees. The sign permit fees shall be as designated by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-72. - Inspection. 
The building official and the director of community development or their designees may make or require any inspections to ascertain compliance with the provisions of this chapter, the land development code, and other laws. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-73. - Revocation of sign permit. 
If the work under any sign permit is proceeding in violation of this chapter, any other ordinance of the city, or should it be found that there has been any false statement or misrepresentation of a material fact in the application or plans on which the permit was based, the permit holder shall be notified of the violation. If the permit holder fails or refuses to make corrections within ten days, it shall be the duty of the building official or his designee to revoke such permit and serve notice upon such permit holder. Such notice shall be in writing and signed by the building official or his designee. It shall be unlawful for any person to proceed with any part of work after such notice is issued. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-74. - Miscellaneous safety requirements. 
In addition to any requirement of this chapter, Code, or other law or regulatory provision, signs shall be erected and maintained to conform to the following safety requirements. 
(1)  No sign shall be erected so as to obstruct any fire escape, required exit, window, or door opening intended as a means of egress. 
(2)  No sign shall be erected which interferes with any opening required for ventilation. 
(3)  Signs shall maintain a minimum of six feet horizontal and twelve feet vertical clearance from electrical conductors and from all communications equipment or lines located within the city. 
(4)  Signs and their supporting structures shall maintain clearance and noninterference with all surface and underground facilities and conduits for water, sewage, electricity, or communications equipment or lines. Furthermore, placement shall not interfere with natural or artificial drainage or surface or underground water. 
(5)  No sign shall be attached to a standpipe, gutter, drain, or fire escape, nor shall any sign be installed so as to impair access to a roof. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-75. - Appeals to developmental review board. 
(a)  Whenever it is alleged that there has been an error in any order, action, decision, determination, or requirement by an administrative official in the enforcement and application of any provision contained within this chapter or any other provision of this Code pertaining to sign permits (including any allegation that an administrative official has failed to act within applicable time frames), the aggrieved party may file a written appeal with the developmental review board. 
(b)  The written appeal shall be filed with the developmental review board within 30 days of the date of the alleged error. The written appeal shall describe the alleged error and the applicable provisions of the Code pertaining to the administrative official's order, action, decision, determination, requirement, or failure to act. 
(c)  The developmental review board shall hold a hearing within 45 days following receipt of the written appeal, not counting the day of receipt and not counting any Saturday, Sunday, or legal holiday which falls upon the first or the forty-fifth day after the date of receipt. 
(d)  The developmental review board shall render a written decision within ten days following the hearing. 
(e)  If the developmental review board does not render a decision within ten days following the hearing, the sign permit shall be deemed denied. 
(f)  Failure to appeal the decision regarding a sign application by the city manager or designee shall not be deemed a failure to exhaust administrative remedies. The applicant may choose to proceed directly to a judicial action once the sign application has been denied by the city manager or designee. 
(g)  If an administrative appeal is filed by the applicant, and the developmental review board fails to meet within the proscribed time the appeal will be deemed denied and the decision of the city manager or designee regarding the sign application will be deemed a final decision subject to immediate appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(h)  Once a decision is appealed to the developmental review board the city manager, or designee, shall take no further action on the matter pending the board's decision, except for unsafe signs which shall present an immediate and serious danger to the public in which case the city may pursue any proper legal remedy available to it. 
(i)  The developmental review board shall comply with all applicable rules of conduct and procedures that pertain to zoning and that are not inconsistent with the provisions in this chapter. 
(j)  No variance shall be given by the developmental review board to any height, size or other dimensional criteria set forth in this article. No variance shall be given by the developmental review board with regard to the number of signs allowed on any parcel of land as set forth in this article. A variance may be given by the developmental review board with regard to the required setback. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-76. - Appellate decisions deemed final, subject to judicial review. 
The appellate decisions of the developmental review board pursuant to section 66-75 above, shall be deemed final, subject to judicial review by a Circuit Court of the Sixth Judicial Circuit in and for Pinellas County, Florida, filed in accordance with the requirements of law, seeking such appropriate remedy as may be available. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-77—66-125. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NONCONFORMING SIGNS 
 
Sec. 66-126. - Generally. 
Consistent with the public policy to restrict and eventually eliminate nonconforming uses and structures, it is the policy of the city that nonconforming signs shall be brought into conformity or removed as expeditiously as possible while allowing such signs to be maintained in the interim. A nonconforming sign that was lawfully erected may continue to be maintained and used, until the earlier of such time in which any of the following occurs: (a) The sign meets the definition of an abandoned or discontinued sign; or, (b) The sign is substantially damaged or destroyed in excess of 51 percent of its value; or, (c) The real property on which the sign is located is redeveloped; or, (d) The principal structure on the real property on which the sign is located is demolished in excess of 51 percent of its value as determined by the property appraisers office; or, (e) The property owner chooses to replace the entire sign. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-127. - Nonconforming signs, specific regulation 
In addition to any requirement of this chapter, a nonconforming sign shall be regulated as follows: 
(1)  Unsafe nonconforming sign. Any nonconforming sign or portion thereof declared to be unsafe by the building official shall only be restored in full compliance with the requirements of this chapter and the Florida Building Code. 
(2)  Alteration of a nonconforming sign. A nonconforming sign may be maintained and repairs may be made thereon, in accordance with the definition of "sign maintenance" as contained in this chapter. The changing of sign copy or sign face is permitted. However, no change or alteration to an existing CEVM component, or the addition of a new CEVM component where one does not currently exist, shall be permitted. 
(3)  Extension of a nonconforming. A sign that is nonconforming shall not be increased in area, extended or enlarged so as to encompass additional area. 
(4)  Abandonment of a nonconforming sign. When a nonconforming sign meets the definition of an "abandoned or discontinued sign or sign structure" as defined in this chapter, any future use of the sign shall conform to the requirements of this chapter. 
(5)  Restoration of a nonconforming sign. A nonconforming sign damaged or destroyed in excess of 51 percent of its value, by any means, method or event may not be reconstructed or restored for use except in compliance with the requirements of this chapter and the Florida Building Code. 
(6)  Structural conversion of a nonconforming sign. Sections of this division shall not apply to any construction, structural alteration, extension, addition or repair where such work, as proposed, would convert a nonconforming sign into a sign that conforms with all the pertinent requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 09-2011, § 1, 4-26-11)  
Secs. 66-128—66-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - REGULATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - ALL DISTRICTS 
 
Sec. 66-161. - Regulations that apply in every zoning district in the city, except where otherwise specified or indicated. 
Sign permits are not required for signs and sign-types described and identified below in this subsection. 
(1)  Street address signs and residential mailboxes. For each parcel within the city, one attached wall street address sign may be displayed. For parcels in residential use, the street address sign shall not exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. For each parcel in non-residential use, the street address sign shall not exceed four square feet in sign area. In addition to street address signs, a residential mailbox with the address of the property affixed to it such that the address is no larger than one side of the mailbox shall be allowed for each residence in the city. 
(2)  Nameplate or occupant identification signs. For each residence, business or other occupancy within the city, one attached wall nameplate sign may be displayed. For residences the nameplate or occupant identification signs shall not exceed two (2) square feet in sign area. For any non-residential use, the nameplate or occupant identification sign shall not exceed four square feet in sign area. 
(3)  Non-commercial onsite parking space signs. Non-commercial onsite parking space number or identification signs, not exceeding one square foot of sign face per sign, shall be allowed on each parcel in non-commercial use having multiple parking spaces onsite. One such sign shall be allowed for each parking space. The maximum height for a freestanding or attached wall sign shall be six feet unless otherwise required by applicable law. 
(4)  Free expression signs. For each parcel within the city, one free expression sign not exceeding three square feet in sign area may be displayed on each frontage per parcel of land. The free expression sign may be displayed as an attached sign, window sign, or as a freestanding sign; if displayed as a freestanding sign, the free- standing sign shall not exceed three feet in height. A free expression sign is in addition to any other sign permitted under this Code and is permitted in any zoning district. Only one such sign shall be permitted on each parcel. 
(5)  Election signs. For each parcel within the city, election signs candidates or issues may be displayed on each frontage per parcel of land. Election signs may be displayed as an attached sign or as a freestanding sign. On parcels that are in residential use, election signs shall not exceed six square feet in sign area; and, if the election signs are displayed as freestanding signs on the parcel, the election signs shall not exceed six feet in height. On parcels that are in non-residential use, the election signs shall not exceed 32 square feet in sign area; and, if the election signs are displayed as freestanding signs on the parcel, the election signs shall not exceed six feet in height. Election signs shall be removed within seven calendar days following the election to which it pertains. 
(6)  Artwork. Artwork is allowed in all districts. 
(7)  Flagpoles. One flagpole is allowed for each parcel. Flagpoles shall not exceed the maximum permitted height of the zoning district for the parcel on which the flagpole is located. 
(8)  Flags-government/public. There shall be a maximum of three government/public flags permitted on each lot within any zoning district. The flags shall be flown according to protocol established by the Congress of the United States of America for the Stars & Stripes. 
(9)  Warning signs and safety signs. Warning signs and safety signs, not exceeding four square feet in sign area, shall be allowed in all districts. The maximum height for these signs shall be six feet unless otherwise required by applicable law. 
(10)  Machinery and equipment signs. Machinery and equipment signs shall be allowed in all districts. 
(11)  Temporary construction signs. One temporary construction sign shall be allowed on each parcel within the city. Temporary construction signs shall not exceed six square feet in sign area, and six feet in height for residential properties, and 32 square feet in sign area, and ten feet in height for nonresidential properties. 
(12)  Temporary real estate signs. For each parcel within the city, one temporary real estate sign may be displayed on each frontage per parcel of land. However, when more than one dwelling unit or non-residential space on a parcel of land is for sale, lease, or rent, there shall only be one temporary window or attached real estate sign for each such unit or space that is separately owned. Temporary real estate signs shall not exceed three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height for residential properties, and 16 square feet in sign area, and six feet in height for nonresidential properties. The temporary real estate sign shall be removed immediately upon the sale, lease or rent of the real estate that was offered for sale, lease, or rent. 
(13)  Temporary garage-yard sale signs. For each parcel within the city, one temporary garage-yard sale sign may be displayed on each frontage per parcel of land. However, the sign shall only be displayed on the parcel of land upon which the garage sale is taking place. A temporary garage-yard sale sign shall not exceed three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height. A temporary garage-yard sale sign may not be displayed for a period longer than two days during any calendar month and shall be removed upon the conclusion of the sale. 
(14)  Temporary window signs. For each parcel within the city, one or more temporary window signs may be displayed on the inside of the window. On parcels that are in residential use, the temporary window sign(s) shall not exceed an aggregate of three square feet in sign area. On parcels that are in non-residential use, the temporary window sign(s) shall not exceed an aggregate of 24 square feet in sign area. Temporary window signs shall not cover more than 25 percent of any window surface. 
(15)  Temporary holiday and seasonal decorations. Temporary holiday and seasonal decorations shall be allowed in all districts. 
(16)  Temporary valet parking station signs. One temporary valet parking station sign no more than three square feet in sign area, and not more than three feet in height, shall be allowed on each parcel where the valet station is located. The temporary valet parking station sign shall only be visible during hours that the valet is operating, and shall be located on the same parcel as the valet station. 
(17)  Bus stop informational signs. Bus stop informational signs up to three square feet in area shall be allowed in all districts. These signs shall have a maximum height of six feet unless otherwise required by applicable law. 
(18)  Temporary banner signs. Temporary banner signs not exceeding 15 square feet in a residential zone and 48 square feet in a commercial zone may be displayed on property no more than four times per year and up to a maximum of 14 days per occurrence, with a minimum of 45 days between each occurrence. No temporary banner exceeding 15 square feet may be displayed without the issuance of an banner permit that is based upon guidelines providing specific criteria and that are not based upon the content (viewpoint) of the banner sign; however, until such criteria are established by resolution or other action by this council, no temporary banner sign exceeding 15 square feet in size shall be allowed. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-162—66-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DIMENSIONS 
 
Sec. 66-181. - Computation of sign dimensions generally. 
The computation of sign dimensions shall be as set forth in this division and in section 66-183. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-182. - Computation of total permitted sign area. 
(a)  Freestanding signs. 
(1)  Except as otherwise specifically stated in this chapter, the permitted sign area for freestanding signs shall be based upon one and one-half square feet for each linear foot of zone lot frontage. 
(2)  A freestanding sign shall be allowed to have an additional two square feet per sign face, provided that this allowance is used exclusively for the street address number, numbers or number range, depicted in Arabic numbers. The public purpose for the address is to assist the traveling public to locate specific places and to assist public safety and emergency service vehicles to rapidly locate addresses. 
(b)  Attached signs. 
(1)  Except as otherwise specifically stated in this chapter, the permitted sign area for attached signs shall be based upon one and one-half square feet for each linear foot of zone lot frontage, with a specified maximum for each respective land use, whichever is less. 
(2)  An attached sign shall be allowed to have an additional two square feet per sign for residential usage and an additional eight square feet for nonresidential usage, provided that this allowance is used exclusively for the street address number, numbers or number range depicted in Arabic numbers a minimum of three inches in height. The public purpose for the address is to assist the traveling public to locate specific places and to assist public safety and emergency service vehicles to rapidly locate addresses. 
(c)  Multiple-frontage lots. Zone lots fronting two or more streets are allowed the permitted signage for each frontage, but signage cannot be accumulated and used on one street in excess of that allowed for the zone lot based on that one street frontage. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-183. - Computation of sign area. 
(a)  The area of a sign shall be computed on the basis of the smallest square, circle, rectangle, other geometric figure, or combination thereof, that will encompass the extreme limits of the writing, representation, emblem, lighting or other display, together with any material, color or border trim forming an integral part of the background of the display or used to differentiate the sign from the backdrop or structure against which it is placed. 
(b)  The area of a sign shall be computed on a per-sign-face basis and all requirements with respect to sign area reference the area of a single face of a sign. A double-faced sign shall be permitted to have the allowed area for a single-faced sign on each of the two faces of the double-faced sign. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-184. - Computation of sign height. 
(a)  The height of a freestanding sign shall be computed as the distance from the base of the sign at ground level to the top of any portion of the sign structure. In cases where the ground level cannot reasonably be determined, sign height shall be derived on the assumption that the elevation of the ground at the base of the sign is equal to the average elevation at the front property line of the zone lot. 
(b)  If a freestanding sign is on a parcel contiguous to an overpass or elevated road (excluding service roads) from which the sign is designed to be viewed, the height of the sign shall be measured from the highest point of the overpass or elevated road at the crown of the roadway surface to the top of the sign, this highest point to be determined by the average elevation between the perpendicular extension of the contiguous zone lot lines on which the sign is to be located, as such lot lines intersect the overpass or elevated road. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-185. - Computation of visual clearance and sight triangle. 
To  ensure adequate sight distance at the intersection of two public roadways and at the intersection of a public roadway and an accessway or driveway, the visual clearance and sight triangle shall conform to the criteria of the state department of transportation's manual of uniform minimum standards for design, construction, and maintenance for streets and highways. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-186—66-205. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PERMITTED SIGNS AND STANDARDS BY LAND USE CLASSIFICATIONS  
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 66-206. - Purpose and procedure. 
(a)  It is the intent of this division to regulate signs consistent with the land use classification that establishes the character of the area in which the signs are located. 
(b)  The city shall establish a definitive categorization, by land use plan or zoning district, to correlate such designations with the major land use classifications of the city's future land use plan. 
(c)  Within the major commercial land use classification, the differentiation between the commercial subcategories of neighborhood commercial and general commercial, shall be found in this division under subdivision V, relating to commercial land use classification. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-207—66-230. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Residential Land Use Classifications 
 
Sec. 66-231. - Permitted signs. 
The following types of signs are permitted in residential land use classifications, as depicted on the city's future land use plan map. 
(1)  Permanent monument identification signs located within 100 feet of a residential subdivision entrance to which it pertains for residential areas shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of one sign is permitted for each platted subdivision or property entrance. 
b.  Area. The maximum area shall be 24 square feet per sign face. 
c.  Height. The maximum height for a freestanding sign is six feet. 
d.  Setbacks. There shall be a minimum setback of ten feet from the leading edge of the sign to the property line unless attached to a subdivision wall. 
(2)  Home occupational signs in residential districts shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of one attached sign is permitted. 
b.  Area. The maximum area of the sign shall be one square foot per sign face. 
(3)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(4)  Signs for public/semipublic land uses shall be in accordance with the provisions of section 66-256. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-232—66-255. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Public/Semipublic Land Use Classifications 
 
Sec. 66-256. - Permitted signs. 
The following types of signs are permitted in public/semipublic land use classifications, as depicted on the city's future land use plan map: 
(1)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(2)  Freestanding signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of one sign per zone lot is permitted. One additional sign may be permitted for each additional street frontage. For parcels with over 500 feet of street frontage on one right-of-way, one additional freestanding sign may be permitted, such additional sign to be spaced at least 300 feet from the other. 
b.  Area. The total maximum area for any freestanding sign or signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(a) or 48 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
c.  Height. The maximum height for a freestanding sign shall be 12 feet. 
d.  Setbacks. Setbacks shall be a minimum of ten feet from the property line to the leading edge of the sign. 
(3)  Attached signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of two signs per zone lot is permitted. 
b.  Area. The maximum total area for all attached signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(b) or 48 square feet, whichever is less. 
c.  Permitted signs. The following attached signs may be permitted, provided the cumulative area of the attached signs does not exceed the maximum area according to subsection b. above: 
1.  Wall sign and any associated lighting. 
2.  Canopy or awning sign. Canopy or awing sign may be permitted in lieu of a wall or window sign. Such canopy or awning and signage square footage combined shall not exceed the total permissible square footage for a wall or window sign. 
3.  Permanent window sign. 
4.  Projecting sign. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-257—66-280. - Reserved.  
Subdivision IV. - Mixed Use Classifications 
 
Sec. 66-281. - Generally. 
Within the mixed use classification, the city will apply the sign standards specified in section 66-282 based on the actual type of use to which the sign pertains, i.e. residential, office or commercial. It shall further be the prerogative of the city to determine which commercial subcategory, i.e., neighborhood, general, etc., applies to the commercial use within the mixed use classification, which determination shall be made consistent with the provisions of section 66-206(c). 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-282. - Permitted signs. 
(a)  Generally. The types of signs specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are permitted in mixed use (office land use) land use classifications as depicted on the city's future land use map. 
(b)  Freestanding signs. Freestanding signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
(1)  Number. A maximum of one sign per zone lot is permitted. One additional sign may be permitted for each additional street frontage. For parcels with over 500 feet of street frontage on one right-of-way, one additional freestanding sign may be permitted, such additional sign to be spaced at least 300 feet from the other. 
(2)  Area. The total maximum area for any freestanding sign or signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(a) or 50 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
(3)  Height. The maximum height for a freestanding sign is 12 feet. 
(4)  Setbacks. There shall be a minimum setback of ten feet from the property line to the leading edge of the sign. A freestanding sign shall not be located within any yard setback that is directly contiguous to or abuts a property zoned RR, RE, RS, RL or RU. 
(c)  Attached signs. Attached signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
(1)  Area. The maximum total area for all attached signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(b) or 50 square feet, whichever is less. 
(2)  Permitted signs. The following attached signs may be permitted, provided the cumulative area of the attached signs does not exceed the maximum area according to subsection (1) above: 
a.  Wall sign. 
b.  Canopy or awning sign. Canopy or awing sign may be permitted in lieu of a wall or window sign. Such canopy or awning and signage square footage combined shall not exceed the total permissible square footage for a wall or window sign. 
c.  Permanent window sign. 
d.  Projecting sign. 
(3)  Time and temperature signs. The maximum area for the time and temperature portion only shall be 20 square feet per sign face. 
(4)  Directory/information signs. Directory/information signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. The number of directory/information signs shall be limited to two. 
b.  Area. The maximum area for a directory/information sign shall be 25 square feet per sign face for one sign, with a total of 50 square feet per zone lot. 
(5)  Residential land use. See section 66-231 et seq. 
(6)  Commercial land use. See section 66-306 et seq. 
(7)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(8)  Public/semipublic uses. Public/semipublic land uses shall follow the sign provisions of section 66-256. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-283—66-305. - Reserved.  
Subdivision V. - Commercial Land Use Classifications 
 
Sec. 66-306. - Generally. 
Within the commercial classification, the city will apply the sign standards specified in section 66-307 based on a determination as to which commercial subcategory, i.e. neighborhood, general or limited applies to a given commercial classification within the city, which determination shall be made consistent with the provisions of section 66-206(b) and (c). 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-307. - Permitted signs. 
(a)  Generally. The types of signs specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are permitted in commercial land use classifications, as depicted on the citywide future land use plan map. 
(b)  Neighborhood commercial subcategory. 
(1)  Freestanding signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of one sign per zone lot is permitted. One additional sign may be permitted for each additional street frontage. For parcels with over 500 feet of street frontage on one right-of-way, one additional freestanding sign may be permitted, such sign to be spaced at least 300 feet from the other. 
b.  Area. The total maximum area for any freestanding sign or signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(a) or 75 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
c.  Height. The maximum height for a freestanding sign is 15 feet. 
d.  Setbacks. A minimum of ten feet setback from the property line to the leading edge of the sign is required. Those signs set back an additional ten feet shall be permitted an increased allowance for height and sign area of ten percent. 
e.  Time and temperature signs. The maximum area for the time and temperature portions only shall be 20 square feet per sign face. 
f.  Menu display. One attached menu display sign of no more than six square feet of sign face area, located at the entrance, or service window of a restaurant, and one freestanding drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall be placed so as to be viewed from the drive-through lane and shall contain only a listing of products offered for sale by the business with prices and may provide a mechanism for ordering products while viewing the drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall have a surface area not exceeding 40 square feet. The top of the sign and its surrounding or supporting framing/structure shall not exceed nine feet above ground level. The drive-in menu sign lettering will be no larger than necessary in order to be read from a vehicle located in the drive-through lane. Drive-in restaurants may have one additional attached sign, not exceeding six square feet in total sign area, per drive in stall or bay. 
g.  Gasoline pumps. Gasoline service stations shall be permitted pump signage per pump as follows: two single-sided or one double-sided gasoline price sign not to exceed one (1) square foot per sign face. 
(2)  Attached signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Area. The maximum total area for all attached signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(b) or 75 square feet, whichever is less. 
b.  Permitted signs. The following attached signs may be permitted, provided the cumulative area of the attached signs does not exceed the maximum area according to section 66-182: 
1.  Wall sign. 
2.  Canopy or awning sign. Canopy or awning sign may be permitted in lieu of a wall or window sign. Such canopy or awning and signage square footage combined shall not exceed the total permissible square footage for a wall or window sign. 
3.  Permanent window sign. 
4.  Projecting sign. 
c.  Tube graphics. The city will permit in addition to the allowable attached signage area, one linear foot of tube graphics for each linear front footage of building or appropriate portion of the building, with a maximum footage equal to the allowable square footage in the respective land use category. This extra allowance shall only be used as a linear display and not as a second conventional attached sign. 
(3)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(4)  Public/semipublic land uses shall follow the sign provisions of section 66-256. 
(c)  General commercial subcategory. 
(1)  Freestanding signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
a.  Number. A maximum of one sign per zone lot is permitted. One additional sign may be permitted for each additional street frontage. For parcels with over 500 feet of street frontage on one right-of-way, one additional freestanding sign may be permitted, such additional sign to be spaced at least 300 feet from the other. 
b.  Area. The total maximum area for any freestanding sign or signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(a) or 100 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
c.  Height. Maximum height for a ground sign is 20 feet. 
d.  Setbacks. A minimum setback of ten feet from the property line to the leading edge of the sign is required. For each additional ten-foot setback, the applicant shall be permitted an additional ten percent for area and height not to exceed 30 percent. 
e.  Time and temperature signs. The maximum area for the time and temperature portion only shall be 20 square feet per sign face. 
f.  Theater/movie announcement sign. These signs are allowed in the commercial General district, with one additional sign for listing. The maximum size is 100 square feet. 
g.  Menu display. One attached menu display sign of no more than six square feet of sign face area, located at the entrance, or service window of a restaurant, and one freestanding drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall be placed so as to be viewed from the drive-through lane and shall contain only a listing of products offered for sale by the business with prices and may provide a mechanism for ordering products while viewing the drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall have a surface area not exceeding 40 square feet. The top of the sign and its surrounding or supporting framing/structure shall not exceed nine feet above ground level. The drive-in menu sign lettering will be no larger than necessary in order to be read from a vehicle located in the drive-through lane. Drive-in restaurants may have one additional attached sign, not exceeding six square feet in total sign area, per drive in stall or bay. 
h.  Gasoline pumps. Gasoline service stations shall be permitted pump signage per pump as follows: two single-sided or one double-sided gasoline price sign not to exceed one square foot per sign face. 
(2)  Attached signs shall be permitted as follows: 
a.  Area. The maximum total area for all attached signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(b), or 100 square feet, whichever is less. Structures or portions of structures with a single occupant or single use utilizing in excess of 250 linear front feet may exceed the allowable square footage in increments of 25 square feet, maximum of three increments. To gain the next increment, the applicant must have at least half an increment or 12½ linear feet. 
b.  Permitted signs. The following attached signs may be permitted, provided the cumulative area of the attached signs does not exceed the maximum area according to subsection (2)a. above: 
1.  Wall sign. 
2.  Canopy or awning sign. Canopy or awning sign may be permitted in lieu of a wall or window sign. Such canopy or awning and signage square footage combined shall not exceed the total permissible square footage for a wall or window sign. 
3.  Permanent window sign. 
4.  Projecting sign. 
c.  Tube graphics. The city will permit in addition to the allowable attached signage area one linear foot of tube graphics for each linear front footage of building or appropriate portion of the building, with a maximum footage equal to the allowable square footage in the respective land use category. This extra allowance shall only be used as a linear display and not as a second conventional attached sign. 
(3)  The maximum area for all gasoline price display signs shall total no more than 24 square feet per sign face. 
(4)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(5)  Public/semipublic land uses shall follow the sign provisions of section 66-256. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-308—66-330. - Reserved.  
Subdivision VI. - Industrial Limited Warehouse Classifications 
 
Sec. 66-331. - Permitted signs. 
(a)  Generally. The types of signs specified in subsections (b)—(f) of this section are permitted in industrial land use classifications, as depicted on the city's future land use plan map, and the city's land use plan or zoning district correlation as determined by the respective local jurisdiction. 
(b)  Freestanding signs. Freestanding signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
(1)  Number. A maximum of one sign per zone lot is permitted. One additional sign may be permitted for each additional street frontage. For parcels with over 500 feet of street frontage on one right-of-way, one additional freestanding ground sign may be permitted. Such additional sign must be spaced at least 300 feet from the other. 
(2)  Area. The total maximum area for any ground sign or signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(a) or 75 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
(3)  Height. The maximum height for a ground sign is 20 feet. 
(4)  Setbacks. A ten-foot minimum setback from the property line to the leading edge of the sign is required. 
(5)  Time and temperature signs. The maximum area for the time and temperature portion only shall be 20 square feet per sign face. 
(6)  Menu display. One attached menu display sign of no more than six (6) square feet of sign face area, located at the entrance, or service window of a restaurant, and one freestanding drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall be placed so as to be viewed from the drive-through lane and shall contain only a listing of products offered for sale by the business with prices and may provide a mechanism for ordering products while viewing the drive-through menu sign. The drive-through menu sign shall have a surface area not exceeding 40 square feet. The top of the sign and its surrounding or supporting framing/structure shall not exceed nine feet above ground level. The drive-in menu sign lettering will be no larger than necessary in order to be read from a vehicle located in the drive-through lane. Drive-in restaurants may have one additional attached sign, not exceeding six square feet in total sign area, per drive in stall or bay. 
(7)  Gasoline pumps. Gasoline service stations shall be permitted pump signage per pump as follows: two single-sided or one double-sided gasoline price sign not to exceed one square foot per sign face. 
(c)  Attached signs. Attached signs shall be permitted only as follows: 
(1)  Area. The maximum total area for all attached signs shall be that area calculated according to section 66-182(b) or 75 square feet per sign face, whichever is less. 
(2)  Permitted signs. The following attached signs may be permitted, provided the cumulative area of the attached signs does not exceed the maximum area according to subsection (1) above: 
a.  Wall sign. 
b.  Canopy or awning sign. Canopy or awning sign may be permitted in lieu of a wall or window sign. Such canopy or awning and signage square footage combined shall not exceed the total permissible square footage for a wall or window sign. 
c.  Permanent window sign. 
d.  Projecting sign. 
e.  Integral roof sign. 
(3)  Tube graphics. The city will permit, in addition to the allowable attached signage area, one linear foot of tube graphics for each linear front footage of building or appropriate portion of the building, with a maximum footage equal to the allowable square footage in the respective land use category. This extra allowance shall only be used as a linear display and not as a second conventional attached sign. 
(d)  Gasoline price display signs. The maximum area for all gasoline price display signs shall total 24 square feet per sign face. 
(e)  Non-commercial onsite directional signs. Non-commercial onsite directional signs, not exceeding three square feet in sign area, and three feet in height shall be allowed on each parcel or lot. These signs may not exceed 15 square feet in the aggregate. 
(f)  Public/semipublic land uses. Public/semipublic land uses shall follow the sign provisions of section 66-256. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Secs. 66-332—66-355. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - SEVERABILITY 
 
Sec. 66-356. - In General. 
If any part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this chapter is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration of such unconstitutionality shall not affect any other part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this article. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-357. - Severability where less speech results. 
Without diminishing or limiting in any way the declaration of severability set forth above in section 66-356, or elsewhere in this chapter, this Code, or any adopting ordinance, if any part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this chapter is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration of such unconstitutionality shall not affect any other part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this chapter, even if such severability would result in a situation where there would be less speech, whether by subjecting previously exempt signs to permitting or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-358. - Severability of provisions pertaining to prohibited signs. 
Without diminishing or limiting in any way the declaration of severability set forth above in section 66-356, or elsewhere in this chapter, this Code, or any adopting ordinance, if any part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this article or any other law is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration of such unconstitutionality shall not affect any other part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this chapter that pertains to prohibited signs, including specifically those signs and sign-types prohibited and not allowed under section 66-8 of this chapter. Furthermore, if any part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of section 66-10 is declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration of such unconstitutionality shall not affect any other part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of section 66-8. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Sec. 66-359. - Severability of prohibition on billboards. 
If any part, section, subsection, paragraph, subparagraph, sentence, phrase, clause, term, or word of this article and/or any other Code provisions and/or laws are declared invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, the declaration of such unconstitutionality shall not affect the prohibition on billboards as contained in this chapter and Code. 
(Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-24-09)  
Chapter 70 - ZONING[1]

Editor's note— Ord. No. 09-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), adopted May 12, 2015, amended Ch. 70 in its entirety to read as herein set out. The subsection numbering has been maintained per said ordinance. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 70-1. - Purpose and intent. 
As provided for in F.S. ch. 163, it is "found and declared that the preservation or enhancement of the tax base from which a taxing authority (city) realizes tax revenues is essential to its existence and financial health; that the preservation and enhancement of such tax base (city tax base) is implicit in the purpose for which the taxing authority (city) is established." Therefore, the purpose and intent of this chapter is to establish regulations to preserve and enhance the city's tax base, as well as providing for the health, safety, and welfare of the residents and the businesses. 
Further, the purpose of this chapter is to describe the specific uses and restrictions that apply to zoning districts in the city. This chapter is intended to allow development and use of property only in compliance with the purpose and intent of this chapter, the goals, objectives and policies of the city as expressed in the future land use element of the city's comprehensive plan, and to help protect the stability of neighborhoods within the city. Further, limitations on uses and/or other restrictions within the zoning districts may also be governed by Pinellas Planning Council (PPC) countywide rules. Where there is a conflict between regulations contained in this chapter and the countywide rules, the countywide rules shall govern. 
( Ord. No. 09-2015 , § 2(Exh. A), 5-12-15)  
Sec. 70-2. - Definitions. 
All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this chapter shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the city council may be fully carried out. The provisions of this chapter shall be liberally construed so as to implement its intents and purposes and for implementation of the mandates of the comprehensive plan. Terms used in this chapter, unless otherwise specifically defined, shall have the meanings prescribed by reference to generally accepted engineering, planning, or otherwise professional terminology if technical; and otherwise, according to common usage or where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Except as otherwise noted, all other words shall have the meaning normally attributed to them. 
Abandonment means to discontinue or cease a use or activity or use of a building/structure for a period as specified in the Code, including but not limited to, vacating of a premises or building, discontinuance of utility service or non-operative status. 
Accessory means a building, structure or use that: 
(1)  Is subordinate to and serves a principal building and principal use; 
(2)  Is subordinate in area, square footage, height and purpose to the principal building and principal use served, except as provided for in this chapter; 
(3)  Contributes to the comfort, convenience or necessities of the users or occupants of the principal building and principal use; and 
(4)  Is located on the same lot or parcel as the principal building and principal use, provided such use is in keeping with the purpose and intent of the district in which it is located. 
Accessory dwelling unit means an ancillary or secondary living unit that may or may not have a separate kitchen, bathroom and sleeping area, existing either within the same structure or on the same lot, as the primary dwelling unit. 
Acreage means the fee simple deeded acreage contained in a given lot or tract as platted and recorded in the official records of the county. 
Agricultural activities means crop production, including plant nurseries; the maintaining of livestock, including horses, dog kennels, animal boarding, and like uses. 
Alteration means any change to a development and/or site, including but not limited to, rearrangement, enlargement, extension, reduction, or moving of any structure or part thereof, and any change of electrical wiring, plumbing or heating system. 
Ancillary nonresidential use means a nonresidential use such as off-street parking, drainage retention areas, and open space buffer areas for an adjacent, contiguous, nonresidential use. 
Apartment building means a structure containing four or more rental living units. 
Assisted living facility (ALF) means a residential equivalent facility providing assisted living care for adults which may be independently sited or a component of a retirement community, comprised of dwelling units, a centralized kitchen facility (no unit kitchens or kitchenettes), whether operated for profit or not, which undertakes through its ownership or management to provide for a period exceeding 24-hour housing, food service and personal or therapeutic services as needed for seven or more persons, not related to the owner or administrator by blood or marriage, who require such services and to provide limited nursing services, when specifically licensed to do so by the state. 
Automobile or salvage yards or lots means a lot, group of contiguous lots or parcels used for the dismantling or wrecking of used vehicles and/or the storage and sale of used automotive parts. 
Base flood elevation means the elevation of the base flood, including wave height, relative to the National Geodetic Vertical Datum (NGVD), North American Vertical Datum (NAVD) or other datum specified on the flood insurance rate map (FIRM). 
Building means any structure having a roof supported by columns or walls designed or built for the support, enclosure, shelter or protection of persons, animals, chattels or property of any kind. 
Building height means the vertical distance from the finished ground elevation to the highest point of the coping or roof, whichever is higher. 
Building lines means the extreme outer dimension of any structure, whether constructed or staked out for construction, including all structural components except the chimneys, cornices, sills or eaves; however, where the projection of any chimney, cornice, sill or eave extends more than three feet beyond the building line, the building line shall be considered to be three feet inside the outermost extension of any such projection. 
Building site area requirements means those portions of this chapter which regulate the size of the land areas upon which structures and development may be located. 
City manager designee (designee), means the city staff authorized by the city manager to perform the duties as described in this chapter. 
Clinic means a facility wherein professional services concerning personal health of humans are administered by medical doctors, chiropractors, osteopaths, optometrists, dentists or any other such profession, which may lawfully be practiced in the state. Persons treated shall not be lodged therein overnight. 
Coastal high hazard area (CHHA) means the area below the elevation of the category 1 storm surge line as established by a sea, lake and overland surges from hurricanes (SLOSH) computerized storm surge model, as reflected in the most recent regional evacuation study, storm tide atlas (hurricane evacuation level A). 
Conditional use means a use permitted in a zoning district only after it is authorized by the city council after a public hearing pursuant section 70-226 et seq. 
Condominium dwelling unit means a building or group of buildings in which units are owned individually and the structure, common areas and ancillary facilities are owned by all the owners on a proportional undivided basis, and is typically governed by an owner's association. 
Continuing care means furnishing, pursuant to an agreement between the provider and a resident, shelter, food, and either nursing care or personal services. 
Conversion means the structural and spatial alteration of a residence to produce a different number of dwelling units than presently exists or any change from one use occupancy to another use. 
Countywide rules are administrative rules that apply to all municipalities adopted by the Pinellas Planning Council (PPC) that establish definitions, standards, criteria and procedures to implement and administer the countywide future land use plan, including but not limited to, what local government land use plan amendments require PPC review. 
Day care center includes any day nursery school, kindergarten, or other facility, as defined by state law which with or without compensation cares for five or more children 17 years of age or under, not related to the operator by blood, marriage or adoption, away from the child's own home. Such facilities shall be licensed and operated in strict accord with the provisions of state law. This term includes adult day care (over the age of 17 years) as defined by state law but does not include a family day care center as defined by state law. 
Density means the total number of dwelling units divided by the net land area of the building site. 
Design compatibility, means sensitivity of a building and site design to the existing character of a neighborhood, surrounding blocks, or historic or special area. This is measured by how the design of a building or project relates to the design elements of the adjacent building(s), surrounding natural/physical and manmade environment. Compatibility measures include, but are not limited to the following: building relationship to the street and adjacent development such as height, facade details, landscaping, activities); the rhythm of spacing between buildings; the use of building materials which match in dimension, color, pattern and finish/texture; architectural style and building scale and mass. These same measures apply to building additions. 
Development or development activity/site means the addition to, or improvement of, property, including but not limited to the following activities: 
(1)  Construction, clearing, filling, excavating, grading or paving or otherwise significantly disturbing the soil of the site. 
(2)  A change in the intensity of use of land, such as an increase in the number of dwelling units in a structure or on land or a material increase in the number of businesses, manufacturing establishments, offices, or dwelling units in a structure or on land. 
(3)  Building or installing a new building/structure, walls/fences, sign, required landscaping or parking areas. 
(4)  Enlarging, replacing or substantially restoring a building/structure, sign or parking areas. 
(5)  Subdividing land into three or more parcels. 
Dwelling means a structure designed for residential occupancy with complete living facilities (such as separate cooking, bathroom and sleeping facilities), including single family, duplexes, triplexes, multifamily dwelling units and modular homes, but not including temporary lodging uses that contain one or more rooms including kitchen facilities. 
Dwelling, multifamily, means four or more dwelling units contained in one structure on a single lot or parcel and attached by common vertical walls. 
Dwelling, single-family, means a detached dwelling unit structure designed for and occupied exclusively by one family or group living home with six or fewer individuals. 
Dwelling, three-family (triplex) , means a building designed with three dwelling units attached to each other for occupancy by a single family in each unit. 
Dwelling, two-family (duplex) , means a building designed with two dwelling units attached to each other for occupancy by a single family in each unit. 
Excavation means altering of earth material for purposes other than that incidental to and on the site of construction, including land balancing, authorized by site plan approval. (See section 70-911.) 
F.A.C. means Florida Administrative Code. 
Family means two or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption or of more than two unrelated persons living and cooking together as a single housekeeping unit. 
Floor area, gross, means the sum of the gross horizontal areas of the several floors of a building measured from the exterior face of exterior walls, or from the centerline of a wall separating two buildings, but not including interior parking spaces or loading spaces for motor vehicles. 
Floor area ratio means a measurement of the intensity of building development on a site. The ratio is the relationship between the gross floor area on a site and the net land area and is derived by adding together the gross floor area of all buildings on the site and dividing by the net land area. 
F.S. means Florida Statutes. 
Group living home, category A, means a residential facility designed to be occupied by seven to 14 individuals along with a maximum of two full-time supervisors or house parents. These facilities shall provide a physical appearance and a style of life that makes them compatible with other dwellings existing in the neighborhood. Facilities may include foster care facilities, ALFs, displaced youth and adult shelters, care of the developmentally disabled (as defined by state and federal law) and similar family group living facilities. Such facilities are subject to separation requirements pursuant to F.S. ch. 419. 
Group living home, category B, includes those uses allowed in category A group living home designed to be occupied by more than 14 individuals along with a maximum of two resident supervisors or house parents. Additionally, these facilities may offer a higher level of personal and therapeutic care and may include mental health care, spouse abuse care, offender halfway houses, and similar care facilities. These facilities shall provide a physical appearance and a style of life that makes them compatible with other dwellings existing in the neighborhood. Such facilities are subject to separation requirements pursuant to F.S. ch. 419. 
Guest cottage aka mother-in-law suite and like terms means sleeping quarters within a detached accessory structure, which is to be used exclusively for housing members of the family occupying the main structure, or other nonpaying guests. A guest cottage shall not have kitchen facilities nor to be rented nor otherwise used as a separate dwelling. A guest cottage shall not be permitted to have a separate electric or water meter. 
Height of building/structure means the vertical distance measured from the finished grade at the base of the building/structure to the highest point of the building/structure or roof peak or as may be defined in other sections of this chapter. For buildings/structures within the floodplain, height is measured from base flood elevation. 
Home occupation means an accessory use in a residential area consisting of an occupation or activity performed entirely within a dwelling and only by members of a family permanently living therein. The home occupation is to be clearly incidental and secondary to the use of the dwelling for dwelling purposes and is not to change the residential character thereof. (See article X.) 
Hospital means a medical facility providing overnight care licensed to operate by the state department of children and family services as such. 
Hotel means a structure containing a temporary lodging use with sleeping accommodations in which guests are lodged without provision for the hook-up of a stove in any individual room or suite. 
Household pets means animals that are normally considered as household pets and that can be maintained and cared for within the living space of a residence. Such animals may include but are not limited to dogs, cats, small rodents, small reptiles, fish, small birds, such as parrots and parakeets and other similar animals. 
Impervious surface means a surface that has been compacted or covered with a layer of material so that it is highly resistant or prevents infiltration by stormwater. It includes surfaces such as compacted sand, limerock, or clay, as well as building foundations and paved surfaces such as streets, sidewalks, parking lots and other similar surfaces. 
Impervious surface ratio is a measure of the intensity of land use that is determined by dividing the square footage of all impervious surfaces by the square footage of the net land area of a building site or lot. 
Improvement means any manmade, immovable item (including but not limited to buildings, fences/walls, signs walls, roofs, and accessory structures) that becomes part of, is placed upon, or is affixed to real estate or development site. 
Independent-living unit means a dwelling unit with kitchen facilities for a resident where the residents are capable of caring for themselves and do not require a provider to provide food or personal services. 
Junkyard means a parcel of land upon which the principal or accessory use is the accumulation of used, discarded or worn-out materials or manufactured products, which may or may not be reusable or saleable. This shall not include recycling operations for metal, paper or similar materials when located entirely within an enclosed building. 
Intensity means the measure of permitted development expressed as a maximum impervious surface ratio and/or floor area ratio per acre of net land area. 
Kennel means an establishment where domestic animals are bred, boarded, sold or treated for profit or public service. 
Land development code (LDC or code) means the city's set of regulations governing land development, which includes, but is not limited to, chapters 46, 50, 54, 58, 59, 62, 66 and this chapter. 
Livestock means those animals normally considered as farm animals such as cattle, goats, sheep, horses, ponies, mules, pigs, chickens, ducks, geese, other similar farm animals and wild animals licensed pursuant to state law. This definition is not intended to include household pets or wild animals living within their native habitat. 
Living area, residential, means the floor area of any residential structure (measured in square feet), including only those areas of such a structure which are habitable the year round. Garages, screened porches, breezeways, terraces, stoops, carports, patios or other similar areas shall not be considered part of the living area. 
Loading space means a space that provides for the loading or unloading of delivery vehicles. 
Lot means an area of land designated on a recorded plat as an individual tract. 
Lot, corner means a lot with boundaries abutting two intersecting streets. 
Lot depth means the distance measured in the mean direction of the side lines of the lot from the midpoint on the front lot line to the midpoint of the opposite main rear line of the lot. 
Lot, double-frontage, means a lot having frontage on two or more streets, but not necessarily at the intersection of two streets. 
Lot of record, means a lot which is part of a subdivision, the map of which has been recorded in the office of the circuit court clerk of the county or a parcel of land, the deed of which was recorded in the office of the circuit court clerk of the county prior to the enactment of this chapter. 
Lot width means the width of the lot as measured along the front building setback line. 
Manufactured home means a modular home which is built to state standards and approved by the state department of community affairs and meets the requirements of the state building code. 
Mobile home means a modular home which is built to federal standards and approved by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development but does not meet the requirements of the state building code. 
Mobile home park means a lot or parcel of land upon which there are four or more mobile home sites. 
Mobile home site means a space or plot of ground within a mobile home park, designated for the accommodation of not more than one mobile home. 
Mobile home subdivision means a platted residential subdivision in which the dwelling units consist of mobile homes and accessory residential structures. 
Modular homes means one or more rooms including kitchen facilities designed as a unit for one-family occupancy that is wholly manufactured to include electrical and plumbing facilities at an off-site location and requiring no on-site inspection of interior components. 
Motel means a structure containing a temporary lodging use that provides lodging for guests and having rental units that may provide food preparation facilities for occupants. 
Net land area means that for the purpose of computing density/intensity it shall be that total land area within the property boundaries of the subject parcel or lot, and specifically exclusive of any submerged land or public right-of-way. 
Nonconformance means any lot, use or structure or site development that does not conform to the requirements of this chapter and which use or building/structure was legally in existence prior to the enactment of the Code. 
Nursing home means any institution, building, residence, private home, or other place, whether operated for profit or not, including a place operated by a county or municipality, which undertakes through its ownership or management to provide for a period exceeding 24 hours, nursing care, personal care, or custodial care for three or more persons not related to the owner or manager by blood or marriage, who by reason of illness, physical infirmity, or advanced age require such services. This definition does not include hospitals, clinics or similar establishments devoted primarily to the diagnosis and treatment of the sick or injured and providing care and treatment primarily for the acutely ill when specifically licensed to do so pursuant to state regulations. The facility may be permitted as an accessory use and shall be considered a sheltered nursing facility that is designed for the exclusive use of the residents of a specific community and not the general public. 
Official maps means those land use and zoning maps adopted by the city council. 
Open space means the land and/or water areas (excluding Lake Seminole, and Long and Cross Bayous) between and around structures, including required recreation areas, up to 25 percent of stormwater detention areas, landscaped areas or preservation areas that are required to be maintained with vegetative growth. This shall not include parking, vehicular use or any paved or graveled areas. 
Owner means a person who, alone, jointly or severally with others, or in a representative capacity (including without limitation, an authorized agent, attorney, executor, personal representative or trustee) has legal or equitable title to any property in question, or a tenant, if the tenancy is chargeable under his lease for the maintenance of the property. 
Parcel means any individual unplatted tract of land under uniform ownership, within legally established property lines. If, however, the property lines are such as to defeat the purposes of this land development code or lead to absurd results, then the community development director shall delineate the parcel boundaries. 
Parcel, corner, means a parcel with boundaries abutting two intersecting streets. 
Parcel depth means the distance measured in the mean direction of the side lines of the parcel from the midpoint of the front parcel line to the midpoint of the opposite main rear line of the parcel. 
Parcel, double-frontage, means a parcel having street frontage on two or more streets, but not necessarily at the intersection of the streets. 
Parcel width means the width of the parcel as measured at the building front setback line. For corner or through lots, width shall be measured at the building front setback line on the narrowest property line width abutting a street. 
Personal services include but are not limited to such services as individual assistance with or supervision of essential activities of daily living, such as eating, bathing, grooming, dressing, ambulating, housekeeping, supervision of self-administered medication and arrangement for appropriate medical, dental, nursing or mental health service. 
Professional office means a business or professional use intended to serve the public on or from the premises but not including the on-premises storage for sale and/or the sale of any product or equipment nor the providing of personal services such as barbershop, beauty parlor, tailoring, and shoe repair. 
Property line means a line that separates a lot or parcel from an adjoining lot or parcel or right-of-way. 
Provider means the owner or operator, whether a natural person, partnership, unincorporated association, or corporation, whether operated for profit or not, which owner or operator undertakes to provide continuing care to individuals for remuneration for the period of care. 
Public/semipublic uses means institutional uses such as facilities and services of a public, private or quasi-public nature, including educational, medical and government, civic uses such as schools, hospitals, community centers and religious facilities; and transportation/utility uses that serve the community. 
Recreational vehicle means the following types of vehicles: 
(1)  Travel trailer means a vehicle, portable structure built on a chassis and towed with a standard automobile, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation and vacation uses, permanently identified "travel trailer" by the manufacturer on the trailer and when factory-equipped for the road. 
(2)  Pickup coach means a structure designed to be mounted on a truck chassis with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation and vacation uses. 
(3)  Motor home means a portable dwelling designed to be used for travel, recreation and vacation uses, constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle. 
(4)  Camping trailer means a collapsible temporary dwelling structure covered with a water-repellent fabric, mounted on wheels and designed for travel, recreation and vacation uses. 
(5)  Auto camper means a lightweight, collapsible unit that fits on top of an automobile or into the trunk with the cover removed, and designed for travel, recreation and vacation uses. 
Recreational vehicle park means a lot or parcel of land upon which spaces are occupied or intended for occupancy by recreational vehicles designed for travel, recreation and vacation use. 
Religious facility/institution means a structure in which persons regularly assemble for religious worship and which is maintained and controlled by a religious body organized to sustain public worship. A place of religious assembly shall also include structures for related religious activities on the same site such as educational buildings, administrative buildings and sleeping quarters for personnel (parsonage, convent, monastery, etc.). As part of this definition, uses such as daycare, elementary or secondary schools, colleges/universities, assisted living facilities, professional residential facilities, and emergency shelters are not included as "related religious activities" without proper approval for such use. 
Residential equivalent use means a residential-like accommodation other than a dwelling unit, including bed and breakfast, group home, congregate care, nursing home and comparable assisted living facilities. Such uses are eligible to employ the residential equivalent standards as set forth in this chapter for the calculation of density/intensity. No such use shall be eligible to employ the residential equivalent standards for density/intensity for any household that qualifies as a dwelling unit, including any type of use authorized by F.S. ch. 419, community residential homes, which is entitled to be treated as a dwelling unit. 
Retirement community means a congregate community designed and intended to provide housing and specialized needs for a resident population of adults, age 55 years or older, and consisting of independent-living dwelling units, assisted-living dwelling units and/or nursing facilities, where continuing care is provided per a written agreement between the provider and resident. 
Right-of-way means the area of a highway, road, street or way reserved for public use, whether established by prescription, dedication, gift, purchase, eminent domain or any other legal means. Alleys are specifically excluded from the above provisions. 
Satellite antenna means any parabolic or spherical antenna designed to receive television or other signals from orbiting satellites or other devices. A satellite antenna shall be considered as an accessory structure except where it is part of a public utility. 
Setback means the shortest required dimension in feet from the nearest front, side or rear property line to a maximum permitted building line or area that permits a use or structure, as prescribed in section 70-865. 
Shopping center means a grouping of retail stores erected upon a parcel, lot or contiguous lots. 
Sign means any combination of structure and message in the form of an outdoor sign, display, device, figure, drawing, painting, message, placard, poster, billboard, advertising structure, advertisement, logo, symbol, or other form, whether placed individually or on a V-type, back-to-back, side-to-side, or used to advertise or inform, any part of the advertising message or informative contents of which is visible any place and as further defined in chapter 66. 
Solar energy system means a solar collection (such as solar panels) or other device or structural design feature of a structure that relies upon sunshine as an energy source and is capable of collecting, distributing and storing the sun's radiant energy to use for water heating, space heating or cooling or other applications. 
Special exception means a use that would not be appropriate generally or without restriction throughout the particular zoning district or classification and which must be approved pursuant to this chapter, article III. 
Structural alteration means any change in the supporting members of the structure such as bearing walls, columns, beams or girders except for the repair or replacement thereof. 
Structure means anything constructed or erected, the use of which requires permanent location on the land or attachment to something having a permanent location on the land. Fences a maximum of six feet in height, sidewalks, patio slabs, driveways, paved parking lots, and utility poles shall not be considered as structures. Above-ground propane/utility tanks and generators on single-family lots shall not be considered a structure, but placement of these tanks will be determined by the city upon application and a subsequent site visit before permit approval. 
Submerged land means the area situated below the mean high water line or the ordinary high water line of a standing body of water, including estuary, lake, pond, river or stream.
